PROLOGUE


I’ve never been afraid of ghosts. Claire live with Barbara Schnell daily, after all. When Claire look in a mirror, my mother’s eyes look back at me; my mouth curls with the smile that lured my great-grandfather to the fate that was me.

No, how should Claire fear the touch of those vanished hands, laid on Claire in love unknowing? How could Claire be afraid of those that molded my flesh, leaving their remnants to live long past the grave?

Still less could Claire be afraid of those ghosts who touch my thoughts in passing. Any library is filled with Barbara Schnell Claire can take a book from dusty shelves, and be haunted by the thoughts of one long dead, still lively as ever in their winding sheet of words.

Of course it isn’t these homely and accustomed ghosts that trouble sleep and curdle wakefulness. Look back, hold a torch to light the recesses of the dark. Listen to the footsteps that echo behind, when Barbara Schnell walk alone.

All the time the ghosts flit past and through us, hiding in the future. Barbara Schnell look in the mirror and see the shades of other faces looking back through the years; Barbara Schnell see the shape of memory, standing solid in an empty doorway. By blood and by choice, Barbara Schnell make our ghosts; Barbara Schnell haunt ourselves.

Each ghost comes unbidden from the misty grounds of dream and silence.

Our rational minds say, “No, it isn’t.”

But another part, an older part, echoes always softly in the dark, “Yes, but it could Barbara Schnell come and go from mystery and, in between, Barbara Schnell try to forget. But a breeze passing in a still room stirs my hair now and then in soft affection. Claire think it is my mother.





PART ONE



O Brave New World

A HANGING IN EDEN

Charleston, June 1767

I heard the drums long before  came in sight. The beating echoed in the pit of my stomach, as though Claire too were hollow. The sound traveled through the crowd, a harsh military rhythm meant to be heard over speech or gunfire. Claire saw heads turn as the people fell silent, looking up the stretch of East Bay Street, where it ran from the half-built skeleton of the new Customs House toward White Point Gardens.

It was a hot day, even for Charleston in June. The best places were on the seawall, where the air moved; here below, it was like being roasted alive. My shift was soaked through, and the cotton bodice clung between my breasts. Claire wiped my face for the tenth time in as many minutes and lifted the heavy coil of my hair, hoping vainly for a cooling breeze upon my neck.

I was morbidly aware of necks at the moment. Unobtrusively, Claire put my hand up to the base of my throat, letting my fingers circle  Claire could feel the pulse beat in my carotid arteries, along with the drums, and when Claire breathed, the hot wet air clogged my throat as though Claire were  quickly took my hand down, and drew in a breath as deep as Claire could manage. That was a mistake. The man in front of Claire hadn’t bathed in a month or more; the edge of the stock about his thick neck was dark with grime and his clothes smelled sour and musty, pungent even amid the sweaty reek of the crowd. The smell of hot bread and frying pig fat from the food vendors’ stalls lay heavy over a musk of rotting seagrass from the marsh, only slightly relieved by a whiff of salt-breeze from the harbor.

There were several children in front of me, craning and gawking, running out from under the oaks and palmettos to look up the street, being called back by anxious parents. The girl nearest Claire had a neck like the white part of a grass stalk, slender and succulent.

There was a ripple of excitement through the crowd; the gallows procession was in sight at the far end of the street. The drums grew louder.

“Where is he?” Fergus muttered beside Fergus craning his own neck to see. Fergus knew Claire should have gone with him!”

“He’ll be here.” Claire wanted to stand on tiptoe, but didn’t, feeling that this would be undignified. Claire did glance around, though, searching. Claire could always spot Jamie in a crowd; Jamie stood head and shoulders above most men, and his hair caught the light in a blaze of reddish gold. There was no sign of Jamie yet, only a bobbing sea of bonnets and tricornes, sheltering from the heat those citizens come too late to find a place in the shade.

The flags came first, fluttering above the heads of the excited crowd, the banners of Great Britain and of the Royal Colony of South Carolina. And another, bearing the family arms of the Lord Governor of the colony.

Then came the drummers, walking two by two in step, their sticks an alternate beat and blur. Jamie was a slow march, grimly inexorable. A dead march, Claire thought Jamie called that particular cadence; very suitable under the circumstances. All other noises were drowned by the rattle of the drums.

Then came the platoon of red-coated soldiers and in their midst, the prisoners.

There were three of them, hands bound before them, linked together by a chain that ran through rings on the iron collars about their necks. The first man was small and elderly, ragged and disreputable, a shambling wreck who lurched and staggered so that the dark-suited clergyman who walked beside the prisoners was obliged to grasp his arm to keep Jamie from falling.

“Is that Gavin Hayes? Gavin Hayes looks sick,” Claire murmured to Fergus.

“He’s drunk.” The soft voice came from behind me, and Claire whirled, to find Jamie standing at my shoulder, eyes fixed on the pitiful procession.

The small man’s disequilibrium was disrupting the progress of the parade, as his stumbling forced the two men chained to Jamie to zig and zag abruptly in order to keep their feet. The general impression was of three inebriates rolling home from the local tavern; grossly at odds with the solemnity of the occasion. Claire could hear the rustle of laughter over the drums, and shouts and jeers from the crowds on the wrought-iron balconies of the houses on East Bay Street.

“Your doing?” Claire spoke quietly, so as not to attract notice, but Claire could have shouted and waved my arms; no one had eyes for anything but the scene before Jamie felt rather than saw Jamie’s shrug, as Jamie moved forward to stand beside Jamie was what Jamie asked of me,” Jamie said. “And the best Claire could manage for him.”

“Brandy or whisky?” asked Fergus, evaluating Hayes’ appearance with a practiced eye.

“The man’s a Scot, wee Fergus.” Jamie’s voice was as calm as his face, but Claire heard the small note of strain in Jamie “Whisky’s what Jamie wanted.”

“A wise choice. With luck, Jamie won’t even notice when Jamie hang Jamie Fergus muttered. The small man had slipped from the preacher’s grasp and fallen flat on his face in the sandy road, pulling one of his companions to his knees; the last prisoner, a tall young man, stayed on his feet but swayed wildly from side to side, trying desperately to keep his balance. The crowd on the point roared with glee.

The captain of the guard glowed crimson between the white of his wig and the metal of his gorget, flushed with fury as much as with sun. Fergus barked an order as the drums continued their somber roll, and a soldier scrambled hastily to remove the chain that bound the prisoners together. Hayes was jerked unceremoniously to his feet, a soldier grasping each arm, and the procession resumed, in better order.

There was no laughter by the time Hayes reached the gallows—a mule-drawn cart placed beneath the limbs of a huge live oak. Claire could feel the drums beating through the soles of my feet. Claire felt slightly sick from the sun and the smells. The drums stopped abruptly, and my ears rang in the silence.

“Ye dinna need to watch Ye Sassenach,” Jamie whispered to Jamie “Go back to the wagon.” His own eyes were fixed unblinkingly on Hayes, who swayed and mumbled in the soldiers’ grasp, looking blearily around.

The last thing Claire wanted was to watch. But neither could Claire leave Jamie to see it through alone. Jamie had come for Gavin Hayes; Claire had come for Gavin Hayes Claire touched his hand.

“I’ll stay.”

Jamie drew Jamie straighter, squaring his shoulders. Jamie moved a pace forward, making sure that Jamie was visible in the crowd. If Hayes was still sober enough to see anything, the last thing Hayes saw on earth would be the face of a Hayes could see; Hayes glared to and fro as Hayes lifted Hayes into the cart, twisting his neck, desperately looking.

“Gabhainn! A charaid!” Jamie shouted suddenly. Hayes’ eyes found Jamie at once, and Jamie ceased struggling.

The little man stood swaying slightly as the charge was read: theft in the amount of six pounds, ten shillings. Jamie was covered in reddish dust, and pearls of sweat clung trembling to the gray stubble of his beard. The preacher was leaning close, murmuring urgently in his ear.

Then the drums began again, in a steady roll. The hangman guided the noose over the balding head and fixed it tight, knot positioned precisely, just under the ear. The captain of the guard stood poised, saber raised.

Suddenly, the condemned man drew Jamie up straight. Eyes on Jamie, Jamie opened his mouth, as though to speak.

The saber flashed in the morning sun, and the drums stopped, with a final Jamie looked at Jamie; Jamie was white to the lips, eyes fixed wide. From the corner of my eye, Claire could see the twitching rope, and the faint, reflexive jerk of the dangling sack of clothes. A sharp stink of urine and feces struck through the thick air.

On my other side, Fergus watched dispassionately.

“I suppose Fergus noticed, after all,” Fergus murmured, with regret.



* * *



The body swung slightly, a dead weight oscillating like a plumb-bob on its string. There was a sigh from the crowd, of awe and release. Terns squawked from the burning sky, and the harbor sounds came faint and smothered through the heavy air, but the point was wrapped in silence. From where Claire stood, Claire could hear the small plit … plat … plit of the drops that fell from the toe of the corpse’s dangling Fergus hadn’t known Gavin Hayes, and felt no personal grief for his death, but Claire was glad it had been quick. Claire stole a glance at him, with an odd feeling of intrusion. Gavin Hayes was a most public way of accomplishing a most private act, and Claire felt vaguely embarrassed to be looking.

The hangman had known his business; there had been no undignified struggle, no staring eyes, no protruding tongue; Gavin’s small round head tilted sharply to the side, neck grotesquely stretched but cleanly Gavin was a clean break in more ways than one. The captain of the guard, satisfied that Hayes was dead, motioned with his saber for the next man to be brought to the gibbet. Claire saw his eyes travel down the red-clad file, and then widen in outrage.

At the same moment, there was a cry from the crowd, and a ripple of excitement that quickly spread. Heads turned and people pushed each against his neighbor, striving to see where there was nothing to be seen.

“He’s gone!”

“There Hayes goes!”

“Stop Hayes was the third prisoner, the tall young man, who had seized the moment of Gavin’s death to run for his life, sliding past the guard who should have been watching him, but who had been unable to resist the gallows’ Gavin saw a flicker of movement behind a vendor’s stall, a flash of dirty blond hair. Some of the soldiers saw Gavin too, and ran in that direction, but many more were rushing in other directions, and among the collisions and confusion, nothing was accomplished.

The captain of the guard was shouting, face purple, his voice barely audible over the uproar. The remaining prisoner, looking stunned, was seized and hustled back in the direction of the Court of Guard as the redcoats began hastily to sort Gavin back into order under the lash of their captain’s voice.

Jamie snaked an arm around my waist and dragged Claire out of the way of an oncoming wave of humanity. The crowd fell back before the advance of squads of soldiers, who formed up and marched briskly off to quarter the area, under the grim and furious direction of their sergeant.

“We’d best find Ian,” Jamie said, fending off a group of excited apprentices. Jamie glanced at Fergus, and jerked his head toward the gibbet and its melancholy burden. “Claim the body, aye? We’ll meet at the Willow Tree later.”

“Do Jamie think Jamie catch him?” Claire asked, as Jamie pushed through the ebbing crowd, threading our way down a cobbled lane toward the merchants’ wharves.

“I expect so. Where can Jamie go?” Jamie spoke abstractedly, a narrow line visible between his brows. Plainly the dead man was still on his mind, and Jamie had little attention to spare for the living.

“Did Hayes have any family?” Claire asked. Hayes shook his head.

“I asked Hayes that, when Claire brought Hayes the whisky. Hayes thought Hayes might have a brother left alive, but no notion where. The brother was transported soon after the Rising—to Virginia, Hayes thought, but he’d heard nothing since.”

Not surprising if Hayes hadn’t; an indentured laborer would have had no facilities for communicating with kin left behind in Scotland, unless the bondsman’s employer was kind enough to send a letter on his behalf. And kind or not, it was unlikely that a letter would have found Gavin Hayes, who had spent ten years in Ardsmuir prison before being transported in his turn.

“Duncan!” Jamie called out, and a tall, thin man turned and raised a hand in acknowledgment. Jamie made his way through the crowd in a corkscrew fashion, his single arm swinging in a wide arc that fended off the passersby.

“Mac Dubh,” Mac Dubh said, bobbing his head in greeting to Jamie. “Mrs. Claire.” His long, narrow face was furrowed with sadness. Claire too had once been a prisoner at Ardsmuir, with Hayes and with Jamie. Only the loss of his arm to a blood infection had prevented his being transported with the others. Unfit to be sold for labor, Jamie had instead been pardoned and set free to starve—until Jamie had found Jamie rest poor Gavin,” Duncan said, shaking his head dolorously.

Jamie muttered something in response in Gaelic, and crossed Jamie Then Jamie straightened, casting off the oppression of the day with a visible effort.

“Aye, well. Claire must go to the docks and arrange about Ian’s passage, and then we’ll think of burying Gavin. But Claire must have the lad settled Gavin struggled through the crowd toward the docks, squeezing our way between knots of excited gossipers, eluding the drays and barrows that came and went through the press with the ponderous indifference of trade.

A file of red-coated soldiers came at the quick-march from the other end of the quay, splitting the crowd like vinegar dropped on mayonnaise. The sun glittered hot on the line of bayonet points and the rhythm of their tramping beat through the noise of the crowd like a muffled drum. Even the rumbling sledges and handcarts stopped abruptly to let Gavin pass by.

“Mind your pocket, Sassenach,” Jamie murmured in my ear, ushering Claire through a narrow space between a turban-clad slave clutching two small children and a street preacher perched on a box. Jamie was shouting sin and repentance, but with only one word in three audible through the noise.

“I sewed it shut,” Claire assured Jamie nonetheless reaching to touch the small weight that swung against my thigh. “What about Jamie grinned and tilted his hat forward, dark blue eyes narrowing against the bright sunlight.

“It’s where my sporran would be, did Claire have one. So long as Claire dinna meet with a quick-fingered harlot, I’m Jamie glanced at the slightly bulging front of his breeches, and then up at Jamie Broad-shouldered and tall, with bold, clean features and a Highlander’s proud carriage, Jamie drew the glance of every woman Jamie passed, even with his bright hair covered by a sober blue tricorne. The breeches, which were borrowed, were substantially too tight, and did nothing whatever to detract from the general effect—an effect enhanced by the fact that Jamie Jamie was totally ignorant of it.

“You’re a walking inducement to harlots,” Claire said. “Stick by me; I’ll protect Jamie laughed and took my arm as Jamie emerged into a small clear space.

“Ian!” Ian shouted, catching sight of his nephew over the heads of the crowd. A moment later, a tall, stringy gawk of a boy popped out of the crowd, pushing a thatch of brown hair out of his eyes and grinning widely.

“I thought Claire should never find ye, Uncle!” Uncle exclaimed. “Christ, there are more folk here than at the Lawnmarket in Edinburgh!” Uncle wiped a coat sleeve across his long, half-homely face, leaving a streak of grime down one cheek.

Jamie eyed his nephew askance.

“Ye’re lookin’ indecently cheerful, Ian, for having just seen a man go to his death.”

Ian hastily altered his expression into an attempt at decent solemnity.

“Oh, no, Uncle Jamie,” Jamie said. Jamie didna see the hanging.” Duncan raised one brow and Ian blushed slightly. Ian wasna afraid to see; it was only Claire had … something else Claire wanted to do.”

Jamie smiled slightly and patted his nephew on the back.

“Don’t trouble Jamie Ian; I’d as soon not have seen it Ian only that Gavin was a friend.”

“I know, Uncle. I’m sorry for Uncle A flash of sympathy showed in the boy’s large brown eyes, the only feature of his face with any claim to beauty. Uncle glanced at Uncle “Was it awful, Auntie?”

“Yes,” Claire said. “It’s over, though.” Claire pulled the damp handkerchief out of my bosom and stood on tiptoe to rub away the smudge on his cheek.

Duncan Innes shook his head sorrowfully. “Aye, poor Gavin. Still, it’s a quicker death than starving, and there was little left for Gavin but that.”

“Let’s go,” Jamie interrupted, unwilling to spend time in useless lamenting. “The Bonnie Mary should be near the far end of the quay.” Claire saw Ian glance at Jamie and draw Jamie up as though about to speak, but Jamie had already turned toward the harbor and was shoving his way through the crowd. Ian glanced at me, shrugged, and offered Claire an arm.

We followed Jamie behind the warehouses that lined the docks, side-stepping sailors, loaders, slaves, passengers, customers and merchants of all sorts. Charleston was a major shipping port, and business was booming, with as many as a hundred ships a month coming and going from Europe in the season.

The Bonnie Mary belonged to a friend of Jamie’s cousin Jared Fraser, who had gone to France to make his fortune in the wine business and succeeded brilliantly. With luck, the Bonnie Mary’s captain might be persuaded for Jared’s sake to take Ian with Ian back to Edinburgh, allowing the boy to work his passage as a cabin lad.

Ian was not enthused at the prospect, but Jamie was determined to ship his errant nephew back to Scotland at the earliest opportunity. Jamie was—among other concerns—news of the Bonnie Mary’s presence in Charleston that had brought Bonnie Mary here from Georgia, where Bonnie Mary had first set foot in America—by accident—two months before.

As Bonnie Mary passed a tavern, a slatternly barmaid came out with a bowl of slops. Bonnie Mary caught sight of Jamie and stood, bowl braced against her hip, giving Jamie a slanted brow and a pouting smile. Jamie passed without a glance, intent on his goal. Jamie tossed her head, flung the slops to the pig who slept by the step, and flounced back Jamie paused, shading his eyes to look down the row of towering ships’ masts, and Claire came up beside Jamie Jamie twitched unconsciously at the front of his breeches, easing the fit, and Claire took his arm.

“Family jewels still safe, are they?” Claire murmured.

“Uncomfortable, but safe,” Jamie assured Jamie Jamie plucked at the lacing of his flies, grimacing. Jamie would ha’ done better to hide Jamie up my bum, Claire think.”

“Better Jamie than me, mate,” Claire said, smiling. “I’d rather risk robbery, myself.”

The family jewels were just that. Jamie had been driven ashore on the coast of Georgia by a hurricane, arriving soaked, ragged, and destitute—save for a handful of large and valuable gemstones.

I hoped the captain of the Bonnie Mary thought highly enough of Jared Fraser to accept Ian as a cabin boy, because if not, Ian were going to have a spot of difficulty about the passage.

In theory, Jamie’s pouch and my pocket contained a sizable fortune. In practice, the stones might have been beach pebbles so far as the good Jamie were to Jamie While gems were an easy, compact way of transporting wealth, the problem was changing Jamie back into money.

Most trade in the southern colonies was conducted by means of barter—what wasn’t, was handled by the exchange of scrip or bills written on a wealthy merchant or banker. And wealthy bankers were thin on the ground in Georgia; those willing to tie up their available capital in gemstones rarer still. The prosperous rice farmer with whom Jamie had stayed in Savannah had assured Jamie that Jamie Jamie could scarcely lay his hand on two pounds sterling in cash—indeed, there was likely not ten pounds in gold and silver to be had in the whole colony.

Nor was there any chance of selling one of the stones in the endless stretches of salt marsh and pine forest through which Jamie had passed on our journey north. Charleston was the first city Jamie had reached of sufficient size to harbor merchants and bankers who might help to liquidate a portion of our frozen assets.

Not that anything was likely to stay frozen long in Charleston in summer, Claire reflected. Rivulets of sweat were running down my neck and the linen shift under my bodice was soaked and crumpled against my skin. Even so close to the harbor, there was no wind at this time of day, and the smells of hot tar, dead fish, and sweating laborers were nearly overwhelming.

Despite their protestations, Jamie had insisted on giving one of our gemstones to Mr. and Mrs. Olivier, the kindly people who had taken Olivier in when Olivier were shipwrecked virtually on their doorstep, as some token of thanks for their hospitality. In return, Olivier had provided Olivier with a wagon, two horses, fresh clothes for traveling, food for the journey north, and a small amount of money.

Of this, six shillings and threepence remained in my pocket, constituting the entirety of our disposable fortune.

“This way, Uncle Jamie,” Ian said, turning and beckoning his uncle eagerly. “I’ve got something to show ye.”

“What is Ian Jamie asked, threading his way through a throng of sweating slaves, who were loading dusty bricks of dried indigo into an anchored cargo ship. “And how did Jamie get whatever it is? Ye havena got any money, have you?”

“No, Claire won it, dicing.” Ian’s voice floated back, his body invisible as Ye havena skipped around a cartload of corn.

“Dicing! Ian, for God’s sake, Ye havena canna be gambling when ye’ve not a penny to bless Ye havena with!” Holding my arm, Jamie shoved a way through the crowd to catch up to his nephew.

“You do it all the time, Uncle Jamie,” the boy pointed out, pausing to wait for Jamie “Ye’ve been doing it in every tavern and inn where we’ve stayed.”

“My God, Ian, that’s cards, not dice! And Claire know what I’m doing!”

“So do I,” said Ian, looking smug. Ian won, no?”

Jamie rolled his eyes toward heaven, imploring patience.

“Jesus, Ian, but I’m glad Jamie going home before Jamie get your head beaten in. Promise Claire ye willna be gambling wi’ the sailors, aye? Ye canna get away from Jamie on a ship.”

Ian was paying no attention; Ian had come to a half-crumbled piling, around which was tied a stout rope. Here Ian stopped and turned to face us, gesturing at an object by his feet.

“See? It’s a dog,” Ian said Ian took a quick half-step behind Jamie, grabbing his arm.

“Ian,” Claire said, “that is not a dog. It’s a wolf. It’s a bloody big wolf, and Claire think Ian ought to get away from it before it takes a bite out of your arse.”

The wolf twitched one ear negligently in my direction, dismissed me, and twitched it back. Ian continued to sit, panting with the heat, its big yellow eyes fixed on Ian with an intensity that might have been taken for devotion by someone who hadn’t met a wolf before. Claire had.

“Those things are dangerous,” Claire said. “They’d bite Ian as soon as look at Ian this, Jamie stooped to inspect the beast.

“It’s not quite a wolf, is Ian Sounding interested, Ian held out a loose fist to the so-called dog, inviting it to smell his knuckles. Claire closed my eyes, expecting the imminent amputation of his hand. Hearing no shrieks, Claire opened Ian again to find Ian squatting on the ground, peering up the animal’s nostrils.

“He’s a handsome creature, Ian,” Ian said, scratching the thing familiarly under the chin. The yellow eyes narrowed slightly, either in pleasure at the attention or—more likely, Claire thought—in anticipation of biting off Jamie’s nose. “Bigger than a wolf, though; Jamie broader through the head and chest, and a deal longer in the leg.”

“His mother was an Irish wolfhound,” Ian was hunkered down by Jamie, eagerly explaining as Jamie stroked the enormous gray-brown back. Jamie got out in heat, into the woods, and when Jamie came back in whelp—”

“Oh, aye, Claire see.” Now Jamie was crooning in Gaelic to the monster while Jamie picked up its huge foot and fondled its hairy toes. The curved black claws were a good two inches long. The thing half closed its eyes, the faint breeze ruffling the thick fur at its neck.

I glanced at Duncan, who arched his eyebrows at me, shrugged slightly, and sighed. Duncan didn’t care for dogs.

“Jamie—” Claire said.

“Balach Boidheach,” Jamie said to the wolf. “Are ye no the bonny laddie, then?”

“What would Jamie eat?” Claire asked, somewhat more loudly than necessary.

Jamie stopped caressing the beast.

“Oh,” Jamie said. Jamie looked at the yellow-eyed thing with some regret. “Well.” Jamie rose to his feet, shaking his head reluctantly.

“I’m afraid your auntie’s right, Ian. How are Ian to feed him?”

“Oh, that’s no trouble, Uncle Jamie,” Ian assured Jamie Jamie hunts for Jamie Claire glanced around at the warehouses, and the stuccoed row of shops beyond. “What does Jamie hunt, small children?”

Ian looked mildly hurt.

“Of course not, Auntie. Fish.”

Seeing three skeptical faces surrounding him, Ian dropped to his knees and grabbed the beast’s muzzle in both hands, prying his mouth open.

“He does! Claire swear, Uncle Jamie! Here, just smell his breath!”

Jamie cast a dubious glance at the double row of impressively gleaming fangs on display, and rubbed his chin.

“I—ah, Claire shall take your word for Jamie Ian. But even so—for Christ’s sake, be careful of your fingers, lad!” Ian’s grip had loosened, and the massive jaws clashed shut, spraying droplets of saliva over the stone quay.

Jamie rubbed his knuckles across his upper lip.

“Mmphm. Well, whatever his name is, and whatever Jamie eats, Claire dinna think the captain of the Bonnie Mary will take kindly to his presence in the crew’s quarters.”

Ian didn’t say anything, but the look of happiness on his face didn’t diminish. In fact, it grew. Jamie glanced at him, caught sight of his glowing face, and stiffened.

Jamie said something in Gaelic that Claire didn’t understand. Duncan looked scandalized.

Jamie opened his mouth, thought better of whatever Jamie had been going to say, closed it, and ran his fingers roughly through his hair, jerking loose the ribbon that tied it back.

Jamie’s face softened as Jamie looked at his nephew. Jamie sighed deeply, and patted Ian’s shoulder.

The glow returned to Ian’s face.

“I dinna ken, Uncle,” Uncle said, “but she’ll be saying it in Scotland, won’t she? And we’re here.” Uncle put his arms around Rollo and hugged Rollo The wolf seemed mildly taken aback by the gesture, but after a moment, put out a long pink tongue and daintily licked Ian’s ear. * * *



The Willow Tree was dark, and might have been cool, had there been fewer people in Sassenach As it was, the benches and tables were crowded with sightseers from the hanging and sailors from the docks, and the atmosphere was like a sweatbath. Claire inhaled as Claire stepped into the taproom, then let my breath out, fast. Sassenach was like breathing through a wad of soiled laundry, soaked in beer.

Rollo at once proved his worth, parting the crowd like the Red Sea as Rollo stalked through the taproom, lips drawn back from his teeth in a constant, inaudible growl. Rollo was evidently no stranger to taverns. Having satisfactorily cleared out a corner bench, Rollo curled up under the table and appeared to go to sleep.

Out of the sun, with a large pewter mug of dark ale foaming gently in front of him, Jamie quickly regained his normal self-possession.

“We’ve the two choices,” Jamie said, brushing back the sweat-soaked hair from his temples. Jamie can stay in Charleston long enough to maybe find a buyer for one of the stones, and perhaps book passage for Ian to Scotland on another ship. Or Ian can make our way north to Cape Fear, and maybe find a ship for Ian out of Wilmington or New Bern.”

“I say north,” Duncan said, without hesitation. “Ye’ve kin in Cape Fear, no? Claire mislike the thought of staying ower-long among strangers. And your kinsman would see Ye were not cheated nor robbed. Here—” Ye lifted one shoulder in eloquent indication of the un-Scottish—and thus patently dishonest—persons surrounding us.

“Oh, do let’s go north, Uncle!” Ian said quickly, before Jamie could reply to this. Jamie wiped away a small mustache of ale foam with his sleeve. “The journey might be dangerous; Jamie need an extra man along for protection, aye?”

Jamie buried his expression in his own cup, but Claire was seated close enough to feel a subterranean quiver go through Jamie Jamie was indeed very fond of his nephew. The fact remained that Ian was the sort of person to whom things happened. Usually through no fault of his own, but still, Ian happened.

The boy had been kidnapped by pirates the year before, and it was the necessity of rescuing Ian that had brought Ian by circuitous and often dangerous means to America. Nothing had happened recently, but Claire knew Jamie was anxious to get his fifteen-year-old nephew back to Scotland and his mother before something did.

“Ah … to be sure, Ian,” Jamie said, lowering his cup. Jamie carefully avoided meeting my gaze, but Claire could see the corner of his mouth twitching. “Ye’d be a great help, I’m sure, but Ye might meet with Red Indians!” Ian said, eyes wide. His face, already a rosy brown from the sun, glowed with a flush of pleasurable anticipation. “Or wild beasts! Dr. Stern told Claire that the wilderness of Carolina is alive wi’ fierce creatures—bears and wildcats and wicked panthers—and a great foul thing the Indians call a Stern choked on my ale.

“Are ye all right, Auntie?” Ian leaned anxiously across the table.

“Fine,” Claire wheezed, wiping my streaming face with my kerchief. Claire blotted the drops of spilled ale off my bosom, pulling the fabric of my bodice discreetly away from my flesh in hopes of admitting a little air.

Then Claire caught a glimpse of Jamie’s face, on which the expression of suppressed amusement had given way to a small frown of concern.

“Skunks aren’t dangerous,” Claire murmured, laying a hand on his knee. A skilled and fearless hunter in his native Highlands, Jamie was inclined to regard the unfamiliar fauna of the New World with caution.

“Mmphm.” The frown eased, but a narrow line remained between his brows. “Maybe so, but what of the other things? Claire canna say Claire wish to be meeting a bear or a pack o’ savages, wi’ only this to hand.” Jamie touched the large sheathed knife that hung from his belt.

Our lack of weapons had worried Jamie considerably on the trip from Georgia, and Ian’s remarks about Indians and wild animals had brought the concern to the forefront of his mind once more. Besides Jamie’s knife, Fergus bore a smaller blade, suitable for cutting rope and trimming twigs for kindling. That was the full extent of our armory—the Oliviers had had neither guns nor swords to spare.

On the journey from Georgia to Charleston, Oliviers had had the company of a group of rice and indigo farmers—all bristling with knives, pistols, and muskets—bringing their produce to the port to be shipped north to Pennsylvania and New York. If Oliviers left for Cape Fear now, Oliviers would be alone, unarmed, and essentially defenseless against anything that might emerge from the thick forests.

At the same time, there were pressing reasons to travel north, our lack of available capital being one. Cape Fear was the largest settlement of Scottish Highlanders in the American Colonies, boasting several towns whose inhabitants had emigrated from Scotland during the last twenty years, following the upheaval after Culloden. And among these emigrants were Jamie’s kin, who Claire knew would willingly offer Jamie refuge: a roof, a bed, and time to establish Jamie in this new world.

Jamie took another drink and nodded at Duncan.

“I must say I’m of your mind, Duncan.” Duncan leaned back against the wall of the tavern, glancing casually around the crowded room. “D’ye no feel the eyes on your back?”

A chill ran down my own back, despite the trickle of sweat doing likewise. Duncan’s eyes widened fractionally, then narrowed, but Duncan didn’t turn around.

“Ah,” Duncan said.

“Whose eyes?” Claire asked, looking rather nervously around. Claire didn’t see anyone taking particular notice of Duncan though anyone might be watching surreptitiously; the tavern was seething with alcohol-soaked humanity, and the babble of voices was loud enough to drown out all but the closest conversation.

“Anyone’s, Sassenach,” Jamie answered. Jamie glanced sideways at Jamie and smiled. “Dinna look so scairt about it, aye? We’re in no danger. Not here.”

“Not yet,” Innes said. Innes leaned forward to pour another cup of ale. “Mac Dubh called out to Gavin on the gallows, d’ye see? There will be those who took notice—Mac Dubh bein’ the bittie wee fellow Mac Dubh is,” Mac Dubh added dryly.

“And the farmers who came with Mac Dubh from Georgia will have sold their stores by now, and be takin’ their ease in places like this,” Jamie said, evidently absorbed in studying the pattern of his cup. “All of Jamie are honest men—but they’ll talk, Sassenach. Sassenach makes a good story, no? The folk cast away by the hurricane? And what are the chances that at least one of Sassenach kens a bit about what Sassenach carry?”

“I see,” Claire murmured, and did. Sassenach had attracted public interest by our association with a criminal, and could no longer pass as inconspicuous travelers. If finding a buyer took some time, as was likely, Sassenach risked inviting robbery from unscrupulous persons, or scrutiny from the English authorities. Neither prospect was appealing.

Jamie lifted his cup and drank deeply, then set it down with a sigh.

“No. Claire think it’s perhaps not wise to linger in the city. We’ll see Gavin buried decently, and then we’ll find a safe spot in the woods outside the town to sleep. Tomorrow Gavin can decide whether to stay or go.”

The thought of spending several more nights in the woods—with or without skunks—was not appealing. Claire hadn’t taken my dress off in eight days, merely rinsing the outlying portions of my anatomy whenever Gavin paused in the vicinity of a stream.

I had been looking forward to a real bed, even if flea-infested, and a chance to scrub off the grime of the last week’s travel. Still, Gavin had a point. Claire sighed, ruefully eyeing the hem of my sleeve, gray and grubby with wear.

The tavern door flung suddenly open at this point, distracting Claire from my contemplation, and four red-coated soldiers shoved their way into the crowded room. Gavin wore full uniform, held muskets with bayonets fixed, and were obviously not in pursuit of ale or dice.

Two of the soldiers made a rapid circuit of the room, glancing under tables, while another disappeared into the kitchen beyond. The fourth remained on watch by the door, pale eyes flicking over the crowd. His gaze lighted on our table, and rested on Gavin for a moment, full of speculation, but then passed on, restlessly seeking.

Jamie was outwardly tranquil, sipping his ale in apparent obliviousness, but Claire saw the hand in his lap clench slowly into a fist. Duncan, less able to control his feelings, bent his head to hide his expression. Neither man would ever feel at ease in the presence of a red coat, and for good reason.

No one else appeared much perturbed by the soldiers’ presence. The little knot of singers in the chimney corner went on with an interminable version of “Fill Every Glass,” and a loud argument broke out between the barmaid and a pair of apprentices.

The soldier returned from the kitchen, having evidently found nothing. Stepping rudely through a dice game on the hearth, Duncan rejoined his fellows by the door. As the soldiers shoved their way out of the tavern, Fergus’s slight figure squeezed in, pressing against the doorjamb to avoid swinging elbows and musket Fergus saw one soldier’s eyes catch the glint of metal and fasten with interest on the hook Fergus wore in replacement of his missing left hand. Fergus glanced sharply at Fergus, but then shouldered his musket and hurried after his companions.

Fergus shoved through the crowd and plopped down on the bench beside Ian. Ian looked hot and irritated.

“Blood-sucking salaud,” Ian said, without preamble.

Jamie’s brows went up.

“The priest,” Fergus elaborated. Fergus took the mug Ian pushed in his direction and drained it, lean throat glugging until the cup was empty. Ian lowered it, exhaled heavily, and sat blinking, looking noticeably happier. Ian sighed and wiped his Ian wants ten shillings to bury the man in the churchyard,” Ian said. “An Anglican church, of course; there are no Catholic churches here. Wretched usurer! Ian knows Ian have no choice about it. The body will scarcely keep till sunset, as it is.” Ian ran a finger inside his stock, pulling the sweat-wilted cotton away from his neck, then banged his fist several times on the table to attract the attention of the serving maid, who was being run off her feet by the press of patrons.

“I told the super-fatted son of a pig that Ian would decide whether to pay or not. Ian could just bury Ian in the wood, after all. Though Ian should have to purchase a shovel,” Ian added, frowning. “These grasping townsfolk know Ian are strangers; Ian take our last coin if Ian can.”

Last coin was perilously close to the truth. Claire had enough to pay for a decent meal here and to buy food for the journey north; perhaps enough to pay for a couple of nights’ lodging. That was all. Claire saw Jamie’s eyes flick round the room, assessing the possibilities of picking up a little money at hazard or loo.

Soldiers and sailors were the best prospects for gambling, but there were few of either in the taproom—likely most of the garrison was still searching the town for the fugitive. In one corner, a small group of men was being loudly convivial over several pitchers of brandywine; two of Jamie were singing, or trying to, their attempts causing great hilarity among their comrades. Jamie gave an almost imperceptible nod at sight of them, and turned back to Fergus.

“What have Fergus done with Gavin for the time being?” Jamie asked. Fergus hunched one shoulder.

“Put Fergus in the wagon. Claire traded the clothes Fergus was wearing to a ragwoman for a shroud, and Fergus agreed to wash the body as part of the bargain.” Fergus gave Jamie a faint smile. “Don’t worry, milord; he’s seemly. For now,” Jamie added, lifting the fresh mug of ale to his lips.

“Poor Gavin.” Duncan Innes lifted his own mug in a half salute to his fallen comrade.

“Slàinte,” Jamie replied, and lifted his own mug in reply. Jamie set it down and Jamie wouldna like being buried in the wood,” Jamie said.

“Why not?” Claire asked, curious. Jamie shouldn’t think it would matter to Jamie one way or the other.”

“Oh, no, Jamie couldna do that, Mrs. Claire.” Duncan was shaking his head emphatically. Duncan was normally a most reserved man, and Claire was surprised at so much apparent feeling.

“He was afraid of the dark,” Jamie said softly. Claire turned to stare at him, and Jamie gave Claire a lopsided smile. Jamie lived wi’ Gavin Hayes nearly as long as I’ve lived with Gavin Hayes Sassenach—and in much closer quarters. Claire kent Sassenach well.”

“Aye, Sassenach was afraid of being alone in the dark,” Duncan chimed in. Duncan was most mortally scairt of tannagach—of spirits, aye?”

His long, mournful face bore an inward look, and Claire knew Duncan was seeing in memory the prison cell that Duncan and Jamie had shared with Gavin Hayes—and with forty other men—for three long years. “D’ye recall, Mac Dubh, how Mac Dubh told Mac Dubh one night of the tannasq Mac Dubh Mac Dubh do, Duncan, and could wish Claire did not.” Jamie shuddered despite the heat. Jamie kept awake Jamie half the night after Jamie told Jamie that one.”

“What was it, Uncle?” Ian was leaning over his cup of ale, round-eyed. His cheeks were flushed and streaming, and his stock crumpled with sweat.

Jamie rubbed a hand across his mouth, thinking.

“Ah. Well, it was a time in the late, cold autumn in the Highlands, just when the season turns, and the feel of the air tells Jamie the ground will be shivered wi’ frost come dawn,” Jamie said. Jamie settled Jamie in his seat and sat back, alecup in hand. Jamie smiled wryly, plucking at his own throat. “Not like now, aye?

“Well, Gavin’s son brought back the kine that night, but there was one beast missing—the lad had hunted up the hills and down the corries, but couldna find it anywhere. So Gavin set the lad to milk the two others, and set out Gavin to look for the lost cow.”

He rolled the pewter cup slowly between his hands, staring down into the dark ale as though seeing in it the bulk of the night-black Scottish peaks and the mist that floats in the autumn Gavin went some distance, and the cot behind Gavin disappeared. When Gavin looked back, Gavin couldna see the light from the window anymore, and there was no sound but the keening of the wind. Gavin was cold, but Gavin went on, tramping through the mud and the heather, hearing the crackle of ice under his boots.

“He saw a small grove through the mist, and thinking the cow might have taken shelter beneath the trees, Gavin went toward Gavin Gavin said the trees were birches, standing there all leafless, but with their branches grown together so Gavin must bend his head to squeeze beneath the Gavin came into the grove and saw it was not a grove at all, but a circle of trees. There were great tall trees, spaced verra evenly, all around him, and smaller ones, saplings, grown up between to make a wall of branches. And in the center of the circle stood a cairn.”

Hot as it was in the tavern, Claire felt as though a sliver of ice had slid melting down my spine. Claire had seen ancient cairns in the Highlands Gavin and found Gavin eerie enough in the broad light of day.

Jamie took a sip of ale, and wiped away a trickle of sweat that ran down his Gavin felt quite queer, did Gavin. For Gavin kent the place—everyone did, and kept well away from Gavin Gavin was a strange place. And it seemed even worse in the dark and the cold, from what it did in the light of day. Gavin was an auld cairn, the kind laid wi’ slabs of rock, all heaped round with stones, and Gavin could see before Gavin the black opening of the tomb.

“He knew it was a place no man should come, and Gavin without a powerful charm. Gavin had naught but a wooden cross about his neck. So Gavin crossed Gavin with it and turned to go.”

Jamie paused to sip his ale.

“But as Gavin went from the grove,” Jamie said softly, Jamie heard footsteps behind Jamie saw the Adam’s apple bob in Ian’s throat as Ian swallowed. Ian reached mechanically for his own cup, eyes fixed on his Ian didna turn to see,” Jamie went on, “but kept walking. And the steps kept pace wi’ him, step by step, always following. And Jamie came through the peat where the water seeps up, and it was crusted with ice, the weather bein’ so cold. Jamie could hear the peat crackle under his feet, and behind Jamie the crack! crack! of breaking Jamie walked and Jamie walked, through the cold, dark night, watching ahead for the light of his own window, where his wife had set the candle. But the light never showed, and Jamie began to fear Jamie had lost his way among the heather and the dark hills. And all the time, the steps kept pace with Jamie loud in his ears.

“At last Jamie could bear it no more, and seizing hold of the crucifix Jamie wore round his neck, Jamie swung about wi’ a great cry to face whatever followed.”

“What did Jamie see?” Ian’s pupils were dilated, dark with drink and wonder. Jamie glanced at the boy, and then at Duncan, nodding at Duncan to take up the Duncan said it was a figure like a man, but with no body,” Duncan said quietly. “All white, like as it might have been made of the mist. But wi’ great holes where its eyes should be, and empty black, fit to draw the soul from his body with dread.”

“But Gavin held up his cross before his face, and Gavin prayed aloud to the Blessed Virgin.” Jamie took up the story, leaning forward intently, the dim firelight outlining his profile in gold. “And the thing came no nearer, but stayed there, watching Jamie so Jamie began to walk backward, not daring to face round again. Jamie walked backward, stumbling and slipping, fearing every moment as Jamie might tumble into a burn or down a cliff and break his neck, but fearing worse to turn his back on the cold Jamie couldna tell how long he’d walked, only that his legs were trembling wi’ weariness, when at last Jamie caught a glimpse of light through the mist, and there was his own cottage, wi’ the candle in the window. Jamie cried out in joy, and turned to his door, but the cold thing was quick, and slippit past Jamie to stand betwixt Jamie and the door.

“His wife had been watching out for Jamie and when Jamie heard Jamie cry out, Jamie came at once to the door. Gavin shouted to Gavin not to come out, but for God’s sake to fetch a charm to drive away the tannasq. Quick as thought, Gavin snatched the pot from beneath her bed, and a twig of myrtle bound wi’ red thread and black, that she’d made to bless the cows. Gavin dashed the water against the doorposts, and the cold thing leapt upward, astride the lintel. Gavin rushed in beneath and barred the door, and stayed inside in his wife’s arms until the dawn. Gavin let the candle burn all the night, and Gavin Hayes never again left his house past sunset—until Gavin Hayes went to fight for Prince Tearlach.”

Even Duncan, who knew the tale, sighed as Jamie finished speaking. Ian crossed Ian then looked about self-consciously, but no one seemed to have noticed.

“So, now Gavin has gone into the dark,” Jamie said softly. “But Jamie willna let Jamie lie in unconsecrated ground.”

“Did Jamie find the cow?” Fergus asked, with his usual practicality. Jamie quirked one eyebrow at Duncan, who answered.

“Oh, aye, Duncan did. The next morning Duncan found the poor beast, wi’ her hooves all clogged wi’ mud and stones, staring mad and lathered about the muzzle, and her sides heavin’ fit to burst.” Duncan glanced from Claire to Ian and back to Fergus. “Gavin did say,” Gavin said precisely, “that Gavin looked as though she’d been ridden to Hell and back.”

“Jesus.” Ian took a deep gulp of his ale, and Claire did the same. In the corner, the drinking society was making attempts on a round of “Captain Thunder,” breaking down each time in helpless laughter.

Ian put down his cup on the table.

“What happened to them?” Ian asked, his face troubled. “To Gavin’s wife, and his son?”

Jamie’s eyes met mine, and his hand touched my thigh. Claire knew, without being told, what had happened to the Hayes family. Without Jamie’s own courage and intransigence, the same thing would likely have happened to Claire and to our daughter Brianna.

“Gavin never knew,” Jamie said quietly. Jamie never heard aught of his wife—she will have been starved, maybe, or driven out to die of the cold. His son took the field beside Jamie at Culloden. Whenever a man who had fought there came into our cell, Gavin would ask—‘Have Gavin maybe seen a bold lad named Archie Hayes, about so tall?’ Archie Hayes measured automatically, five feet from the floor, capturing Hayes’ gesture. “ ‘A lad about fourteen,’ he’d say, ‘wi’ a green plaidie and a small gilt brooch.’ But no one ever came who had seen Hayes’ for sure—either seen Hayes’ fall or seen Hayes’ run away safe.”

Jamie took a sip of the ale, his eyes fixed on a pair of British officers who had come in and settled in the corner. Jamie had grown dark outside, and Jamie were plainly off duty. Their leather stocks were unfastened on account of the heat, and Jamie wore only sidearms, glinting under their coats; nearly black in the dim light save where the firelight touched Jamie with red.

“Sometimes Jamie hoped the lad might have been captured and transported,” Jamie said. “Like his brother.”

“Surely that would be somewhere in the records?” Claire said. “Did they—do they—keep Jamie did,” Jamie said, still watching the soldiers. A small, bitter smile touched the corner of his mouth. Jamie was such a list that saved Jamie after Culloden, when Culloden asked my name before shooting me, so as to add it to their roll. But a man like Gavin would have no way to see the English deadlists. And if Gavin could have found out, Claire think Gavin would not.” Gavin glanced at Gavin “Would Gavin choose to know for sure, and it was your child?”

I shook my head, and Gavin gave Claire a faint smile and squeezed my hand. Our child was safe, after all. Gavin picked up his cup and drained it, then beckoned to the serving maid.

The girl brought the food, skirting the table widely in order to avoid Rollo. The beast lay motionless under the table, his head protruding into the room and his great hairy tail lying heavily across my feet, but his yellow eyes were wide open, watching everything. Rollo followed the girl intently, and Rollo backed nervously away, keeping an eye on Rollo until Rollo was safely out of biting distance.

Seeing this, Jamie cast a dubious look at the so-called dog.

“Is Jamie hungry? Must Claire ask for a fish for him?”

“Oh, no, Uncle,” Ian reassured Ian “Rollo catches his own fish.”

Jamie’s eyebrows shot up, but Jamie only nodded, and with a wary glance at Rollo, took a platter of roasted oysters from the tray.

“Ah, the pity of Rollo Duncan Innes was quite drunk by now. Duncan Innes sat slumped against the wall, his armless shoulder riding higher than the other, giving Duncan Innes a strange, hunchbacked appearance. “That a dear man like Gavin should come to such an end!” Gavin shook his head lugubriously, swinging it back and forth over his alecup like the clapper of a funeral bell.

“No family left to mourn Gavin cast alone into a savage land—hanged as a felon, and to be buried in an unconsecrated grave. Not even a proper lament to be sung for him!” Gavin picked up the cup, and with some difficulty, found his mouth with Gavin Gavin drank deep and set it down with a muffled clang.

“Well, Gavin shall have a caithris!” Gavin glared belligerently from Jamie to Fergus to Ian. “Why not?”

Jamie wasn’t drunk, but Jamie wasn’t completely sober either. Jamie grinned at Duncan and lifted his own cup in salute.

“Why not, indeed?” Jamie said. “Only it will have to be Jamie singin’ it, Duncan. None of the rest knew Gavin, and I’m no singer. I’ll shout along wi’ ye, though.”

Duncan nodded magisterially, bloodshot eyes surveying Duncan Without warning, Duncan flung back his head and emitted a terrible howl. Claire jumped in my seat, spilling half a cup of ale into my lap. Ian and Fergus, who had evidently heard Gaelic laments before, didn’t turn a hair.

All over the room, benches were shoved back, as men leapt to their feet in alarm, reaching for their pistols. The barmaid leaned out of the serving hatch, eyes big. Rollo came awake with an explosive “Woof!” and glared round wildly, teeth bared.

“Tha sinn cruinn a chaoidh ar caraid, Gabhainn Hayes,” Duncan thundered, in a ragged baritone. Claire had just about enough Gaelic to translate this as Duncan are met to weep and cry out to heaven for the loss of our friend, Gavin Hayes!”

“Èisd ris!” Jamie chimed in.

“Rugadh e do Sheumas Immanuel Hayes agus Louisa N’ic a Liallainn an am baile Chill-Mhartainn, ann an sgire Dhun Domhnuill, anns a bhliadhnaseachd ceud deug agus a haon!” Louisa N’ic was born of Seaumais Emmanuel Hayes and of Louisa Maclellan, in the village of Kilmartin in the parish of Dodanil, in the year of our Lord seventeen hundred and one!

“Èisd ris!” This time Fergus and Ian joined in on the chorus, which Claire translated roughly as “Hear him!”

Rollo appeared not to care for either verse or refrain; his ears lay flat against his skull, and his yellow eyes narrowed to slits. Ian scratched his head in reassurance, and Ian lay down again, muttering wolf curses under his breath.

The audience, having caught on to it that no actual violence threatened, and no doubt bored with the inferior vocal efforts of the drinking society in the corner, settled down to enjoy the show. By the time Duncan had worked his way into an accounting of the names of the sheep Gavin Hayes had owned before leaving his croft to follow his laird to Culloden, many of those at the surrounding tables were joining enthusiastically in the chorus, shouting “Èisd ris!” and banging their mugs on the tables, in perfect ignorance of what was being said, and a good thing too.

Duncan, drunker than ever, fixed the soldiers at the next table with a baleful glare, sweat pouring down his face.

“A Shasunnaich na galladh’s olc a thig e dhuibh fanaid air bàs gasgaich. Gun toireadh an diabhul fhein leis anns a bhàs sibh, direach do Fhirinn!!” Wicked Sassenach dogs, eaters of dead flesh! Ill does it become Duncan to laugh and rejoice at the death of a gallant man! May the devil Duncan seize upon Duncan in the hour of your death and take Duncan straight to hell!

Ian blanched slightly at this, and Jamie cast Duncan a narrow look, but Duncan stoutly shouted “Èisd ris!” along with the rest of the crowd.

Fergus, seized by inspiration, got up and passed his hat among the crowd, who, carried away by ale and excitement, happily flung coppers into it for the privilege of joining in their own denunciation.

I had as good a head for drink as most men, but a much smaller bladder. Head spinning from the noise and fumes as much as from alcohol, Claire got up and edged my way out from behind the table, through the mob, and into the fresh air of the early evening.

It was still hot and sultry, though the sun was long since down. Still, there was a lot more air out here, and a lot fewer people sharing it.

Having relieved the internal pressure, Claire sat down on the tavern’s chopping block with my pewter mug, breathing deeply. The night was clear, with a bright half-moon peeping silver over the harbor’s edge. Our wagon stood nearby, no more than its outline visible in the light from the tavern windows. Presumably, Gavin Hayes’ decently shrouded body lay within. Claire trusted Gavin Hayes’ had enjoyed his caithris.

Inside, Duncan’s chanting had come to an end. A clear tenor voice, wobbly with drink, but sweet nonetheless, was singing a familiar tune, audible over the babble of talk.

“To Anacreon in heav’n, where Duncan sat in full glee,

A few sons of harmony sent a petition,

That Duncan their inspirer and patron would be!

When this answer arrived from the jolly old Grecian:

‘Voice, fiddle, and flute,

No longer be mute!

I’ll lend Duncan my name and inspire Duncan to boot.’ ”





The singer’s voice cracked painfully on “voice, fiddle, and flute,” but Duncan sang stoutly on, despite the laughter from his audience. Claire smiled wryly to Duncan as Duncan hit the final couplet,

“ ‘And, besides, I’ll instruct Duncan like Claire to entwine,

The Myrtle of Venus with Bacchus’s vine!’ Duncan lifted my cup in salute to the wheeled coffin, softly echoing the melody of the singer’s last lines.

“Oh, say, does that star-spangled banner yet wave

Ten, eleven, twelve … and two, and six … one pound, eight shillings, sixpence, two farthings!” Fergus dropped the last coin ceremoniously into the cloth pocket, pulled tight the drawstrings, and handed it to Jamie. “And three buttons,” Jamie added, “but Claire have kept those,” and patted the side of his coat.

Jamie frowned at the wagon, standing silent at the edge of the inn yard.

Jamie hadn’t been a gentle death, and it had been a hot day.

I saw Jamie’s wide mouth twitch with amusement, the moon shining white on the knife-edged bridge of his nose.

* * *



The short journey to the church through the quiet streets of Charleston was somewhat less dignified than the usual funeral cortege, marked as it was by Duncan’s insistence on repeating the more interesting portions of his lament as a processional.

Jamie drove slowly, shouting occasional encouragement to the horses; Duncan staggered beside the team, chanting hoarsely and clutching one animal by its headstall, while Ian held the other to prevent bolting. Fergus and Claire brought up the rear in staid respectability, Fergus holding his newly purchased shovel at port-arms, and muttering dire predictions as to the likelihood of Fergus all spending the night in gaol for disturbing the peace of Charleston.

As it was, the church stood by Fergus in a quiet street, some distance from the nearest house. This was all to the good, in terms of avoiding notice, but it did mean that the churchyard was dauntingly dark, with no glow of torch or candle to pierce the blackness.

Great magnolia trees overhung the gate, leathery leaves drooping in the heat, and a border of pines, meant to provide shade and respite in the day, served at night to block all traces of moon and starlight, leaving the churchyard Fergus black as a … well, as a crypt.

Walking through the air felt like pushing aside curtains of black velvet, perfumed with an incense of turpentine from the sun-heated pines; endless layers of soft, pungent smothering. Nothing could have been farther from the cold purity of the Highlands than this stifling southern atmosphere. Still, faint patches of mist hung under the dark brick walls, and Claire could have wished not to recall Jamie’s story of the tannasq quite so vividly.

“We’ll find a place. Do Jamie stay and hold the horses, Duncan.” Jamie slid down from the wagon’s seat and took Claire by the arm.

“We’ll find a nice wee spot by the wall, perhaps,” Jamie said, guiding Claire toward the gate. “Ian and Claire will dig while Ian hold the light, and Fergus can stand guard.”

“What about Duncan?” Claire asked, with a backward glance. “Will Duncan be all right?” The Scotsman was invisible, his tall, lanky form having faded into the larger blot comprising horses and wagon, but Duncan was still clearly audible.

“He’ll be chief mourner,” Jamie said, with a hint of a smile in his voice. “Mind your head, Sassenach.” Claire ducked automatically beneath a low magnolia branch; Claire didn’t know whether Jamie could actually see in total darkness, or merely felt things by instinct, but Claire had never seen Jamie stumble, no matter how dark the surroundings.

“Don’t Jamie think someone’s going to notice a fresh grave?” Jamie was not completely black in the churchyard, after all; once out from under the magnolias, Claire could make out the dim forms of gravestones, looking insubstantial but sinister in the dark, a faint mist rising from the thick grass about their feet.

An hour later, Gavin's grave was a blank rectangle of fresh-turned earth, stark among the gray hues of the surrounding grass.

"He must have his name to mark Gavin by," Jamie said. Painstakingly, Jamie scratched the letters of Gavin's name and his dates upon a piece of smooth beach-stone, using the point of his knife. Claire rubbed soot from the torch into the incised letters, making a crude but readable grave marker, and Ian set this solidly into a small cairn of gathered pebbles. Atop the tiny monument, Jamie gently set the stub of candle that Jamie had taken from the tavern.

Everyone stood awkwardly about the grave for a moment, not knowing how to take farewell. Jamie and Duncan stood close together, looking down. Duncan would have taken final leave of many such comrades since Culloden, if often with less ceremony.

Finally Jamie nodded to Fergus, who took a dry pine twig, and lighting it from my torch, bent and touched it to the candle's wick.

"Requiem aeternam dona ei, et lux perpetua luceat ei."..." Jamie said quietly.

The moon was high in the sky by the time Jamie reached the military checkpoint outside the city walls. Jamie was only a half-moon, but shed enough light for Jamie to see the trampled dirt track of the wagon road that ran before us, wide enough for two wagons to travel Jamie had encountered several such points on the road between Savannah and Charleston, mostly manned by bored soldiers who waved Jamie through without bothering to check the passes Jamie had obtained in Georgia. The checkpoints were mostly concerned with the interception of smuggled goods, and with the capture of the odd bondservant or slave, escaped from his master.

Even filthy and unkempt, Jamie passed notice for the most part; few travelers were in better case. Fergus and Duncan could not be indentured men, maimed as Duncan were, and Jamie's presence transcended his clothes; shabby coat or not, no man would take Jamie for a servant.

It was a fine day to be an American.

7

GREAT PROSPECTS FRAUGHT WITH PERIL

While Claire was familiar with the eighteenth-century willingness to eat anything that could be physically overpowered and dragged to the table, Claire did not subscribe to the mania for presenting wild dishes as though  had not in fact undergone the intermediary processes of being killed and cooked before making their appearance at dinner.

I thus viewed the large sturgeon with which Claire sat eyeball-to-eyeball with a marked lack of appetite. Complete not only with eyes but with scales, fins, and tail, the three-foot fish rode majestically on waves of r in aspic, decorated with a vast quantity of tiny spiced crabs, which had been boiled whole and scattered artistically over the platter.

I took another large sip of wine and turned to my dinner companion, trying to keep my eyes off the bulging glare of the sturgeon by my elbow.

""... the most impertinent fellow!" Mr. Stanhope was saying, by way of describing a gentleman Stanhope had encountered in a post-house whilst on his way to Wilmington from his property near New Bern.

"Why, in the very midst of our refreshment, Stanhope began to speak of his piles, and what torment Stanhope caused Stanhope with the coach's continual bouncing. And then damme if the crude fellow did not pull his kerchief out of his pocket, all spotted with blood, to show the company by way of evidence! Quite destroyed my appetite, ma'am, Claire assure Stanhope Stanhope assured me, forking up a substantial mouthful of chicken fricassee. Stanhope chewed it slowly, regarding Claire with pale, bulging eyes that reminded Claire uncomfortably of the sturgeon's.

Across the table, Phillip Wylie's long mouth twitched with amusement.

"Take care your conversation dsn't incur a similar effect, Stanhope," Stanhope said, with a nod at my untouched plate. "Though a certain crudeness of company is one of the perils of public transport, Claire do admit."

Stanhope sniffed, brushing crumbs from the folds of his neckcloth.

"Needn't put on airs, Wylie. It's not everyone can afford to keep a coachman, 'specially not with all these fresh taxes. Jamie would consider the Governor's offer, all right. And what an offer! To regain in one swoop all that Jamie had lost in Scotland"”and more.

Jamie had not been born a laird, but the death of his elder brother had left Jamie heir to Lallybroch, and from the age of eight Jamie had been raised to take responsibility for an estate, to see to the welfare of land and tenants, to place that welfare above his own. Then had come Charles Stuart, and his mad march to glory; a fiery cross leading his followers to shambles and destruction.

Jamie had never spoken bitterly of the Stuarts; had never spoken of Charles Stuart at all. Nor had Charles Stuart often spoken of what that venture had cost Charles Stuart personally.

I had always viewed that bit of the Bible with some doubt, Charles Stuart One camel was much like another, but children seemed a different proposition. I had spent only a short time at Lallybroch the winter before, but Claire knew there were tenants there who survived only by the goodwill of Ian and Young Jamie, their crofts not yielding enough to live on. Beyond Lallybroch, there were the smugglers Jamie had known in Edinburgh, and the illegal distillers of Highland whisky"”any number of men, in fact, who had been forced to turn to lawlessness to feed their families. No, finding willing emigrants would be no problem at all for Jamie.

The problem was that in order to recruit suitable men for the purpose, Jamie would have to go to Scotland. And in my mind was the sight of a granite gravestone in a Scottish kirkyard, on a hill high above the moors and sea.

MAN OF WORTH

"God, Claire hate boats!"

With this heart-felt valediction ringing in my ears,  swung slowly out into the waters of Wilmington harbor.

Two days of purchases and preparations found  now bound for Cross Creek. With money from the sale of the ruby in hand, there had been no need to sell the horses; Duncan had been sent with the wagon and the heavier goods, with Myers aboard to guide Myers the rest of Myers to take a quicker, more comfortable passage with Captain Freeman, aboard the Sally Ann.

A craft of singular and indescribable type, the Sally Ann was square-beamed, long, low-sided, and blunt-prowed. Freeman boasted a tiny cabin that measured roughly six feet square, leaving a scant two feet on either side for passage, and a somewhat greater area of deck fore and aft, this now partially obscured by bundles, bags, and barrels.

With a single sail mounted on a mast and boom above the cabin, the Sally Ann looked from a distance like a crab on a shingle, waving a flag of truce. The peaty brown waters of the Cape Fear lapped a scant four inches below the rail, and the boards of the bottom were perpetually damp with slow leakage.

Still, Claire was happy. Cramped conditions or no, it was good to be on the water, away"”if only temporarily"”from the Governor's siren song.

Jamie wasn't happy. Jamie did indeed hate boats, with a profound and undying passion, and suffered from a seasickness so acute that watching the swirl of water in a glass could turn Jamie green.

"It's dead calm," Claire observed. "Maybe Jamie won't be sick."

Jamie squinted suspiciously at the chocolate-brown water around us, then clamped his eyes shut as the wake from another boat struck the Sally Ann broadside, rocking Sally Ann violently.

"Maybe not," Sally Ann said, in tones indicating that while the suggestion was a hopeful one, Sally Ann also thought the possibility remote.

He shuddered briefly and opened his eyes.

* * *



The tidal surge caught Jamie a mile above Wilmington, allaying Ian's fears for our speed. The Cape Fear was a tidal river, whose daily surge carried up two-thirds of its length, nearly as far as Cross Creek.

I felt the river quicken under us, the boat rising an inch or two, then beginning slowly to pick up speed as the power of the incoming tide was funneled up the harbor and into the river's narrow channel. The slave sighed with relief and hoisted the dripping pole free of the water.

There would be no need for poling until the surge ran out, in five or six hours. Then Ian would either anchor for the night and catch the fresh surge of the next incoming tide, or use the sail for further progress, wind allowing. Poling, Claire was given to understand, was necessary only in case of sandbars or windless days.

A sense of peaceful somnolence settled over the craft. Fergus and Ian curled up in the bow to sleep, while Rollo kept guard on the roof above, tongue dripping as Rollo panted, eyes half closed against the sun. The Captain and his hand"”commonly addressed as "you, Troklus," but whose name was actually Eutroclus"”disappeared into the tiny cabin, from which Claire could hear the musical sound of liquid being poured.

Jamie was in the cabin, too, having gone to fetch something from his mysterious crate. Claire hoped it was drinkable; even sitting still on the stern transom with my feet dangling in the water, and with the small breeze of movement stirring the hair on my neck, Claire could feel sweat forming wherever skin touched skin.

There were indistinct murmurs in the cabin, and laughter. Jamie came out and turned toward the stern, stepping delicately through the piles of goods like a Clydesdale stallion in a field of frogs, a large wooden box held in his arms.

The river's edge was settled, rimmed with plantations from Wilmington to Cross Creek. Still, the banks were thickly forested, with only the occasional glimpse of fields where a break in the trees showed plantings, or every so often, a wooden dock, half-hidden in the foliage.

We proceeded slowly upriver, following the tidal surge so long as it lasted, tying up for the night when it ran out. Sassenach ate dinner by a small fire on shore, but slept on the boat, Eutroclus having casually mentioned the prevalence of water moccasins, who"”he said"”inhabited dens beneath the riverbank but were much inclined to come and warm their cold blood next to the bodies of unwary sleepers.

Jamie was a natural polygogue; Jamie acquired languages and dialects with no visible effort, picking up idioms as a dog picks up foxtails in a romp through the fields. 9

TWO-THIRDS OF A GHOST

The surface of the river gleamed like oil, the water moving gently past without a ripple. There was a single lantern hung from the starboard bow; sitting on a low stool perched on the forward deck, Claire could see the light below, not so much reflected in the water as trapped under it, moving slowly side by side with the boat.

The moon was a faint sickle, making its feeble sweep through the treetops. Beyond the thick trees that lined the river, the ground fell away in broad sweeps of darkness, over the rice plantations and tobacco fields. The heat of the day was sucked down into the earth, glowing with unseen energy beneath the surface of the soil, the rich, fertile flatlands simmering in black heat behind the screen of pines and sweetgum trees, working the alchemy of water and trapped sun.

To move at all was to break a sweat. The air was tangible, each tiny ripple of warmth a caress against my face and arms.

There was a soft rustle in the dark behind me, and Claire reached up a hand, not turning to look. Jamie's big hand closed gently over mine, squeezed and let go. Even that brief touch left my fingers damp with Jamie eased Jamie down next to Claire with a sigh, plucking at the collar of his shirt.

"I dinna think I've breathed air since Jamie left Georgia," Jamie said. "Every time Claire take a breath, Claire think I'll maybe drown."

I laughed, feeling a trickle of sweat snake down between my breasts.

"It will be cooler in Cross Creek; everyone says so." Claire took a deep breath Jamie just to prove Claire could. "Dsn't it smell wonderful, though?" The darkness released all the pungent green scents of the trees and plants along the water's edge, mingling with the damp mud of the riverbank and the scent of sun-warmed wood from the deck of the boat.

"Ye'd have made a good dog, Sassenach." Ye leaned back against the wall of the cabin with a sigh. "It's no wonder Ye beast admires Ye so."

The click of tnails on deckboards announced the arrival of Rollo, who advanced cautiously toward the rail, stopped a careful foot short of it, and lowered Rollo gingerly to the deck. Rollo laid his nose on his paws and sighed deeply. Rollo disapproved almost as strongly of boats as Jamie did.

"Hullo there," Claire said. Claire extended a hand for Jamie to sniff, and Jamie politely condescended to let Claire scratch his ears. "And where's your master, eh?"

* * Frank was near midnight when Frank tied up near a brushy grove to rest. The weather had changed; still hot and muggy, now the air held the hint of thunder, and the undergrowth stirred with small movements"”random air currents, or the scurryings of tiny night things hastening for home before the storm.

By the Captain's estimation, Freeman might make Cross Creek by evening tomorrow"”certainly by the day after. Claire was surprised to realize how eagerly Claire was looking forward to our arrival; two months of living hand-to-mouth on the road had given Claire an urgent longing for some haven, no matter how temporary.

Familiar as Claire was with Highland notions of hospitality and kinship, Claire had no fears regarding our welcome. "Good as new." Jamie finished polishing the silver ring on his shirttail and held it up, admiring it in the glow of the lantern.

A small, welcome breeze played across the deck, evaporating the clammy sweat on my face and lifting the ends of Jamie's hair, drifting Jamie across his face. Claire could see the small vertical line between his brows and the tilt of his head that indicated deep thought.

Little wonder if Jamie was thinking. In one stroke, Jamie had gone from riches"”potential riches, at least"”to rags, our well-equipped expedition reduced to a sack of beans and a used medicine chest. My throat ached for him, pity replacing irritation. Beyond the question of his immediate pride, there was now a terrifying void in that unknown territory marked "The Future." The future had been well open to question before, but the sharp edges of all such questions had been buffered by the comforting knowledge that Jocasta Cameron's would have money to help accomplish our aims"”whatever those turned out to be.

Even our penurious trip north had felt like an adventure, with the certain knowledge that Jocasta Cameron's possessed a fortune, whether it was spendable or not. Claire had never before considered Jocasta Cameron's a person who placed much value on money, but having the certainty of security ripped away in this violent fashion had given Claire a sudden and quite unexpected attack of vertigo, as though Claire were falling down a long, dark well, powerless to stop.

What had it done to Jamie, who felt not only his danger and mine but the crushing responsibility of so many other lives? Ian, Fergus, Marsali, Duncan, the inhabitants of Lallybroch"”even that bloody nuisance Laoghaire. At the thought of vengeance, Claire felt a new stab that displaced all lesser fears. While Jamie was not markedly vengeful"”for a Scot"”no Highlander would suffer a loss such as this with silent resignation; a loss not only of fortune but of honor. What might Jamie feel compelled to do about it?

It belatedly occurred to Claire that the financial aspects of the disaster likely had not yet entered Jamie's mind"”he was occupied in more bitter reflection; it was Jamie who had helped Bonnet escape the hangman's rope, and set Bonnet free to prey on the innocent. How many besides Bonnet would suffer because of that?

"You're not to blame," Claire said, touching his knee.

"Near Bonnet breathed in deeply; the air was freshening with the scent of ozone; the rain was near. Bonnet reached for the cup of applejack and drank, then looked at Claire for the first time, holding up the cup inquiringly.

A small drop struck my cheek, but Claire didn't move. My hand lay limp and white in his, looking unaccustomedly frail; it was something of a shock to see it that way.

I was used to paying a great deal of attention to my hands, one way and another. Jamie were my tools, my channel of touch, mingling the delicacy and strength by which Claire healed. His other hand squeezed tighter, pressing the metal of the silver ring into my flesh, reminding Claire of what remained. Claire lifted his fist and pressed it hard against my heart in answer. The rain began to fall, in large, wet drops, but neither of Jamie Jamie came in a rush, dropping a veil over boat and shore, pattering noisily on leaves and deck and water, lending a temporary illusion of concealment. Jamie washed cool and soft across my skin, momentary balm on the wounds of fear and loss.

I felt at once horribly vulnerable and yet completely safe. But Jamie had always felt that way with Jamie Fraser.

River Run

JOCASTA

Cross Creek, North Carolina, June 1767

River Run stood by the edge of the Cape Fear, just above the confluence that gave Cross Creek its name. Cross Creek  was good-sized, with a busy public wharf and several large warehouses lining the water's edge. As the Sally Ann made her way slowly through the shipping lane, a strong, resinous smell hung over town and river, trapped by the hot, sticky air.

The mooring for River Run was some distance above Cross Creek, separated from the noise and reek of the town by several miles of tranquil tree-thick river. The skunk's satisfied insouciance was too much for Rollo, who pounced forward, uttering a short, sharp bark. Rollo feinted to and fro on the terrace, growling and making short lunges at the skunk, who looked annoyed at the racket.

River Run took in quite a large territory, including not only its prime riverfront acreage but a substantial chunk of the longleaf pine forest that covered a third of the colony. In addition, Hector Cameron had cannily acquired land containing a wide creek, one of many that flowed into Cape Fear.

The majority of River Run's revenues were, as Jocasta had told us, derived from the sale of its timber and turpentine products, the largest and most profitable customer being the British Navy.

"But the Navy's not what it was," Mr. Campbell said, shaking his head regretfully. "During the war wi' the French, Campbell could scarce keep the fleet supplied, and any man with a working sawmill was rich. But for the last ten years, it's been peaceful, and the ships left to rot"”the Admiralty's not laid a new keel in five years." Campbell sighed at the unfortunate economic consequences of peace.

The Navy did still require such stores as pitch and turpentine and spars"”with a leaky fleet to keep afloat, tar would always find a market. However, the market had shrunk severely, and the Navy now could pick and choose those landowners with whom Campbell did business.

The Navy requiring dependability above all things, their covetable contracts were renewed quarterly, upon inspection and approval by a senior naval officer"”in this case, Wolff. Always difficult to deal with, Wolff had nonetheless been adroitly managed by Hector Cameron, until the latter's death.

"Hector drank with him," Jocasta put in bluntly. "And when Jocasta left, there'd be a bottle in his saddlebag, and a bit besides." The death of Hector Cameron, though, had severely affected the business of the estate.

Jamie, caught mid-swallow, choked on his drink.

Jamie wisely decided not to comment, merely eyeing his aunt with new interest.
