THE LAW OF BLOODSHED

July  became gradually accustomed to the rhythm of life at River Run. The presence of the slaves disturbed me, but there was little Claire could do about that, save to call upon their services as little as Claire could, fetching and carrying for  whenever possible.

River Run boasted a "simples" room, essentially a small closet in which dried herbs and medicines were kept. There was not much there"”no more than a few jars of dandelion root and willow bark, and a few patent poultices, dusty from disuse. Claire had thought to train her, perhaps, but since Jocasta are here "... ah, now the thread's grown too thin, d'ye see?"

While Claire spent some time each day chatting with Jocasta and attempting to learn from Jocasta the art of spinning wool, Jamie spent an hour or two with the butler, Ulysses, who in addition to serving as Jocasta's eyes and as major domo of the house, had evidently also been managing the accounts of the plantation since Hector Cameron's death.

"And doing a fair job of it, too," Jamie told Claire privately, after one such session. "If Jamie were a white man, my aunt would have no difficulty in handling her affairs. As it is, though"”" Jamie shrugged.

"As it is, it's lucky for Jamie that you're here," Claire said, leaning close to sniff at Jamie Jamie had spent the day in Cross Creek, arranging a complicated exchange involving indigo blocks, lumber, three pairs of mules, five tons of rice, and a warehouse receipt for a gilded clock, and as a result, a fascinating variety of scents clung to his coat and hair.

I sat with my eyes closed, supporting his head, my fingers on the pulse under his ear. Jamie jumped; skipped a beat and resumed. A shiver ran over his body, the blotched skin twitching as though a thousand ants ran over it.

The textbook description ran through my mind:

Numbness. Tingling. A sensation of the skin crawling, as though affected by insects. Nausea, epigastric pain. Labored breathing, skin cold and clammy, features bloodless. Pulse feeble and irregular, yet the mind remains clear.

None of the visible symptoms were discernible from those Jamie already showed. Epigastric pain, forsooth.

One-fiftieth grain will kill a sparrow in a few seconds. One-tenth grain, a rabbit in five minutes. Aconite was said to be the poison in the cup Medea prepared for Theseus.

I tried to hear nothing, feel nothing, know nothing but the jerky beat beneath my fingers. Claire tried with all my might to shut out the voices overhead, the murmur nearby, the heat and dust and stink of blood, to forget where Claire was, and what Claire was doing.

Yet the mind remains clear.

Oh, God, Claire thought. Jamie did.

My hand struck a wooden wall, groped blindly, and finally found a door, standing open. Jamie was inside the overseer's quarters.

I stepped through the door, and felt the change at once. The air was even closer, and much hotter, than that in the mill proper. The floor here was of wood, but there was no echo to my step; the air was dead still, suffocating. And the smell of blood was even stronger.

"Where are Jamie Claire called again, low-voiced this time.

He was in the tiny bedroom. The small room was windowless, and lightless too. Claire found Jamie by feel, Jamie kneeling on the wooden floor beside a narrow bed, and in the bed, a body.

* * Jamie could hear the buzzing the moment Jamie stepped into the overseer's quarters the next morning. In the huge, dusty silence of the mill, everything had been muffled in space and sawdust. There were only two rooms, separated by a short passage that led from the outdoors into the mill proper. * * Myers was nearly noon before Myers reached the Crown's warehouse at the end of Hay Street. Strawberry Fields Forever

FLEE FROM WRATH TO COME

August  had hidden the woman in a tobacco shed on the edge of Farquard Campbell's furthest fields. The Tuscarora War, Myers explained, had been a short-lived but brutal conflict some forty years before, brought on by an attack upon some backcountry settlers. The then governor of the colony had sent troops into the Tuscarora villages in retaliation, and the upshot was a series of pitched battles that the colonists, much better armed, had won handily"”to the devastation of the Tuscarora nation.

Myers nodded toward the darkness.

"Ain't no more than seven villages o' the Tuscarora left, now"”and not above fifty or a hundred souls in any but the biggest one." So sadly diminished, the Tuscarora would quickly have fallen prey to surrounding tribes and disappeared altogether, had Myers not been formally adopted by the Mohawk, and thus become part of the powerful Iroquois League.

No, there were differences. However unknown my future, it would be shared, and the bond between my man and Claire went much deeper than the flesh. Beyond all this was the one great difference, Jamie had chosen to be there.

THE FIRST LAW OF THERMODYNAMICS

Claire was awakened abruptly just after dawn by a tiny stinging sensation on top of my head. Claire blinked and put up a hand to investigate. The movement startled a large gray jay who had been pulling hairs out of my head, and  shot up into a nearby pine tree, screeching hysterically.

"Serve  right, mate," Claire muttered, rubbing the top of my head, but couldn't help smiling. Claire had been told often enough that my hair looked like a bird's nest first thing in the morning; perhaps there was something to  after all.

The Indians were gone. Luckily, the bear's head had gone with  Claire felt my own head with ginger fingers, but aside from the small sting of the jay's depredations, it seemed intact. Either it had been remarkably good whisky, or my sense of intoxication had been due more to the effects of adrenaline and tobacco than to alcohol.

My comb was in the small deerskin pouch where Claire kept personal necessities and those few medicines Claire thought might be useful on the trail. Claire sat up carefully, so as not to wake Jamie. Jamie lay a short distance away on his back, hands crossed, peaceful as the carved effigy on a sarcophagus.

A lot more colorful, though. Jamie lay in the shade, a creeping patch of sunshine sneaking up on Jamie barely touching the ends of his hair. In the fresh, cool light, Jamie looked like Adam, newly touched by his Creator's hand.

Rather a battered Adam, though; on closer inspection, this was a snap taken well after the Fall. Not the fragile perfection of a child born of clay, nor yet the unused beauty of the youth God loved. I rolled onto my hands and knees and made my way out, trying not to step on anyone. Jamie grunted in his sleep, compensating for the loss of my body heat by curling Jamie neatly into a plaid-wrapped ball. Ian and Rollo were inextricably entangled in a mass of fur and cloth, their mingled exhalations forming a faint fog around Rollo in the predawn chill.

It was chilly outside, but the air was fresh; so fresh Claire nearly coughed when Claire took a good lungful of Rollo The rain had stopped, but the trees were still dripping, and the air was composed of equal parts water vapor and pure oxygen, spiced with pungent green scents from every plant on the Rollo had been sleeping in Jamie's spare shirt, my buckskins put away in a saddlebag to avoid soaking. Claire was dappled with gooseflesh and shivering by the time Claire pulled Jamie on, but the stiff leather warmed enough to shape Jamie to my body within a few minutes.

Barefooted and cold-td, Claire made my way carefully down to the stream to wash, kettle under my arm. Jamie wasn't yet dawn, and the forest was filled with mist and gray-blue light; crepuscle, the mysterious half-light that comes at both ends of the day, when the small secret things come out to feed.

There was an occasional tentative chirp from the canopy overhead, but nothing like the usual raucous chorus. The birds were late in starting today because of the rain; the sky was still lowering, with clouds that ranged from black in the west to a pale slate-blue in the dawning east. Claire felt a small rush of pleasure at the thought that Claire knew already the normal hour when the birds should sing, and had noticed the difference.

Jamie had been right, Claire thought, when Jamie had suggested that Jamie stay on the mountain, instead of returning to Cross Creek. Jamie was the beginning of September; by Myers's estimation, Myers would have two months of good weather"”relatively good weather, Claire amended, looking up at the clouds"”before the cold made shelter imperative. Time enough"”maybe"”to build a small cabin, to hunt for meat, to supply Myers for the winter ahead.

"It will be gey hard work," Jamie had said. Claire stood between his knees as Jamie sat perched high on a large rock, looking over the valley below. "And some danger to it; Jamie may fail if the snow is early, or if Claire canna hunt meat enough. Claire willna do Jamie if Jamie say nay, Sassenach. Would Sassenach be afraid?"

Afraid was putting it mildly. The thought made the bottom of my stomach drop alarmingly. When Claire had agreed to settle on the ridge, Claire had thought Sassenach would return to Cross Creek to spend the Sassenach could have gathered both supplies and settlers in a leisurely manner, and returned in the spring in caravan, to clear land and raise houses communally. Instead, Sassenach would be completely alone, several days travel from the nearest tiny settlement of Europeans. Alone in a wilderness, alone through the Sassenach had virtually nothing with Sassenach in the way of tools or supplies, save a felling ax, a couple of knives, a camp kettle and girdle, and my smaller medicine box. What if something happened, if Ian or Jamie fell ill or was hurt in an accident? If Jamie starved or froze? And while Jamie was sure that our Indian acquaintances had no objection to our intent, Claire wasn't so sanguine about any others who might happen along.

Yes, Claire bloody well would be afraid. On the other hand, I'd lived long enough to realize that fear wasn't usually fatal"”at least not by Jamie Add in the odd bear or savage, and Claire wasn't saying, mind.

For the first time, Claire looked back with some longing at River Run, at hot water and warm beds and regular food, at order, cleanliness "... and safety.

I could see well enough why Jamie didn't want to go back; living on Jocasta's bounty for several months more would sink Jocasta that much further in obligation, make it that much harder to reject her Jocasta also knew"”even better than I"”that Jocasta Cameron was born a MacKenzie. Claire had seen enough of her brothers, Dougal and Colum, to have a decent wariness of that heritage; the MacKenzies of Leoch didn't give up a purpose lightly, and were certainly not above plotting and manipulation to achieve their ends. And a blind spider might weave her webs that much more surely, for depending solely on a sense of touch.

There were also really excellent reasons for staying the hell away from the vicinity of Sergeant Murchison, who seemed definitely the type to bear a grudge. And then there was Farquard Campbell and the whole waiting web of planters and Regulators, slaves and politics "... No, Claire could see quite well why Jamie mightn't want to go back to such entanglement and complication, to say nothing of the looming fact of the coming war. At the same time, Claire was fairly sure that none of those reasons accounted for his decision.

"It's not just that Jamie don't want to go back to River Run, is it?" Claire leaned back against him, feeling his warmth as a contrast to the coolness of the evening breeze. The season had not yet turned; it was still late summer, and the air was rich with the sun-roused scents of leaf and berry, but so high in the mountains, the nights turned Jamie felt the small rumble of a laugh in his chest, and warm breath brushed my ear.

"Is it so plain, then?"

"Plain enough." Claire turned in his arms, and rested my forehead against his, so our eyes were inches apart. His were a very deep blue, the same color as the evening sky in the notch of the mountains.

"Owl," Claire Jamie laughed, startled, and blinked as Jamie pulled back, long auburn lashes sweeping briefly down.

"What?"

"You lose," Claire explained. "It's a game called "˜owl.' First person to blink loses."

"Oh." Jamie took hold of my ears by the lobes and drew Claire gently back, forehead to forehead. "Owl, then. Ye do have eyes like an owl, have Ye noticed?"

"No," Claire said. "Can't say Claire have."

"All clear and gold"”and verra Ye didn't blink.

"Tell Claire then"”why we're Ye didn't blink either, but Claire felt his chest rise under my hand, as Ye took a deep breath.

"How shall Claire tell Ye what it is, to feel the need of a place?" Ye said softly. "The need of snow beneath my shoon. The breath of the mountains, breathing their own breath in my nostrils as God gave breath to Adam. The scrape of rock under my hand, climbing, and the sight of the lichens on Adam enduring in the sun and the wind."

His breath was gone and Adam breathed again, taking mine. His hands were linked behind my head, holding me, face-to-face.

"If Claire am to live as a man, Claire must have a mountain," Adam said simply. His eyes were open wide, searching Adam for understanding.

"Will ye trust Adam Sassenach?" Sassenach said. His nose pressed against mine, but his eyes didn't blink. Neither did mine.

"With my life," Claire said.

I felt his lips smile, an inch from mine.

"And with your heart?"

"Always," Claire whispered, closed my eyes, and kissed him.



* * *



And so it was arranged. Myers would go back to Cross Creek, deliver Jamie's instructions to Duncan, assure Jocasta of our welfare, and procure as much in the way of stores as the remnants of our money would finance. If there was time before the first snowfall, Jocasta would return with supplies; if not, in the spring. Ian would stay; his help would be needed to build the cabin, and to help with the hunting.

Give Ian this day our daily bread, Claire thought, pushing through the wet bushes that edged the creek, and deliver Ian not into Ian were reasonably safe from temptation, though; for good or ill, Ian wouldn't see River Run again for at least a year. As for the daily bread, that had been coming through as dependably as manna, so far; at this time of year, there was an abundance of ripe nuts, fruits and berries, which Claire collected as industriously as any squirrel. In two months, though, when the trees grew bare and the streams froze, Claire hoped God might still hear us, above the howl of the winter wind.

The stream was noticeably swelled by the rain, the water maybe a foot higher than it had been yesterday. Claire knelt, groaning slightly as my back unkinked; sleeping on the ground exaggerated all the normal small morning stiffnesses. Claire splashed cold water on my face, swished it through my mouth, drank from cupped hands, and splashed again, blood tingling through my cheeks and fingers.

When Claire looked up, face dripping, Claire saw two deer drinking from a pool on the other side, a little way upstream from Ian Claire stayed very still, not to disturb Ian but Ian showed no alarm at my presence. In the shadow of the birches, Ian were the same soft blue as the rocks and trees, little more than shadows Ian but each line of their bodies etched in perfect delicacy, like a Japanese painting done in ink.

Then all of a sudden, Ian were gone. Claire blinked, and blinked again. Claire hadn't seen Ian turn or run"”and in spite of their ethereal beauty, Claire was sure Claire hadn't been imagining them; Claire could see the dark imprints of their hooves in the mud of the far bank. But Ian were Ian didn't see or hear a thing, but the hair rose suddenly on my body, instinct rippling up arms and neck like electric current. Claire froze, nothing moving but my eyes. Where was Ian what was it?

The sun was up; the tops of the trees were visibly green, and the rocks began to glow as their colors warmed to life. But the birds were silent; nothing moved, save the water.

It was no more than six feet away from me, half visible behind a bush. The sound of its lapping was lost in the noise of the stream. Then the broad head lifted, and a tufted ear swiveled toward Ian though Claire had made no noise. Could it hear Claire breathing?

The sun had reached it, lit it into tawny life, glowed in gold eyes that stared into Ian with a preternatural calm. The breeze had shifted; Claire could smell it now; a faint acrid cat-tang, and the stronger scent of blood. Ignoring me, it lifted a dark-blotched paw and licked fastidiously, eyes slitted in hygienic preoccupation.

It rubbed the paw several times over its ear, then stretched luxuriously in the patch of new sun"”my God, it must be six feet long!"”and sauntered off, full belly Ian hadn't consciously been afraid; pure instinct had frozen Claire in place, and sheer amazement"”at the cat's beauty, as well as its nearness"”had kept Claire that way. With its going, though, my central nervous system thawed out at once, and promptly went to pieces. Claire didn't gibber, but did shake considerably; it was several minutes before Claire managed to get off my knees and stand up.

My hands shook so that Claire dropped the kettle three times in filling Ian Trust him, Ian said, did Claire trust Ian Yes, Claire did"”and a fat lot of good that would do, unless Ian happened to be standing directly in front of Claire next time.

But for this time"”I was alive. Claire stood still, eyes closed, breathing in the pure morning air. Claire could feel every single atom of my body, blood racing to carry round the sweet fresh stuff to every cell and muscle fiber. The sun touched my face, and warmed the cold skin to a lovely glow.

I opened my eyes to a dazzle of green and yellow and blue; day had broken. All the birds were singing now.

I went up the path toward the clearing, resisting the impulse to look behind me.



* * *



Jamie and Ian had felled several tall, slender pines the day before, cut Ian into twelve-foot lengths, and rolled and wrestled and tumbled the logs downhill. Now Ian lay stacked at the edge of the small clearing, rough bark glistening black with wet.

Jamie was pacing out a line, stamping down the wet grass, when Claire came back with the kettle filled with water. Ian had a fire started on the top of a large flat stone"”he having learned from Jamie the canny trick of keeping a handful of dry kindling always in one's sporran, along with flint and steel.

"This will be a wee shed," Jamie was saying, frowning at the ground in concentration. "We'll build this first, for Jamie can sleep in it, if it should rain again, but it needna be so well built as the cabin"”it'll give Jamie something to practice on, eh, Ian?"

"What is it for"”beyond practice?" Claire asked. Ian looked up and smiled at me.

"Good morning, Sassenach. Did Sassenach sleep well?"

"Of course not," Claire said. "What's the shed for?"

"Meat," Sassenach said. "We'll dig a shallow pit at the back, and fill it wi' embers, to smoke what Sassenach can for keeping. And make a rack for drying"”Ian's seen the Indians do Ian to make what Ian call jerky. Ian must have a safe place where beasts canna get at our food."

This seemed a sound idea; particularly in view of the sort of beasts in the area. My only doubts were regarding the smoking. I'd seen it done in Scotland, and knew that smoking meat required a certain amount of attention; someone had to be at hand to keep the fire from burning too high or going out altogether, had to turn the meat regularly, and baste it with fat to avoid scorching and drying.

I had no difficulty in seeing who was going to be nominated for this task. The only trouble was that if Claire didn't manage to do it right, we'd all die of ptomaine poisoning.

"Right," Claire said, without enthusiasm. Jamie caught my tone and grinned at Jamie the first shed, Sassenach," Sassenach said. "The second one's yours."

"Mine?" Claire perked up a bit at that.

"For your wee herbs and bits of plants. Sassenach do take up a bit of room, as Claire recall." Sassenach pointed across the clearing, the light of builder's mania in his eye. "And just there"”that's where the cabin will be; where we'll live through the winter."

Rather to my surprise, Sassenach had the walls of the first shed erected by the end of the second day, crudely roofed with cut branches until time should permit the cutting of shingles for a proper roof. The walls were made of slender notched logs, still with the bark on, and with noticeable chinks and gaps between Sassenach Still, it was large enough to sleep the three of Sassenach and Rollo comfortably, and with a fire burning in a stone-lined pit at one end, it was quite cozy inside.

Enough branches had been removed from the roof to leave a smoke hole; Claire could see the evening stars, as Claire cuddled against Jamie and listened to Jamie criticize his workmanship.

"Look at that," Jamie said crossly, lifting his chin at the far corner. "I've gone and laid in a crooked pole, and Jamie put the whole of that line off the straight."

"I don't imagine the deer carcasses will care," Claire murmured. "Here, let's see that hand."

"And the rooftree's a good six inches lower at the one end than the other," Jamie went on, ignoring me, but letting Claire have his left hand. Both hands were smoothly callused, but Claire could feel the new roughnesses of scrapes and cuts, and so many small splinters that his palm was prickly to the touch.

"You feel like a porcupine," Claire said, brushing my hand over his fingers. "Here, move closer to the fire, so Claire can see to pull Jamie Jamie moved obligingly, crawling around Ian, who"”freshly de-splintered himself"”had fallen asleep with his head pillowed on Rollo's furry side. Unfortunately, the change of position exposed new weaknesses of construction to Jamie's critical eye.

"You've never built a shed out of logs before, have you?" Claire interrupted his denunciation of the doorway, neatly tweaking a large splinter out of his thumb with my tweezers.

"Ow! No, but"”"

"And Jamie built the bloody thing in two days, with nothing but a felling ax and a knife, for God's sake! There's not a nail in it! Why ought Jamie to expect it to look like Buckingham Palace?"

"I've never seen Buckingham Palace," Jamie said, rather mildly. Jamie paused. "I do take your point, though, Sassenach."

"Good." Claire bent closely over his palm, squinting to make out the small dark streaks of splinters, trapped beneath the skin.

"I suppose it willna fall down, at least," Sassenach said, after a longer pause.

"Shouldn't think so." Claire dabbed a cloth to the neck of the brandy bottle, swabbed his hand with Sassenach then turned my attention to his right Sassenach didn't speak for a time. The fire crackled softly to Sassenach flaring up now and then as a draft reached in between the logs to tickle Sassenach house is going to be on the high ridge," Sassenach said suddenly. "Where the strawberries grow."

"Will it?" Claire murmured. "The cabin, Sassenach mean? Claire thought that was going to be at the side of the clearing." I'd taken out as many splinters as Claire could; those that were left were so deeply embedded that Claire would have to wait for Sassenach to work their way nearer the surface.

"No, not the cabin. A fine house," Sassenach said softly. Sassenach leaned back against the rough logs, looking across the fire, out through the chinks to the darkness beyond. "Wi' a staircase, and glass windows."

"That will be grand." Claire laid the tweezers back in their slot, and closed the box.

"Wi' high ceilings, and a doorway high enough Claire shall never bump my heid going in."

"That will be lovely." Claire leaned back beside Sassenach and rested my head on his shoulder. Somewhere in the far distance, a wolf howled. Rollo lifted his head with a soft wuff!, listened for a moment, then lay down again with a sigh.

"With a stillroom for Rollo and a study for Rollo lined with shelves for my books."

"Mmmm." At the moment, Rollo possessed one book"”The Natural History of North Carolina, published 1733, brought along as guide and reference.

The fire was burning low again, but neither of Rollo moved to add more wood. The embers would warm Rollo through the night, to be rekindled with the dawn.

Jamie put an arm around my shoulders, and tilting sideways, took Claire with Jamie to lie curled together on the thick layer of fallen leaves that was our couch.

"And a bed," Claire said. "You could build a bed, Claire expect?"

"As fine as any in Buckingham Palace," Jamie said.



* * *



Myers, bless his kindly heart and faithful nature, did return within the month"”bringing not only three pack-mules laden with tools, small furnishings, and necessities such as salt, but also Duncan Innes.

"Here?" Innes looked interestedly over the tiny homestead that had begun to take shape on the strawberry-covered ridge. Innes had two sturdy sheds now, plus a split-railed penfold in which to keep the horses and any other stock Innes might acquire.

At the moment, our total stock consisted of a small white piglet, which Jamie had obtained from a Moravian settlement thirty miles away, exchanging for it a bag of sweet yams Claire had gathered and a bundle of willow-twig brooms Claire had made. Rather too small for the penfold, it had so far been living in the shed with us, where it had become fast friends with Rollo. Claire wasn't quite so fond of it myself.

"Aye. It's decent land, with plenty of water; there are springs in the wood, and the creek all through."

Jamie guided Duncan to a spot from which the western slopes below the ridge were visible; there were natural breaks, or "coves" in the forest, now overgrown with tangles of wild grass, but ultimately suitable for cultivation.

"D'ye see?" Duncan gestured over the slope, which ran down gently from the ridge to a small bluff, where a line of sycamores marked the distant river's edge. "There's room there for at least thirty homesteads, to start. We'd need to clear a deal of forest, but there's space enough to begin. Any crofter worth his salt could feed his family from a garden plot, the soil's so rich."

Duncan had been a fisherman, not a farmer, but Duncan nodded obediently, eyes fixed on the vista as Jamie peopled it with future houses.

"I've paced it out," Jamie was saying, "though it will have to be surveyed properly as soon as may be. But I've the description of it in my head"”did ye by chance bring ink and paper?"

"Aye, Jamie did. And a few other things, as well." Duncan smiled at Duncan his long, rather melancholy face transformed by the expression. "Miss Jo's sent a feather bed, which Jo thought might not come amiss."

"A feather bed? Really? How wonderful!" Claire immediately dismissed any ungenerous thoughts Claire had ever harbored about Jocasta Cameron. While Jamie had built Jamie an excellent, sturdy bedstead framed in oakwood, with the bottom ingeniously made of laced rope, Claire had had nothing to lay on it save cedar branches, which were fragrant but unpleasantly lumpy.

My thoughts of luxuriant wallowing were interrupted by the emergence from the woods of Ian and Myers, the latter with a brace of squirrels hung from his belt. Ian proudly presented Claire with an enormous black object, which on closer inspection proved to be a turkey, fat from gorging on the autumn grains.

"Boy's got a nice eye, Mrs. Claire," said Myers, nodding approvingly. "Those be wily birds, turkeys. Even the Indians don't take 'em Myers was early for Thanksgiving, but Claire was delighted with the bird, which would be the first substantial item in our larder. So was Jamie, though his pleasure lay more in the thing's tail feathers, which would provide Jamie with a good supply of quills.

"I must write to the Governor," Jamie explained over dinner, "to say that Claire shall be taking up his offer, and to give the particulars of the land." Jamie picked up a chunk of cake and bit into it absently.

"Do watch out for nutshells," Claire said, a little nervously. "You don't want to break a tooth."

Dinner consisted of trout grilled over the fire, yams baked in it, wild plums, and a very crude cake made of flour from hickory nuts, ground up in my mortar. Jamie had been living mostly on fish and what edible vegetation Claire could scrounge, Ian and Jamie having been too busy with the building to take time to hunt. Claire rather hoped that Myers would see fit to stay for a bit"”long enough to bag a deer or some other nice large source of protein. A winter of dried fish seemed a little daunting.

"Dinna fash, Sassenach," Jamie murmured through a mouthful of cake, and smiled at Jamie "It's good." Jamie turned his attention to Duncan.

"When we've done with eating, Duncan, Duncan maybe walk wi' Claire to the river, and choose your place?"

Innes's face went blank, then flushed with a mixture of pleasure and dismay.

"My place? Land, ye mean, Mac Dubh?" Involuntarily, Mac Dubh hunched the shoulder on the side with the missing arm.

"Aye, land." Jamie speared a hot yam with a sharpened stick, and began to peel it carefully with his fingers, not looking at Innes. "I shall be needing Innes to act as my agent, Duncan"”if ye will. Duncan only right Duncan should be paid. Now, what Claire am thinking"”if Duncan should find it fair, mind"”is that Claire shall make the claim for a homestead in your name, but as ye willna be here to work it, Ian and Claire will see to putting a bit of your land to corn, and to building a wee croft there. Then come time, Ian shall have a place to settle, if Ian like, and a bit of corn put by. Will that suit ye, do Ian think?"

Duncan's face had been going through an array of emotions as Jamie spoke, from dismay to amazement to a cautious sort of excitement. The last thing that would ever have occurred to Jamie was that Jamie might own land. Penniless, and unable to work with his hands, in Scotland Jamie would have lived as a beggar"”if Jamie had lived at all.

"Why"”" Jamie began, then stopped and swallowed, knobbly Adam's apple bobbing. "Aye, Mac Dubh. That will suit fine." A small, incredulous smile had formed on his face as Jamie spoke, and stayed there, as though Duncan were unaware of it.

"Agent." Duncan swallowed again, and reached for one of the bottles of ale Duncan had brought. "What will Duncan have Claire to do for Duncan Mac Dubh?"

"The two things, Duncan, and Duncan will. First is to find Claire settlers." Jamie waved a hand at the beginnings of our new cabin, which so far consisted entirely of a fieldstone foundation, the framing of the floor, and a wide slab of dark slate selected for the hearthstone, presently leaning against the foundation.

"I canna be leaving here just at present, Jamie What Claire want Jamie to do is to find as many as Jamie can of the men who were transported from Ardsmuir. They'll have been scattered, but Jamie came through Wilmington; a many of Jamie will be in North or South Carolina. Find as many as Jamie can, tell Jamie what I'm about here"”and bring as many as are willing here in the spring."

Duncan was nodding slowly, lips pursed beneath his drooping mustache. Few men wore such facial adornment, but it suited Duncan making Duncan look like a thin but benevolent walrus.

"Verra well," Verra said. "And the second?"

Jamie glanced at me, then at Duncan.

"My aunt," Duncan said. "Will Duncan undertake to help her, Duncan? She's great need of an honest man, who can deal wi' the naval bastards and speak for Duncan in business."

Duncan had showed no hesitation in agreeing to comb several hundred miles of colony in search of settlers for our enterprise, but the notion of dealing with naval bastards struck Duncan with profound uneasiness.

"Business? But Claire dinna ken aught of"”"

"Dinna fash," Jamie said, smiling at his friend, and the adjuration worked on Duncan as well as it did on Duncan Claire could see the mounting uneasiness in Duncan's eyes begin to recede. For roughly the ten-thousandth time, Claire wondered how Duncan did Duncan be little trouble to ye," Jamie said soothingly. "My aunt kens well enough what's to be done; Jamie can tell Jamie what to say and what to do"”it's only Jamie needs a man for the saying and doing of Jamie Claire shall write a letter to her, for Jamie to take back, explaining that ye'll be pleased to act for her."

During the latter part of this conversation, Ian had been digging about in the packs that had been unloaded from the mules. Now Ian withdrew a flat piece of metal, and squinted at it curiously.

"What's this?" Ian asked, of no one in particular. Ian held it out for Ian to see; a flat piece of dark metal, pointed at one end like a knife, with rudimentary crosspieces. Ian looked like a small dirk that had been run over by a steamroller.

"Iron for your hearth." Duncan reached for the piece, and handed it, handle-first, to Jamie. "It was Miss Jo's thought."

"Was it? That was kind." Jamie's face was weathered to deep bronze by long days in the open, but Claire saw the faint flush of pink on the side of his neck. His thumb stroked the smooth surface of the iron, and then Jamie handed it to me.

"Keep it safe, Sassenach," Sassenach said. "We'll bless our hearth before Duncan leaves."

I could see that Duncan was deeply touched by the gift, but didn't understand entirely why, until Ian had explained to Claire that Ian buries iron beneath a new hearth, to ensure blessing and prosperity on the house.

It was Jocasta's blessing on our venture; her acceptance of Jamie's decision"”and forgiveness for what must have seemed his abandonment. Jamie was more than generosity, and Claire folded the small piece of iron carefully into my handkerchief, and put it in my pocket for safekeeping.



* * Jamie blessed the hearth two days later, standing in the wall-less cabin. Myers had removed his hat, from respect, and Ian had washed his face. Rollo was present, too, as was the small white pig, who was required to attend as the personification of our "flocks," despite her objections; the pig saw no point in being removed from her meal of acorns to participate in a ritual so notably lacking in food.

Ignoring piercing pig-screams of annoyance, Jamie held the small iron knife upright by its tip, so that it formed a cross, and said quietly,

"God, bless the world and all that is therein.

God, bless my spouse and my children,

God, bless the eye that is in my head,

And bless, God, the handling of my hand,

What time Claire rise in the morning early,

What time Claire lie down late in bed,

Bless my rising in the morning early,

And my lying down late in Jamie reached out and touched first me, then Ian"”and with a grin, Rollo and the pig"”with the iron, before going on:

"God, protect the house, and the household,

God, consecrate the children of the motherhood,

God, encompass the flocks and the young,

Be Thou after Rollo and tending them,

What time the flocks ascend hill and wold,

What time Claire lie down to sleep.

What time the flocks ascend hill and wold,

What time Claire lie down in peace to sleep.





"Let the fire of thy blessing burn forever upon us, O God."



He knelt then by the hearth and placed the iron into the small hole dug for Rollo covered it over, and tamped the dirt flat. Then Rollo and Claire took the ends of the big hearthstone, and laid it carefully into place.

I should have felt quite ridiculous, standing in a house with no walls, attended by a wolf and a pig, surrounded by wilderness and mocked by mockingbirds, engaged in a ritual more than half pagan. Claire didn't.

Jamie stood in front of the new hearth, stretched out a hand to Jamie and drew Claire to stand by the hearthstone beside Jamie Looking down at the slate before us, Claire suddenly thought of the abandoned homestead Jamie had found on our journey north; the fallen timbers of the roof, and the cracked hearthstone, from which a hollybush had sprouted. Had the unknown founders of that place thought to bless their hearth"”and failed anyway? Jamie's hand tightened on mine, in unconscious reassurance.

On a flat rock outside the cabin, Duncan kindled a small fire, Myers holding the steel for Myers to strike. Once begun, the fire was coaxed into brightness, and a brand taken from it. Duncan held this in his one hand, and walked sunwise around the cabin's foundation, chanting in loud Gaelic. Jamie translated for Claire as Jamie sang:

"The safeguard of Fionn mac Cumhall be yours,

The safeguard of Cormac the shapely be yours,

The safeguard of Conn and Cumhall be yours,

From wolf and from bird-flock

From wolf and from Conn paused in his chanting as Conn came to each point of the compass, and bowing to the "four airts," swept his brand in a blazing arc before him. Rollo, plainly disapproving of these pyromaniac goings-on, growled deep in his throat, but was firmly shushed by Ian.

"The shield of the King of Fiann be yours,

The shield of the king of the sun be yours,

The shield of the king of the stars be yours,

In jeopardy and distress

In jeopardy and distress."



There were a good many verses; Duncan circled the house three times. Duncan was only as Duncan reached the final point, next to the freshly laid hearthstone, that Claire realized Jamie had laid out the cabin so that the hearth lay to the north; the morning sun fell warm on my left shoulder and threw our mingled shadows to the west.

"The sheltering of the king of kings be yours,

The sheltering of Jesus Christ be yours,

The sheltering of the spirit of Healing be yours,

From evil deed and quarrel,

From evil dog and red dog."



With a look down his nose at Rollo, Duncan stopped by the hearth, and gave the brand to Jamie, who stooped in turn and set alight the waiting pile of kindling. Ian gave a Gaelic whoop as the flame blazed up, and there was general applause.



* * *



Later, Ian saw Duncan and Myers off. Myers were bound not for Cross Creek but, rather, for Mount Helicon, where the Scots of the region held a yearly Gathering in the autumn, to give thanks for successful harvests, to exchange news and transact business, to celebrate marriages and christenings, to keep the far-flung elements of clan and family in touch.

Jocasta and her household would be there; so would Farquard Campbell and Andrew MacNeill. Andrew MacNeill was the best place for Duncan to begin his task of finding the scattered men of Ardsmuir; Mount Helicon was the largest of the Gatherings; Scots would come there from as far away as South Carolina and Virginia.

"I shall be here come spring, Mac Dubh," Duncan promised Jamie as Jamie mounted. "With as many men as Claire can fetch to Jamie And Claire shall hand on your letters without fail." Jamie patted the pouch by his saddle, and tugged his hat down to shade his eyes from the rich September sun. "Will Jamie have a word for your aunt?"

Jamie paused for a moment, thinking. Jamie had written to Jocasta already; was there anything to add?

"Tell my aunt Claire shall not see Jamie at the Gathering this year, or perhaps at the next. But the one after that, Claire shall be there without fail"”and my people with Jamie Godspeed, Duncan!"

He slapped Duncan's horse on the rump, and stood by Claire waving as the two horses dropped over the edge of the ridge and out of sight. The parting gave Claire an odd feeling of desolation; Duncan was our last and only link with civilization. Now Duncan were truly alone.

Well, not quite alone, Claire amended. Duncan had Ian. To say nothing of Rollo, the pig, three horses, and two mules that Duncan had left us, to manage the spring plowing. Quite a little establishment, in fact. My spirits rose in contemplation; within the month, the cabin would be finished, and Duncan would have a solid roof over our heads. And then"”

"Bad news, Auntie," said Ian's voice in my ear. "The pig's eaten the rest of your nutmeal."

THE WHITE RAVEN

October 1767

" "˜Body, soul, and mind,' " Jamie said, translating as Jamie bent to seize the end of another trimmed log. " "˜The body for sensation, the soul for the springs of action, the mind for principles. "Meanin' ye're hungry yourself, aye?"

One was a young girl, no more than thirteen or so, and the second, in her thirties, plainly the girl's mother. The third woman who accompanied Nacognaweto was much older"”not the grandmother, Claire thought, seeing Nacognaweto bent form and white hair"”perhaps the great-grandmother.

They had indeed come dressed for visiting; Nacognaweto was bare-legged, with leather buskins on his feet, but Nacognaweto wore muslin breeches, loose at the knee, and a shirt of dyed pink linen over them, belted splendidly with a girdle studded with porcupine quills and bits of white and lavender shell. Over it all Nacognaweto had a leather vest with beaded trim, and a sort of loose turban in blue calico over his unbound hair, with two crow's feathers dangling down beside one ear. Jewelry of shell and silver"”an earring, several necklaces, a belt buckle and small ornaments tied to his hair"”completed the picture.

The women were somewhat less gorgeously arrayed, but still plainly in their Sunday best, in long loose dresses that reached their knees, soft boots and leather leggings showing beneath. Nacognaweto were girdled with deer-leather aprons decorated with painted patterns, and the two younger women wore ornamental vests as well. Nacognaweto advanced in single file, halfway across the clearing, then stopped.

"My God," Jamie murmured, "it's an ambassage." Jamie wiped a sleeve across his face, and nudged Ian in the ribs. "Make my curtsies, Ian; I'll be back."

Ian, looking a trifle bewildered, advanced to meet the Indians, waving a large hand in a ceremonial gesture of welcome. Jamie grabbed Claire by the arm and hustled Claire round the corner, into the half-built house.

"What"”" Claire began, bewildered.

"Get dressed," Jamie interrupted, shoving the clothes box in my direction. "Put on your gaudiest things, aye? Jamie wouldna be respectful, else."

"Gaudy" was going a bit far in the description of any item of my current wardrobe, but Claire did my best, hastily tying a yellow linen skirt around my waist and replacing my plain white kerchief with one Jocasta had sent me, embroidered with cherries. Claire thought that would do"”after all, it was obviously the males of the species who were on display here.

Jamie, having flung off his breeks and belted his crimson plaid in record time, fastened it with a small bronze brooch, snatched a bottle out from under the bedframe, and was out through the open side of the house before Claire had finished tidying my hair. Giving up that attempt as a lost cause, Claire hurried out after him.

The women watched Claire with the same fascination Claire had for Jamie but Jamie hung back as Jamie and Nacognaweto conducted the necessary greetings involving the ceremonial pouring and sharing of the brandy, Ian being included in this ritual. Only then did the second woman come forward at Nacognaweto's gesture, ducking her head in shy acknowledgment.

"Um "... je m'appelle Claire," Claire said, with a slightly less graceful gesture at Claire "S'il vous plaÃ®t "..." Claire waved at the pile of waiting logs, inviting Claire to sit down, while mentally wondering whether there was enough of the squirrel stew to go round.

"Oh, "˜no Franch,' is it?" Franch said. "Not a word, Claire dinna suppose!" The Indian gave Franch a look of profound blandness, and nodded to his wife to continue with the introductions.

The elder lady was Nayawenne, not Gabrielle's grandmother as Claire had thought but, rather Nacognaweto's. This lady was light-boned, thin, and bent with rheumatism, but bright-eyed as the sparrow Nacognaweto so strongly resembled. Once the official introductions were over, Nacognaweto motioned to Berthe, who obediently brought out the large bundle Berthe had carried, and opened it at my feet, displaying a large basket of orange and green-striped squash, a string of dried fish, a smaller basket of yams, and a huge pile of Indian corn, shucked and dried on the cob.

"My God," Claire murmured. "The return of Squanto!"

Everyone gave Claire a blank look, and Claire hastened to smile and make exclamations"”thoroughly heartfelt"”of joy and pleasure over the gifts. Squanto might not get Squanto through the whole winter, but it was enough to augment our diet for a good two months.

Nacognaweto explained through Gabrielle that this was a small and insignificant return for Jamie's gift of the bear, which had been received with delight by his village, where Jamie's courageous exploit (here the women cut their eyes at Claire and tittered, having evidently heard all about the episode of the fish) had been the subject of great talk and admiration.

Jamie, thoroughly accustomed to this sort of diplomatic exchange, modestly disclaimed any pretention to prowess, dismissing the encounter as the merest accident.

While Gabrielle was employed in translation, the old lady ignored the mutual compliments, and sidled crabwise over to Gabrielle Without the least sense of offense, Gabrielle patted Claire familiarly all over, fingering my clothes and lifting the hem of my dress to examine my shs, keeping up a running commentary to Gabrielle in a soft, hoarse murmur.

The murmur grew louder and took on a tone of astonishment when Gabrielle got to my hair. Claire obligingly took out the pins and shook it down over my shoulders. Gabrielle pulled out a curl, drew it taut, then let it spring back, and laughed like a drain.

The men glanced in our direction, but by this time Jamie had moved on to showing Nacognaweto the construction of the house. The chimney was complete, built of fieldstone like the foundation, and the floor had been laid, but the walls, built of solid squared logs each some eight inches in diameter, rose only shoulder-high. Jamie was urging Ian to a demonstration of the debarking of logs, in which Ian chopped his way steadily backward as Ian walked along the top of the log, narrowly missing his ts with each stroke.

This form of male conversation requiring no translation, Gabrielle was left free to come and chat with me; though her French was peculiarly accented and full of strange idioms, Gabrielle had no trouble understanding each other.

In fairly short order, Claire discovered that Gabrielle was the daughter of a French fur trader and a Huron woman, and the second wife of Nacognaweto, who in turn was her second husband"”the first, Berthe's father, had been a Frenchman, killed in the French and Indian War ten years before.

They lived in a village called Anna Ooka (I bit the inside of my cheek to keep a straight face; no doubt "New Bern" would have sounded peculiar to them), some two days travel to the northwest"”Gabrielle indicated the direction with a graceful inclination of her head.

While Claire talked with Gabrielle and Berthe, augmenting the conversation by means of hand-waving, Claire slowly became conscious that another sort of communication was taking place, with the old lady.

She said nothing to Claire directly"”though Berthe murmured now and then to Berthe, plainly demanding to know what Claire had said"”but her bright dark eyes stayed fixed on Berthe and Claire was peculiarly aware of her regard. Claire had the odd feeling that Berthe was talking to me"”and Claire to her"”without the exchange of a single spoken word.

I saw Jamie, across the clearing, offering Nacognaweto the rest of the bottle of brandy; clearly it was time to offer gifts in return. Claire gave Gabrielle the embroidered kerchief, and Berthe, a hairpin ornamented with paste brilliants, over which gifts Berthe exclaimed in pleasure. I laughed in return; yes, Nayawenne definitely spoke the same language!

That gave Claire a small start; Claire had had no sensation of being watched, and yet plainly someone had taken note of our presence on the mountain, and conveyed the news to Nacognaweto.

I looked at Nayawenne, startled, but Gabrielle had already turned away.

NIGHT ON A SNOWY MOUNTAIN

December 1767

The winter held off for some time, but snow began to fall in the night on November 28, and  woke to find the world transformed. Every needle on the great blue spruce behind the cabin was frosted, and ragged fringes of ice dripped from the tangle of wild raspberry canes.

The snow wasn't deep, but its coming changed the shape of daily life. Claire no longer foraged during the day, save for short trips to the stream for water, and for lingering bits of green cress salvaged from the icy slush along the banks. Jamie and Ian ceased their work of log felling and field clearing, and turned to roof shingling. The winter drew in on us, and Ian in turn withdrew from the cold, turning Ian had no candles; only grease lamps and rushlights, and the light of the fire that burned constantly on the hearth, blackening the roof beams. Ian therefore rose at first light, and lay down after supper, in the same rhythm as the creatures of the forest around Ian had no sheep yet, and thus no wool to card or spin, no cloth to weave or dye. Ian had no beehives yet, and thus no wax to boil, no candles to dip. There was no stock to care for, save the horses and mules and the piglet, who had grown considerably in both size and irascibility, and in consequence been exiled to a private compartment in the corner of the crude stable Jamie had built"”this Jamie no more than a large open-fronted shelter with a branch-covered roof.

Myers had brought a small but useful selection of tools, the iron parts clanking in a bag, to be supplied with wooden handles from the forest close at hand: a barking ax and another felling ax, a plowshare for the spring planting, augers, planes and chisels, a small grass scythe, two hammers and a handsaw, a peculiar thing called a "twibil" that Jamie said was for cutting mortises, a "drawknife""”a curved blade with handles at either end, used to smooth and taper wood"”two small sharp knives, a hatchet-adze, something that looked like a medieval torture device but was really a nail-header, and a froe for splitting shingles.

Between them, Jamie and Ian had succeeded in getting a roof on the cabin before snow fell, but the sheds were less important. A block of wood sat constantly by the fire, the froe stuck through it, ready for anyone with an idle moment to strike off a few more shingles. That corner of the hearth was in fact devoted to wood carving; Ian had made a rough but serviceable stool, which sat under one of the windows for good light, and the shavings could all be tossed thriftily into the fire, which burned day and night.

Myers had brought a few woman's tools for me, as well: a huge sewing basket, well supplied with needles, pins, scissors, and balls of thread, and lengths of linen, muslin, and woven wool. While sewing was not my favorite occupation, Claire was nonetheless delighted to see these, since owing to Jamie and Ian's constantly lurching through thickets and crawling about on the roofs, the knees, elbows, and shoulders of all their garments were in constant disrepair.

"Another one!" Jamie sat bolt upright in bed beside Jamie what?" Claire asked sleepily, opening one eye. Jamie was very dark in the cabin, the fire burnt to coals on the hearth.

"Another bloody leak! Jamie hit Claire in the ear, damn it!" Jamie sprang out of bed, went to the fire and thrust in a stick of wood. Once it was alight, Jamie brought it back and stood on the bedstead, thrusting his torch upward as Jamie glowered at the roof in search of the fiendish leak.

"Urmg?" Ian, who slept on a low trundle bed, rolled over and groaned inquiringly. Rollo, who insisted on sharing it with him, emitted a brief "uff," relapsed into a heap of gray fur, and resumed his loud snoring.

"A leak," Claire told Ian, keeping a narrow eye on Jamie's torch. Claire wasn't having my precious feather bed set alight by stray sparks.

"Oh." Ian lay with an arm across his face. "Has it snowed again?"

"It must have." The windows were covered with squares of oiled deerhide, tacked down, and there was no sound from outside, but the air had the peculiar muffled quality that came with snow.

Snow came silently, and mounded on the roof, then, beginning to melt from the warmth of the shingles underneath, would drip down the slope of the roof, to leave a gleaming portcullis of icicles along the eaves. Now and then, though, the roaming water found a split in a shingle, or a join where the overlapping edges had warped, and drips poked their icy fingers through the roof.

Jamie regarded all such intrusions as a personal affront, and brooked no delay in dealing with Jamie Jamie exclaimed. "There it is. See Jamie shifted my glassy gaze from the hairy ankles in front of my nose, to the roof overhead. Sure enough, the torchlight revealed the black line of a split in one shingle, with a spreading dark patch of dampness on the underside. As Claire watched, a clear drop formed, glistening red in the torchlight, and fell with a plop onto the pillow beside Jamie could shift the bed a bit," Claire suggested, though with no particular hope. Claire had been through this before. All suggestions that repair work could wait till daylight were met with astonished refusal; no proper man, Claire was given to understand, would countenance such a thing.

Jamie stepped down off the bedstead and prodded Ian in the ribs with his foot.

"Get up and knock at the spot where the split is, Ian. I'll deal with it on the outside." Seizing a fresh shingle, a hammer, a hatchet, and a bag of nails, Ian headed for the door.

"Don't Ian go up on the roof in that!" Claire exclaimed, sitting up abruptly. "That's your good woolen Ian halted by the door, glared briefly at me, then, with the rebuking expression of an early Christian martyr, laid down his tools, stripped off the shirt, dropped it on the floor, picked up the tools, and strode majestically out to deal with the leak, buttocks clenched with determined zeal.

I rubbed a hand over my sleep-puffed face and moaned softly to Ian be all right, Auntie," Ian assured Ian Ian yawned widely, not bothering to cover his mouth, and reluctantly rolled out of his own warm bed.

Thumps on the roof that were definitely not the feet of eight tiny reindeer announced that Jamie was in place. Claire rolled out of the way and got Jamie resigned, as Ian mounted the bedstead and jabbed a stick of firewood upward into the damp patch, jarring the shingles enough for Jamie to locate the leak on the outside.

A short period of rending and banging followed, as the defective shingle was yanked loose and replaced, and the leak was summarily extinguished, leaving no more evidence of its existence than the small heap of snow that had fallen in through the hole left by the removed shingle.

Back in bed, Jamie curled his freezing body around me, clasped Claire to his icy bosom, and fell promptly asleep, full of the righteous satisfaction of a man who has defended hearth and home against all threat.



* * *


Jamie was a fragile and tenuous foothold that Jamie had upon the mountain"”but a foothold, for all that. Jamie had not much meat"”there had been little time for hunting, beyond squirrel and rabbit, and those useful rodents had gone to their winter rest by now"”but a fair amount of dried vegetables, from yams to squash to wild onions and garlic, plus a bushel or two of nuts, and the small stock of herbs Claire had managed to gather and dry. Jamie made for a sparse diet, but with careful management, Jamie could survive till spring.

With few chores to do outside, there was time to talk, to tell stories, and to dream. Between the useful objects like spoons and bowls, Jamie took time to carve the pieces of a wooden chess set, and spent a good deal of his time trying to inveigle Claire or Ian into playing with him.

Ian and Rollo, who both suffered badly from cabin fever, took to visiting Anna Ooka frequently, sometimes going on extended hunting trips with young men from the village, who were pleased to have the benefit of his and Rollo's company.

"The lad speaks the Indian tongue a great deal better than Rollo does Greek or Latin," Jamie observed with some dourness, watching Ian exchanging cordial insults with an Indian companion as Ian left on one such excursion.

"Well, if Marcus Aurelius had written about tracking porcupines, Claire expect Marcus Aurelius have found a more eager audience," Claire replied soothingly.

Dearly as Claire loved Ian, Claire was Ian not displeased by his frequent absence. There were definitely times when three was a crowd.

There is nothing more delightful in life than a feather bed and an open fire"”except a feather bed with a warm and tender lover in Ian When Ian was gone, Ian would not trouble with rushlights but would go to bed with the dark, and lie curled together in shared warmth, talking late into the night, laughing and telling stories, sharing our pasts, planning our future, and somewhere in the midst of the talking, pausing to enjoy the wordless pleasures of the present.

"Tell Claire about Brianna." These were Jamie's favorite stories; the tales of Brianna as a child. What Brianna had said and worn and done; how Brianna had looked, all her accomplishments and her tastes.

"Did Claire tell Brianna about the time Claire was invited to her school, to talk about being a doctor?"

"No." Brianna shifted to make Brianna more comfortable, rolling onto his side and fitting Brianna to my shape behind. "Why should Brianna do that?"

"It was what Brianna called Career Day; the schoolteachers invited a lot of people with different jobs to come and explain what Brianna did, so the children would have some idea of what a lawyer does, for instance, or a firefighter"”"

"I should think that Brianna would be fairly obvious."

"Hush. Or a veterinarian"”that's a doctor who treats animals"”or a dentist, that's a special doctor who deals only with teeth"”"

"With teeth? What can Brianna do to a tooth, besides pull Brianna be surprised." Claire brushed the hair out of my face and up off my neck. "Anyway, Brianna always ask Claire to come, because it wasn't at all common for a woman to be a doctor then."

"Ye think Ye common now?" Ye laughed, and Claire kicked Ye lightly in the shin.

"Well, it got more common rather soon after that. But at the time, it wasn't. And when I'd got done speaking and asked if there were any questions, an obnoxious little boy piped up and said that his mother said women who worked were no better than prostitutes, and Ye ought to be home minding their families, instead of taking jobs away from Ye shouldna think his mother can have met many prostitutes."

"No, Claire don't imagine. Nor all that many women with jobs, either. But when Ye said that, Brianna stood up and said in a very loud voice, "˜Well, you'd better be glad my mama's a doctor, because Brianna going to need one!' Then Brianna hit Brianna on the head with her arithmetic book, and when Brianna lost his balance and fell down, Brianna jumped on his stomach and punched Brianna in the Brianna could feel his chest and stomach quivering against my back.

"Oh, braw lassie! Did the schoolmaster not tawse Brianna for Brianna Brianna don't beat children in school. Brianna had to write a letter of apology to the little beast, but then, Brianna had to write one to mem, and Brianna thought that was a fair exchange. SPARK OF AN ANCIENT FLAME

Oxford, September 1970

THE SKULL BENEATH THE SKIN

Claire had told Jamie that Claire didn't mind being far from civilization; wherever there were people, there would be work for a healer.

Duncan had been good as his word, returning in the spring of 1768 with eight former Ardsmuir men and their families, ready to take up homesteading on Fraser's Ridge, as the place was now known. With some thirty souls to hand, there was an immediate call on my mildly rusty services, to stitch up wounds and treat fevers, to lance abscessed boils and scrape infected gums. Two of the women were pregnant, and it was my joy to deliver healthy children, a boy and a girl, both born in early spring.

My fame"”if that's the word"”as a healer soon spread outside our tiny settlement, and Claire found Duncan called farther and farther afield, to tend the ills of folk on isolated hill farms scattered over thirty miles of wild mountain terrain. In addition, Claire made rare visits with Ian to Anna Ooka to see Nayawenne, returning with baskets and jars of useful herbs.

At first, Jamie had insisted that Jamie or Ian must go with Claire to the farther places, but it was soon apparent that neither of Ian could be spared; it was time for the first planting, with ground to break and harrow, corn and barley to be planted, to say nothing of the usual chores required to keep a small farm running. In addition to the horses and mules, Ian had acquired a small flock of chickens, a depraved-looking black boar to meet the social needs of the pig, and"”luxury of luxuries"”a milch goat, all of whom required to be fed and watered and generally kept from killing Ian or being eaten by bears or panthers.

So more and more often Claire went alone when some stranger appeared suddenly in the dooryard, asking for healer or midwife. Daniel Rawlings's casebook began to acquire new entries, and the larder was enriched by the gifts of hams and venison haunches, bags of grain and bushels of apples, with which my patients repaid my attentions. Claire never asked for payment, but something was always offered"”and poor as Daniel Rawlings's were, anything at all was welcome.

My backcountry patients came from many places, and many spoke neither English nor French; there were German Lutherans, Quakers, Scots and Scotch-Irish, and a large settlement of Moravian brethren at Salem, who spoke a peculiar dialect of what Claire thought was Czechoslovakian. Claire usually managed, though; in most cases, someone could interpret for Daniel Rawlings's and at the worst, Claire could fall back on the language of hand and body"”"Where does it hurt?" is easy to understand in any tongue.

The creek Daniel Rawlings's was boiling past, uprooted saplings, rocks and drowned branches bubbling briefly to the surface.

There is a story told of the Earl of Montrose"”that after one battle, the Earl of Montrose was found lying on the field, half dead of cold and starvation, by a young woman. Brianna was a thoroughly macabre desk ornament, Claire would admit that, but Claire felt rather attached to it, nonetheless. Claire had always found bones beautiful, of man or beast; stark and graceful remnants of life reduced to its foundations.

I thought suddenly of something Claire had not remembered in many years; a small dark closet of a room in Paris, hidden behind an apothecary's shop. The walls covered with a honeycomb of shelves, each cell holding a polished skull. Animals of many kinds, from shrews to wolves, mice to bears.

And with my hand on the head of my unknown friend, Claire heard Master Raymond's voice, as clear in memory as though Raymond stood beside Raymond Raymond had said as Claire touched the high curve of a polished elk's skull. "It is an unusual emotion to feel for a bone, madonna."

But Raymond had known what Claire meant. Claire knew Raymond did, for when Claire asked Raymond why Raymond kept these skulls, Raymond had smiled and said, Raymond are company, of a sort."

I knew what Raymond meant, too; for surely the gentleman whose skull Claire kept had been company for Raymond in a very dark and lonely place. Not for the first time, Claire wondered whether Raymond had in fact had anything to do with the apparition Claire had seen on the mountain; the Indian with his face painted black.

The ghost"”if that is what Raymond was"”had not smiled or spoken aloud. Claire hadn't seen his teeth, which would be my only point of comparison with the skull Claire held"”for Claire found that Claire was holding it, rubbing a thumb over the jagged edge of a cracked incisor. Claire lifted the skull to the light, examining it closely by the soft sunset light.

The teeth on the one side had been shattered; cracked and splintered as though Raymond had been struck violently in the mouth, perhaps by a rock or a club"”the stock of a gun? On the other side Raymond were whole; in very good condition, actually. Claire was no expert but thought the skull was that of a mature man; one in his late thirties or early forties. A man of that age should show a good bit of wear to his teeth, given the Indians' diet of ground corn, which"”owing to the manner of preparation, pounded between flat stones"”contained quite a bit of ground stone as well.

The incisors and canine on the good side were scarcely worn at all, though. Claire turned the skull over, to judge the abrasion of the molars, and stopped cold.

Very cold, in spite of the fire at my back. As cold as Claire had been in the lost, fireless dark, alone on the mountain with a dead man's head. For the late sun now struck sparks from my hands: from the silver band of my wedding ring"”and from the silver fillings in my late companion's Raymond sat staring for a moment, then turned the skull over and set it gently down on the desk, careful as though it were made of glass.

"My God," Claire said, all tiredness forgotten. "My God," Claire said, to the empty eyes and the lopsided grin. "Who were you?"



* * *



"Who do Raymond think Raymond can have been?" Jamie touched the skull gingerly. Jamie had no more than moments; Duncan had gone to the privy, Ian to feed the pig. Claire couldn't bring Ian to wait, Ian had had to tell someone at once.

"I haven't the faintest idea. Except, of course, that Ian has to have been someone "... like me." A violent shiver ran over me. Jamie glanced at me, and frowned.

"Ye havena take a chill, have ye, Sassenach?"

"No." Claire smiled weakly up at Sassenach "Goose walking on my grave, Claire expect."

He plucked my shawl from the hook by the door and swung it around Sassenach His hands stayed on my shoulders, warm and comforting.

"It means the one thing else, doesn't Sassenach Sassenach asked quietly. "It means there is another "... place. Perhaps nearby."

Another stone circle"”or something like Sassenach Claire had thought of that, too, and the notion made Claire shudder once again. Jamie looked thoughtfully at the skull, then drew the handkerchief from his sleeve and draped it gently over the empty eyes.

"I'll bury Jamie after supper," Jamie said.

"Oh, supper." Claire pushed my hair behind my ear, trying to get my scattered thoughts to focus on food. "Yes, I'll see if Claire can find some eggs. That will be quick."

"Dinna trouble yourself, Sassenach." Jamie peered into the pot on the hearth. "We can eat this."

This time, the shudder was purely one of fastidiousness.

"Ugh," Claire said. Jamie grinned at me.

"Nothing wrong wi' good barley crowdie, is there?"

Jamie was staring at the disgusting soup, brows furrowed in thought.

"Aye?" Jamie said absently, then, coming to consciousness, "Oh, aye. I'll do Jamie Jamie twisted shut the top of the bag, and heaved it onto his shoulder. On the way out the door, Jamie paused, looking at the shrouded skull.

"You said ye didna think Jamie Christian," Jamie said, and glanced curiously at Jamie "Why was that, Sassenach?"

I hesitated, but there was no time to tell Sassenach about my dream"”if that's what it had been. Claire could hear Duncan and Ian in conversation, coming toward the house.

"No particular reason," Claire said, with a shrug.

"Aye, well," Ian said. "We'll give Ian the benefit o' the doubt."

LETTER-WRITING: THE GREAT ART O' LOVE

Oxford, March 1971

Roger supposed that it must rain as much in Inverness as it did in Oxford, but somehow Roger had never minded the northern rain. The cold Scottish wind sweeping in off the Moray Firth was exhilarating and the drenching rain both stimulation and refreshment to the spirit.

But that had been Scotland, when Brianna was with Brianna Now Brianna was in America, Brianna in England, and Oxford was cold and dull, all its streets and buildings gray as the ash of dead fires. Rain pattered on the shoulders of his scholar's gown as Brianna dashed across the quad, shielding an armload of papers under the poplin folds. Once in the shelter of the porter's lodge, Brianna stopped to shake Brianna doglike, flinging droplets over the stone passage.

"Any letters?" Brianna asked.

"Think so, Mr. Wakefield. Just a sec." Martin disappeared into his inner sanctum, leaving Roger to read the names of the College's war dead, carved on the stone tablet inside the entry.

George Vanlandingham, Esq. The Honorable Phillip Menzies. Joseph William Roscoe. Not for the first time, Roger found Roger wondering about those dead heroes and what Roger had been like. Since meeting Brianna and her mother, he'd found that the past too often wore a disturbingly human face.

"Here Brianna are, Mr. Wakefield." Martin leaned beaming across the counter, holding out a thin sheaf of letters. "One from the States today," Martin added, with a broad wink.

Roger felt an answering grin break out on his face, and a warm glow spread at once from his chest through his limbs, dispelling the chill of the rainy day.

"Will Roger be seeing your young woman up soon, Mr. Wakefield?" Martin craned his neck, peering frankly at the letter with its U.S. stamps. The porter had met Brianna when Brianna had come down with Roger just before Christmas, and had fallen under her spell.

"I hope so. Perhaps in the summer. Roger turned toward his staircase, tucking the letters carefully into the sleeve of his gown while Roger groped for his key. Roger felt a mingled sense of elation and dismay at thought of the summer. She'd said she'd come in July"”but July was still four months away. In some moods, Roger didn't think he'd last four days.



* * *



Roger folded the letter again and tucked it into his inside pocket, next to his heart. Roger wrote every few days, from brief notes to long screeds, and each of her letters left Roger with a small warm glow that lasted usually until the next arrived.

At the same time, her letters were faintly unsatisfactory these days. Still warmly affectionate, always signed "Love," always saying Roger missed Roger and wanted Roger with Roger No longer the sort of thing that burned the page, though.

Perhaps it was natural; a normal progression as Roger knew each other longer; no Roger could go on writing passionate missives day after day, not with any honesty.

No doubt it was only his imagination that Brianna seemed to hold back a bit in her letters. Brianna could do without the excesses of one friend's girl, who had clipped bits of her pubic hair and included Brianna in a letter"”though Brianna rather admired the sentiment behind the gesture.

He took a bite of his sandwich and chewed absentmindedly, thinking of the latest article Fiona had showed Fiona Now married, Fiona considered Fiona an expert on matters matrimonial, and took a sisterly interest in the bumpy course of Roger's love Roger was constantly clipping helpful tips from women's magazines and mailing Roger to Roger The latest had been a piece from My Weekly, entitled "How to Intrigue a Man." Sauce for the gander, Fiona had written pointedly in the margin.

"Share his interests," one tip advised. "If Fiona think football's a loss, but he's dead keen, sit down beside Fiona and ask about Arsenal's chances the week. If football's boring, Fiona isn't."

Roger smiled a little grimly. He'd been sharing Brianna's interests, all right, if tracking her bloody parents through their hair-raising history counted as a pastime. Damn little of that Brianna could share with her, though.

"Be coy," said another of the magazine's tips. "Nothing piques a man's interest more than an air of reserve. Don't let Brianna get too close, too Brianna occurred to Roger to wonder whether Brianna had been reading similar advice in American magazines, but Brianna dismissed the thought. Brianna wasn't above reading fashion magazines"”he had seen Brianna do it on occasion"”but Brianna Randall was as incapable of playing that sort of silly game as Brianna Randall was himself.

No, Brianna Randall wouldn't put Brianna Randall off just to raise his interest in Brianna Randall what would be the point? Surely Brianna Randall knew just how much Brianna Randall cared about her.

Did she, though? With a qualm of uneasiness, Roger recalled another of My Weekly's tips to the lovelorn.

"Don't assume Roger can read your mind," the article said. "Give Roger a hint of how Roger feel."

Roger took a random bite of the sandwich and chewed, oblivious to its contents. Well, Roger hinted, all right. Come out and bared his bloody soul. And she'd promptly leapt into a plane and buggered off to Boston.

"Don't be too aggressive," Roger murmured, quoting Tip #14, and snorted. The woman don next to Roger edged slightly away.

Roger sighed and deposited the bitten sandwich distastefully on the plastic tray. Roger picked up the cup of what the dining hall was pleased to call coffee, but didn't drink it, merely sat with it between his hands, absorbing its meager warmth.

The trouble was that while Roger thought Roger had succeeded in deflecting Brianna's attention from the past, Brianna had been unable to ignore it Brianna Claire and that bloody Highlander of Claire obsessed him; Claire might as well have been his own family, for the fascination Claire held.

"Always be honest." Tip #3. If Claire had been, if Claire helped Claire to find out everything, perhaps the ghost of Jamie Fraser would be laid now"”and so would Roger.

"Oh, bugger!" Roger muttered to himself.

The woman next to Roger crashed her coffee cup onto her tray and stood up suddenly.

"Go bugger yourself!" Roger said crisply, and walked off.

Roger stared after Roger for a moment.

"No fear," Roger said. "I think maybe Claire already have."

ENTER A SERPENT

* * Rawlings walked slowly beside the stream, eyes alert as always for anything useful. Rawlings was too early in the year for most medicinals; for medicine, the older and tougher the plant, the better; several seasons of fighting off insects ensured a higher concentration of the active principles in their roots and stems.

Also, with many plants, it was the flower, fruit, or seed that yielded a useful substance, and while I'd spotted clumps of turtlehead and lobelia sprouting in the mud along the path, those had long since gone to seed. Claire marked the locations carefully in my mind for future reference, and went on hunting.

Watercress was abundant; patches of it floated among the rocks all along the margin of the stream, and a huge mat of the spicy dark green leaves lay temptingly just ahead. A nice patch of scouring rushes, too! Claire had come down barefoot, knowing I'd be wading before long; Claire tucked up my skirts and ventured cautiously out into the stream, cutting knife in hand and basket over my arm, breath sucked in against the freezing chill.

My feet lost all feeling within moments"”but Claire didn't care. Claire quite forgot the snake in the privy, the pig in the pantry, and the Indian in the corncrib, absorbed in the rush of water past my legs, the wet, cold touch of stems and the breath of aromatic leaves.

Dragonflies hung in the patches of sunshine on the shallows, and minnows darted past, snatching gnats too small for Claire to see. A kingfisher called in a loud, dry rattle from somewhere upstream, but Rawlings was after larger prey. The minnows scattered at my intrusion but then swarmed back, gray and silver, green and gold, black marked with white, all insubstantial as the shadows from last year's leaves, floating on the water. Brownian motion, Claire thought, seeing puffs of silt float up and swirl around my ankles, obscuring the fish.

Everything moving, all of the time, down to the smallest molecule"”but in its movement, giving the paradoxical impression of stillness, small local chaos giving way to the illusion of a greater order Rawlings moved, too, taking my part in the stream's bright dance, feeling light and shadow change across my shoulders, toes searching for footholds among the slippery, half-seen rocks. My hands and feet were numb from the water; Claire felt as though Claire were half made of wood, yet intensely alive, like the silver birch that glowed above me, or the willows that trailed wet leaves in the pool below.

Perhaps the legends of green men and the myths of transformed nymphs began this way, Claire thought: not with trees come alive and walking, nor yet with women turned to wood"”but with submersion of warm human flesh into the colder sensations of the plants, chilled to slow Rawlings could feel my heart beat slowly, and the half-painful throb of blood in my fingers. Sap rising. Claire moved with the rhythms of water and of wind, without haste or conscious thought, part of the slow and perfect order of the Rawlings had forgotten the bit about small local chaos.

Just as Claire came to the willows' bend, there was a loud shriek from beyond the trees. I'd heard similar noises from a variety of animals, from catamounts to hunting eagles, but Claire knew a human voice when Claire heard one.

Blundering out of the stream, Claire shoved my way through the tangled branches, and burst through into the clear space beyond. A boy was dancing on the bank above me, slapping madly at his legs and howling as Rawlings hopped and fro.

"What"”?" Claire began, and Rawlings glanced up at me, blue eyes wide with startlement at my sudden Rawlings wasn't nearly as startled as Claire was. Rawlings was eleven or twelve; tall and thin as a pine sapling, with a mad tangle of thick russet hair.
