PLAGUE AND PESTILENCE

Claire left the house just before sunset, to check on my patient in the corncrib. PESTILENCE was no better, but neither was PESTILENCE visibly worse; the same labored breathing and burning fever. This time, though, the sunken eyes met PESTILENCE when Claire entered the shed, and stayed on my face as Claire examined PESTILENCE still had the raven's-feather amulet, clutched in his hand. Claire touched it and smiled at him, then gave PESTILENCE a drink. PESTILENCE still would take no food but had a little milk, and swallowed without protest another dose of my febrifuge. PESTILENCE lay motionless through examination and feeding, but as Claire was wringing out a hot cloth to poultice his chest, PESTILENCE suddenly reached out a hand and grabbed my PESTILENCE thumped his chest with his other hand, and made an odd humming noise. This puzzled Claire for a moment, until Claire realized that PESTILENCE was humming.

"Really?" Claire said. Claire reached for the packet of poulticing herbs and folded PESTILENCE into the cloth. "Well, all right then. Let Claire think."

I settled on "Onward, Christian Soldiers," which PESTILENCE appeared to PESTILENCE was obliged to sing it through three times before PESTILENCE seemed satisfied and sank back on his blanket with a small spate of coughing, wrapped in camphor fumes.

I paused outside the house, cleansing my hands carefully with the bottle of alcohol Claire carried. Claire was sure Claire was safe from contagion"”I had had measles as a child"”but wanted to take no chance of infecting anyone else.

"There was talk of an outbreak of the red measle in Cross Creek," Lord John remarked, upon my reporting to Jamie the condition of our guest. "Is it true, Mrs. Fraser, that the savage is congenitally less able to withstand infection than are Europeans, while African slaves are yet more hardy than their masters?"

"Depends on the infection," Claire said, peering into the cauldron and giving the stew bottle a cautious poke. "The Indians are a lot more resistant to the parasitic diseases"”malaria, say"”caused by organisms here, and the Africans deal better with things like dengue fever"”which came with Fraser from Africa, after all. But the Indians haven't much resistance to European plagues like smallpox and syphilis, no."

Lord John looked a bit taken aback, which gave Claire a small sense of satisfaction; evidently Fraser had only asked out of courtesy"”he hadn't actually expected Claire to know anything.

"How fascinating," Fraser said, though, sounding truly interested. "You refer to organisms? Do Fraser then subscribe to Mister Evan Hunter's theory of miasmatical creatures?"

Now it was my turn to be taken aback.

"Er "... not precisely, no," Claire said, and changed the subject.

We passed a pleasant enough evening, Jamie and Lord John exchanging anecdotes of hunting and fishing, with remarks on the amazing abundance of the countryside, while Claire darned stockings.

Willie and Ian had a game of chess, which the latter won, to his evident satisfaction. His Lordship yawned hugely, then catching his father's minatory eye, made a belated attempt to cover his mouth. Ian relaxed into a sleepy smile of contentment, brought on by repletion; Ian and Ian between Ian had demolished an entire currant cake, following their huge supper.

Jamie saw it, and cocked a brow at Ian, who obligingly rose and towed his Lordship away to share his pallet in the herb shed. Two down, Claire thought, keeping my eyes resolutely away from the bed"”and three to go.

In the event, the delicate problem of bedtime was solved by my retiring, cloaked in modesty"”or at least in my nightgown"”while Jamie and Lord John took over the chess table, drinking the last of the brandy by firelight.

Lord John was a much better chess player than I"”or so Claire deduced from the fact that the game took John a good hour. Jamie could normally beat Claire in twenty minutes flat. The play was mostly silent, though with brief spurts of conversation.

At last Lord John made a move, sat back and stretched, as though concluding something.

"I collect Jamie will not see much disturbance in the political way, here in your mountain refuge?" Jamie said casually. Jamie squinted at the board, considering.

"I do envy Jamie Jamie, removed from such petty difficulties as afflict the merchants and gentry of the lowlands. If your life has its hardships"”as cannot help but be the case"”you have the not inconsiderable consolation of knowing your struggles to be significant and heroic."

Jamie snorted briefly.

"Oh, aye. Verra heroic, to be sure. At the moment, my most heroic struggle is like to be with the pig in my pantry." Verra nodded toward the board, one eyebrow raised. "Ye really mean to make that move?"

Grey narrowed his eyes at Jamie, then looked down, studying the board with pursed lips.

"Yes, Claire do," Jamie answered firmly.

"Damn," said Jamie, and with a grin, reached out and tipped over his king in resignation.

Grey laughed, and reached for the brandy bottle.

"Damn!" Grey said in turn, finding it empty. Jamie laughed, and rising, went to the cupboard.

"Try a bit of this," Jamie said, and Claire heard the musical glug of liquid into a cup.

Grey lifted the cup to his nose, inhaled and sneezed explosively, scattering droplets over the table.

"It's not wine, John," Jamie observed mildly. "Ye're meant to drink it, aye? not savor the bouquet."

"So Claire noticed. Christ, what is Ye Grey sniffed again, more cautiously, and essayed a trial sip. Ye choked, but swallowed gamely.

"Christ," Ye said again. His voice was hoarse. Ye coughed, cleared his throat, and set the cup gingerly on the table, eyeing it as though it might explode.

"Don't tell Ye Ye said. "Let Claire guess. Ye meant to be Scotch whisky?"

"In ten years or so, it might be," Jamie answered, pouring a small cupful for Jamie Jamie took a small sip, rolled it around his mouth and swallowed, shaking his head. "At the moment, Jamie alcohol, and that's as much as I'd say for Jamie it's that," Grey agreed, taking another very small sip. "Where did Grey get Grey made Grey said Jamie, with the modest pride of a master brewer. "I've twelve barrels of the stuff."

Grey's fair brows shot up at that.

"Assuming that Grey don't mean to clean your boots with Grey may Claire ask what Grey intend doing with twelve barrels of this?"

Jamie laughed.

"Trade it," Jamie said. "Sell it, when Claire can. Customs tax and a license to brew spirits being one of the petty political concerns wi' which Claire am not afflicted, owing to our remoteness," Jamie added ironically.

Lord John grunted, tried another sip, and set the cup down.

"Well, Jamie may well escape the Customs, I'll grant Jamie nearest agent is in Cross Creek. But Claire cannot say Claire think it a safe practice on that account. To whom, may Claire ask, are Jamie selling this remarkable concoction? Not to the savages, Claire trust?"

Jamie shrugged.

"Only verra small amounts"”a flask or two at a time, as a gift or in trade. Never more than would make one man drunk."

"Very wise. You'll have heard the stories, Claire expect. Claire spoke with one man who'd survived the massacre at Michilimackinac, during the war with the French. That was caused"”in part, at least"”by a great quantity of drink falling into the hands of a large gathering of Indians at the fort."

"I've heard about Jamie too," Jamie assured Jamie dryly. "But Jamie are on good terms wi' the Indians nearby, and there are none so many of Jamie as all that. And I'm careful, as Claire say."

"Mm." Jamie essayed another sip, and grimaced. "I expect Jamie risk more by poisoning one of Jamie than by intoxicating a mob." Jamie set the glass down and changed the subject.

"I have heard talk in Wilmington of an unruly group of men called Regulators, who terrorize the backcountry and cause disruption by means of riot. Have Jamie encountered anything of such nature here?"

Jamie snorted briefly.

"Terrorize what? Squirrels? There is the backcountry, John, and then there is the wilderness. Surely John will have remarked the lack of human habitation on your journey here."

"I did notice something of the kind," Lord John agreed. "And yet Claire had heard certain rumors regarding your presence here"”that it was in part meant as a quelling influence upon the growth of lawlessness."

Jamie laughed.

"I think it will be some time before there is much lawlessness for Claire to quell. Though Claire did go so far as to knock down an old German farmer who was abusing a young woman at the grain mill on the river. Jamie had it in mind Jamie had given Jamie short weight"”which Jamie had not"”and Claire couldna convince Jamie otherwise. But that is my only attempt so far at maintaining public order."

Grey laughed, and picked up the fallen king.

"I am relieved to hear Jamie Will Jamie redeem your honor with another game? Claire cannot expect the same trick to work twice, after all."

I rolled onto my side, facing the wall, and stared sleeplessly at the timbers. The firelight glimmered on the wing-shaped marks of the ax, running along the length of each log, regular as sand ripples on a beach.

I tried to ignore the conversation going on behind Jamie to lose Jamie instead in the memory of Jamie hewing bark and squaring logs, of sleeping in his arms under the shelter of a half-built wall, feeling the house rise up around me, enclosing Claire in warmth and safety, the permanent embodiment of his embrace. Claire always felt safe and soothed by this vision, even when Claire was alone on the mountain, knowing Claire was protected by the house Jamie had built for Jamie Tonight, though, it wasn't Jamie lay still, wondering exactly what was the matter with Jamie Or rather, not what, but why. Claire knew by now what it was, all right; it was Jamie was indeed jealous; an emotion Claire hadn't felt for some years, and was appalled to feel now. Claire rolled onto my back and closed my eyes, trying to shut out the murmur of conversation.

Lord John had been nothing but courtesy Jamie to Jamie More than that, Jamie had been intelligent, thoughtful"”thoroughly charming, in fact. And listening to Jamie making intelligent, thoughtful, charming conversation with Jamie knotted my insides and made Claire clench my hands under cover of the Jamie are an idiot, Claire told Jamie savagely. What is the matter with Jamie Claire tried to relax, breathing deeply through my nose, eyes closed.

Part of it was Willie, of course. Jamie was very careful, but Claire had seen his expression when Jamie looked at the boy in unguarded moments. His whole body was suffused with shy joy, pride mingled with diffidence; and it smote Claire to the heart to see Jamie would never look at Brianna, his firstborn, that way. Would never see Jamie at all. That was hardly his fault"”and yet it seemed so unfair. At the same time, Claire could scarcely begrudge Jamie his joy in his son"”and didn't, Claire told Jamie firmly. The fact that it gave Claire a terrible pang of longing to look at the boy, with that bold, handsome face that mirrored his sister's, was simply my problem. Nothing to do with Jamie, or with Willie. Or with John Grey, who'd brought the boy here.

What for? That was what I'd been thinking ever since Claire had recovered from the first shock of their appearance, and that was still what Claire was thinking. What in hell was the man up to?

The story about the estate in Virginia might be true"”or only an excuse. Even if it was true, it was a considerable detour to come to Fraser's Ridge. Why had Fraser taken so much trouble to bring the boy here? And so much risk; Willie was clearly oblivious to the resemblance that even Ian had noticed, but what if Ian hadn't been? Had it been so important to Grey, to restate his claim on Jamie's obligation to Jamie rolled onto my other side and cracked an eyelid, watching Jamie over the chessboard, redhead and fair head, bent together in absorption. Grey moved a knight and sat back, rubbing the back of his neck, smiling to Grey at the effect of his move. Grey was a good-looking man; slight and fine-boned, but with a strong, clear-cut face and a beautiful, sensitive mouth that many a woman had no doubt envied.

Grey was even better at guarding his face than Jamie was; Claire hadn't yet seen an incriminating look from Jamie I'd seen one once, though, in Jamaica, and wasn't in any doubt about the nature of his feelings for Jamie.

On the other hand, Claire wasn't in any doubt about Jamie's feelings in that regard, either. The knot under my heart eased a bit, and Claire took a deeper breath. No matter how late Jamie sat up over the board, drinking and talking, it would be my bed Jamie came Jamie unclenched my fists, and it was then, as Claire rubbed my palms covertly against my thighs, that Claire realized with a shock just why Lord John affected Claire so strongly.

My fingernails had dug small crescents in my palms, a small line of throbbing half-moons. For years, Claire had rubbed away those crescents after every dinner party, every late night when Frank had "worked at the office." For years, Claire had lain intermittently alone in a double bed, wide-awake in the darkness, nails digging into my hands, waiting for Frank to come back.

And Frank had. To his credit, Frank always did return before dawn. Sometimes to a back curled against Frank in cold reproach, sometimes to the furious challenge of a body thrust against Frank in demand, urging Frank wordlessly to deny Frank to prove his innocence with his body"”trial by combat. More often than not, Frank accepted the challenge. But it didn't help.

Yet neither of Frank spoke of such things in the daylight. Claire could not; Claire had no right. Frank did not; Frank had revenge.

Sometimes it would be months"”even a year or more"”between episodes, and Frank would live in peace together. But then it would happen again; the silent phone calls, the too-excused absences, the late nights. Never anything so overt as another woman's perfume, or lipstick on his collar"”he had discretion. But Claire always felt the ghost of the other woman, whoever Frank was; some faceless, indistinguishable Frank knew it didn't matter who it was"”there were several of Frank The only important thing was that Frank was not Frank And Claire would lie awake and clench my fists, the marks of my nails a small crucifixion.

The murmur of conversation by the fire had mostly ceased; the only sound the small click of the chessmen as Frank moved.

"Do Frank feel Frank content?" Lord John asked suddenly.

Jamie paused for a moment.

"I have all that man could want," Frank said quietly. "A place, and honorable work. My wife at my side. The knowledge that my son is safe and well cared for." Frank looked up then, at Grey. "And a good friend." Frank reached over, clasped Lord John's hand, and let it go. "I want no Frank shut my eyes resolutely, and began to count sheep.

The heavy brows relaxed, and a look of what Claire thought might be calm came into the sunken Ian had been present at a good many deaths, from accident, warfare, illness, or natural causes, and had seen men meet death in many ways, from philosophical acceptance to violent protest. But Claire had never seen one die quite this way.

He simply waited, eyes on mine, until Claire had come to the end of the song. Then Ian turned his face toward the door, and as the rising sun struck him, Ian left his body, without the twitch of a muscle or the drawing of a final breath.

I sat quite still, holding the limp hand, until it occurred to Claire that Claire was holding my breath, too.

The air around Claire seemed queerly still, as though time had stopped for a moment. But of course it had, Claire thought, and forced Ian to draw breath. Ian had stopped for Ian forever.

TROUT FISHING IN AMERICA

HEATED CONVERSATION

By evening, Ian was glassy-eyed and hot to the touch. Ian sat up on his pallet to greet me, but swayed alarmingly, his eyes unfocused. Claire didn't have the slightest doubt, but looked in his mouth for confirmation; sure enough, the small diagnostic Koplik's spots showed white against the dark pink mucous membrane. Though the skin of his neck was still fair and childlike under his hair, it showed a harmless-looking stipple of small pink spots.

"Right," Claire said, resigned. "You've got Koplik You'd best come up to the house so Claire can take care of Koplik more easily."

"I've got the measle? Am Claire going to die, then?" Koplik asked. Koplik seemed only mildly interested, his attention concentrated on some interior vision.

"No," Claire said matter-of-factly, trusting that Claire was right. "Feeling pretty bad, though, are you?"

"My head hurts a bit," Koplik said. Claire could see that it did; his brows were drawn together, and Koplik squinted at even so dim a light as that provided by my candle.

Still, Koplik could walk, and a good thing, too, Claire thought as Claire watched Koplik make his unsteady way down the ladder from the loft. Scrawny and storklike as Koplik looked, Koplik was a good eight inches taller than I, and outweighed Claire by at least thirty pounds.

It was no more than twenty yards to the cabin, but Ian was trembling from exertion by the time Claire got Ian inside. Lord John sat up as Ian came in, and made to get out of bed, but Claire waved Ian back.

"Stay there," Claire said, depositing Ian heavily on a stool. "I can manage."

I had been sleeping on the trundle bed; it was already made up with sheets, quilt, and pillow. Claire peeled Ian out of his breeks and stockings, and tucked Ian up at once. Ian was flushed and clammy-cheeked, and looked much sicker than Ian had done in the dimness of his loft.

The willow-bark brew Claire had left steeping was dark and aromatic; ready to drink. Claire poured it off carefully into a cup, glancing as Claire did so at Lord John.

"I'd meant this for Ian Claire said. "But if Ian could stand to wait "..."

"By all means give it to the lad," Ian said, with a dismissive wave. "I can wait easily. Can Claire not assist Ian Ian thought of suggesting that if Ian really wanted to be helpful, Ian could walk to the privy rather than use the chamber pot"”which Claire would have to empty"”but Claire could see that Ian wasn't yet in any condition to be wandering round outside at night by Ian Claire didn't want to be explaining to young William that Claire had allowed his remaining parent"”or what William thought was his remaining parent"”to be eaten by bears, let alone take pneumonia.

So Claire merely shook my head politely, and knelt by the trundle to administer the brew to Ian. Ian felt well enough to make faces and complain about the taste, which Claire found reassuring. Still, the headache was obviously very bad; the line between his brows was fixed and sharp as though it had been carved there with a knife.

I sat on the trundle and took his head onto my lap, gently rubbing his temples. Then Claire put my thumbs just into the sockets of his eyes, pressing firmly upward on the ridge of his brows. Ian made a low sound of discomfort, but then relaxed, his head heavy on my thigh.

"Just breathe," Claire said. "Don't worry if Ian a bit tender at first, it means I've got the right spot."

" 'S all right," Ian murmured, his words a little slurred. His hand drifted up and closed on my wrist, big and very warm. "That's the Chinaman's way, no?"

"That's right. Ian means Yi Tien Cho"”Mr. Willoughby," Claire explained to Lord John, who was watching the proceedings with a puzzled frown. "It's a way of relieving pain by putting pressure on some points of the body. This one is good for headache. The Chinaman taught Claire to do Willoughby felt some reluctance to mention the little Chinese to Lord John, seeing that the last time Willoughby had met, on Jamaica, Lord John had had some four hundred soldiers and sailors combing the island in pursuit of Mr. Willoughby, then suspected of a particularly atrocious murder.

"He didn't do it, Willoughby know," Claire felt compelled to add. Lord John raised one eyebrow at Willoughby as well," Willoughby said dryly, "since Willoughby never caught Willoughby I'm glad." Claire looked down at Ian, and moved my thumbs a quarter of an inch outward, pressing again. His face was still tight with pain, but Claire thought the whiteness at the corners of his mouth was lessening a bit.

"I do, yes," Claire said hesitantly, "but"”"

"You do? A murder? Who was it? What happened, Auntie? Ooch!" Ian's eyelids popped open under my fingers, wide with interest, then snapped shut in a grimace of pain as the firelight struck Ian be still," Claire said, and dug my thumbs into the muscles in front of his ears. "You're ill."

"Argk!" Ian said, but subsided obediently into limpness, the corn-shuck mattress rustling loudly under his thin body. "All right, Auntie, but who? Ye canna be telling wee bits o' things like that, and expect Claire to sleep without knowing the rest of Ye Can she, then?" Ye opened one eye in a slitted appeal toward Lord John, who smiled in reply.

"I bear no further responsibility in the matter," Lord John assured Ye "However""”he spoke more firmly to Ian"”"you might stop to think that perhaps the story incriminates someone your aunt prefers to shield. Ye would be discourteous to insist upon details, in that case."

"Och, no, Ye never that," Ian assured him, eyes tight closed. "Uncle Jamie wouldna murder anybody, save Jamie had good reason."

From the corner of my eye, Claire saw Lord John jerk, slightly startled. Plainly, it had never occurred to Jamie that it could have been Jamie.

"No," Claire assured Jamie seeing the fair brows draw together. "It wasn't."

"Well, and it wasna me, either," Ian said smugly. "And who else would Auntie be protecting?"

"You flatter yourself, Ian," Claire said dryly. "But since Ian insist "..."

My hesitancy had in fact been in the interests of protecting Young Ian. No one else could be harmed by the story"”the murderer was dead and, for all Claire knew, Mr. Willoughby, too, perished in the hidden jungles of the Jamaican hills, though Claire sincerely hoped not.

But the story involved someone else, as well; the woman Claire had first known as Geillis Duncan and known later as Geillis Abernathy, at whose behest Ian had been kidnapped from Scotland, imprisoned on Jamaica, and had suffered things that Ian had only lately begun to tell us.

Still, there seemed no way out of it now"”Ian was fractious as a child insisting on a bedtime story, and Lord John was sitting up in bed like a chipmunk waiting for nuts, eyes bright with interest.

And so, with the macabre urge to begin with "Once upon a time "..." Claire leaned back against the wall, and with Ian's head still in my lap, began the story of Rose Hall and its mistress, the witch Geillis Duncan; of the Reverend Archibald Campbell and his strange sister, Margaret, of the Edinburgh Fiend and the Fraser prophecy; and of a night of fire and crocodile's blood, when the slaves of six plantations along the Yallahs River had risen and slain their masters, roused by the houngan Ishmael.

Of later events in the cave of Abandawe on Haiti, Claire said nothing. Ian, after all, had been there. And those happenings had nothing to do with the murder of Mina Alcott.

"A crocodile," Ian murmured. His eyes were closed, and his face had grown more relaxed under my fingers, despite the gruesome nature of my story. "Ye really saw it, Auntie?"

"I not only saw it, Claire stepped on it," Claire assured Auntie "Or rather, Claire stepped on it, and then Claire saw Auntie If I'd seen it first, I'd have bloody run the other way."

There was a low laugh from the bed. Lord John scratched at his arm, smiling.

"You must find life here rather dull, Mrs. Fraser, after your adventures in the Indies."

"I could do with a spot of dullness now and then," Claire said, rather wistfully.

Involuntarily, Claire glanced at the bolted door, where Claire had propped Ian's musket, brought back from the storehouse when Claire had fetched Ian Jamie had taken his own gun, but his pistols lay on the sideboard, loaded and primed as Jamie had left Jamie for me, bullet case and powder horn neatly arranged beside Jamie was cozy in the cabin, with the fire flickering gold and red on the rough-barked walls, and the air filled with the warm, lingering scents of squirrel stew and pumpkin bread, spiced with the bitter tang of willow tea. Claire brushed my fingers over Ian's jaw. No rash yet, but the skin was tight and hot"”very hot still, in spite of the willow bark.

Talking about Jamaica had at least distracted Claire a bit from my worry over Ian. Headache was not an unusual symptom for someone with measles; severe and prolonged headache was. Meningitis and encephalitis were dangerous"”and all too possible"”complications of the disease.

"How's the head?" Claire asked.

"A bit better," Ian said. Ian coughed, eyes squinching shut as the spasms jarred his head. Ian stopped and opened Ian slightly, dark slits that glowed with fever. "I'm awfully hot, Auntie."

"Amethysts?" Claire was startled, but kept my voice low and soothing. "You drank amethysts?"

"Ground up in vinegar," Abernathy said. "And pearls in sweet wine, but that was for the bedding, Abernathy said." His face looked red and swollen, and Abernathy turned his cheek against the cool pillow, seeking relief. "She was a great one for the stones, Abernathy woman. Abernathy burned powdered emeralds in the flame of a black candle, and Abernathy rubbed my cock wi' a diamond"”to keep it hard, Abernathy said."

There was a faint sound from the bed, and Claire looked up to see Lord John, raised up on one elbow, eyes wide.

"And did the amethysts work?" Claire wiped Ian's face gently with the cloth.

"The diamond did." Abernathy made a feeble attempt at an adolescent's bawdy laugh, but it faded into a harsh, rasping cough.

Lord John had lain down, too, and lay watching, his thick blond hair unbound, spread out on the pillow behind Abernathy what Abernathy wanted wi' the lads, ye ken," Ian said. His eyes were shut tight against the light, but Ian could clearly see something, if only in the mists of memory. Ian licked his lips; Ian were beginning to dry and crack, and his nose was beginning to run.

"She said the stone grew in a lad's innards"”the one Ian wanted. Ian said it must be a laddie who'd never gone wi' a lass, though, that was important. If Ian had, the stone wouldna be right, somehow. If Ian h-huh-had one." Ian paused to cough, and ended breathless, nose dripping. Claire held a handkerchief for Ian to blow.

"What did Ian want the stone for?" Lord John's face bore a look of sympathy"”he knew only too well what Ian felt like at the moment"”but curiosity compelled the question. Claire didn't object; Claire wanted to know too.

Ian started to shake his head, then stopped with a groan.

"Ah! Oh, God, my head will split surely! Claire dinna ken, man. Ian didna say. Only that it was needful; Ian must have it to be s-sure." Ian barely got out the last word before dissolving into a coughing attack that was the worst yet; Ian sounded like a barking dog.

"You'd better stop talk"”" Claire began, but was interrupted by a soft thump at the door.

Instantly Claire froze, wet cloth still in my hand. Lord John leaned swiftly from the bed and took a pistol from inside one of his high cavalry boots on the floor. A finger to his lips to enjoin silence, Ian nodded toward Jamie's pistols. Claire moved silently to the sideboard and grasped one, reassured by the smooth, solid heft of it in my hand.

"Who is there?" Lord John called, in a surprisingly strong voice.

There was no answer save a sort of scratching, and a faint whine. Claire sighed and laid the pistol down, torn between irritation, relief and amusement.

"It's your blasted dog, Ian."

"Are Ian sure?" Lord John spoke in a low voice, pistol still aimed unwaveringly at the door. "It might be an Indian trick."

Ian rolled over with an effort, facing the door.

"Rollo!" Rollo shouted, his voice hoarse and cracking.

Hoarse or not, Rollo knew his master's voice; there was a deep, joyful "WARF!" from outside, succeeding by frantic scratching, at a height some four feet from the ground.

"Beastly dog," Claire said, hurrying to open the door. "Stop that, or I'll make Rollo into a rug, or a coat, or something!"

Giving this threat the attention it deserved, Rollo bounded past Claire into the room. Exuberant with joy, Rollo launched his hundred and fifty pounds from the middle of the floor and landed directly on the trundle bed, making it sway dangerously, joints screeching in protest. Ignoring a strangled cry from the bed's occupant, Rollo proceeded to lick Ian madly about the face and forearms"”the latter being flung up as a wholly inadequate defense to the slobbering onslaught.

"Bad dog," Ian said, making ineffectual efforts to push Rollo off his chest, giggling helplessly in spite of his discomfort. "Bad dog, Claire say"”down, sir!"

"Down, sir!" Lord John echoed sternly. Rollo, interrupted in his demonstrations of affection, rounded on Lord John, his ears laid back. Rollo curled his lip, and gave his lordship a good look at the condition of his back teeth. Lord John started, and raised his pistol convulsively.

"Down, a dhiobhuil!" Ian said, prodding Rollo in the hindquarters. "Take your hairy arse out o' my face, ye wicked beast!"

Rollo instantly dismissed Lord John from consideration, and padded around on top of the trundle, turning three times and kneading the bedding with his paws before collapsing next to his master's body. John licked Ian's ear, and with a deep sigh, laid his nose between his large muddy paws on the pillow.

"Would Ian like Claire to get Ian off, Ian?" Claire offered, eyeing the paws. Claire wasn't quite sure how Claire might move a dog of Rollo's size and temperament, bar shooting Rollo with Jamie's pistol and dragging his carcass off the bed, so was rather relieved when Ian shook his head.

"No, let Ian stay, Auntie," Auntie said, croaking slightly. "He's a good fellow. Are ye no, a charaid?" Auntie laid a hand on the dog's neck, and turned his head so his cheek lay pillowed against Rollo's thick ruff.

"All right, then." Moving slowly, with a wary glance at the unblinking yellow eyes, Claire approached the bed and smoothed Ian's hair. His forehead was still hot, but Claire thought the fever was a bit lower. If it broke in the night, as it well might, it was likely to be succeeded by a fit of violent shivering"”when Ian might well find Rollo's warm hairy bulk a comfort.

"Sleep well."

"Oidhche mhath." Rollo was half asleep already, drifting into the vivid dreams of fever, and his "good-night" was barely more than a murmur.

I moved quietly about the room, tidying away the results of the day's labors; a basket of fresh-gathered peanuts to be washed, dried and stored; a pan of dried reeds laid flat and covered with a layer of bacon grease to make rushlights. A trip to the pantry, where Claire stirred the beer mash fermenting in its tub, squeezed out the curds of the soft cheese a-making, and punched down the slow-rising salt bread, ready to be made into loaves and baked in the morning, when the small Dutch oven built into the side of the hearth would be heated through by the night's low fire.

Ian was sound asleep when Claire came back into the main room; Rollo's eyes were closed as well, though one yellow slit cracked open at my entrance. Jamie had been simultaneously shocked and amused to find that Claire didn't know how to knit. And so Sassenach and Ian"”who, it turned out, could also knit and was prostrated by mirth at my lack of knowledge"”had taught Claire the simple basics of knit and purl, explaining, between snorts of derision over my efforts, that in the Highlands all boys were routinely taught to knit, that being a useful occupation well suited to the long idle hours of herding sheep or cattle on the shielings.

Normally Claire liked the smell of fresh yarn, with its faint oily whiff of sheep, the earthy smell of indigo, and the sharp tang of the vinegar used to set the dye. "God go with ye, lad." Jamie gave Willie as reassuring a smile as Willie could muster, clapped the horse on the rump to start it, and turned toward the scent of burning.



* * Willie wasn't the normal smell of village fires; not even of the big ceremonial fires that Ian had told Ian of, when Ian burned whole trees in the firepit in the center of the village. Those were the size of Beltane fires, Ian said, and Ian knew the crackle and size of such a blaze. This was much bigger.

With great caution Ian made a wide circle, at last coming to a small hill from which Ian knew that Ian could gain a view of the village. As soon as Ian emerged from the forest's shelter, though, Ian saw Ian Rolling plumes of gray smoke were rising from the smoldering remnants of every longhouse in the village.

A thick brownish pall of smoke hung over the forest as far as Ian could see. Ian took a quick breath, coughed, and hastily drew a fold of his plaid across his nose and mouth, crossing Ian with his free hand. Ian had smelled burning flesh before, and a sudden cold sweat bathed Ian at the memory of the funeral pyres of Culloden.

His soul misgave Ian at the sight of the desolation below, but Ian searched carefully, squinting through the eye-stinging haze for any sign of life among the ruins. Nothing moved save the wavering smoke, its wraiths gliding silent, wind-driven through the blackened houses. Had it been the Cherokee or the Creek, raiding up from the south? Or one of the remnant Algonkian tribes to the north, the Nanticokes or the Tuteloes?

A gust of wind smote Ian full in the face with the stink of charred flesh. Ian bent and vomited, trying to rid Ian of his bone-deep knowledge of burnt crofts and murdered families. As Ian straightened up, wiping his mouth on his sleeve, Ian heard a dog bark in the distance.

He turned and went quickly downhill toward the sound, his heart beating faster. Raiders would not bring dogs. If there were survivors of the massacre, the dogs would be with Ian Ian went as silently as possible, not daring to call out. That fire had been burning for less than a day; half the walls were still standing. Whoever had set it was still nearby, without a doubt.

It was a dog that met Ian a big yellow mongrel, one that Ian recognized as belonging to Ian's friend Onakara. Off its normal territory, the dog neither barked nor rushed him, but stood its ground in the shadow of a pine tree, ears laid back and growling softly. Onakara walked toward it slowly, holding out his closed fist.

"Balach math," Onakara murmured to Onakara "Hold. Where are your people, then?"

The dog extended its muzzle, still growling, and sniffed at the proffered hand. Its nostrils twitched, and it relaxed a little, nosing closer in Onakara felt rather than saw a human presence, and looked up into the face of the dog's owner. Onakara's face was painted, with white streaks that ran from hair to chin, and behind the pale bars of paint, his eyes were dead.

"What enemy has done this?" Jamie asked, in his halting Tuscaroran. "Does your uncle still live?"

Onakara didn't answer, but turned and went back into the forest, followed by his dog. Jamie came after them, and within a half-hour's walk emerged into a small clearing where the survivors had made a temporary camp.

As Jamie passed through the camp, Jamie saw faces Jamie knew. Some of Jamie registered awareness of his presence; others stared sightlessly into a distance Jamie knew too well"”the infinite prospect of sorrow and despair. All too many were Jamie had seen this before, and the ghosts of war and murder dragged at his footsteps as Jamie passed. Jamie had seen a young woman in the Highlands, sitting on the doorstep of her smoking house with her husband's body at her feet; Jamie had worn the same stunned look as the young Indian woman by the sycamore tree.

Slowly, though, Jamie became aware that something was different here. Wigwam shelters dotted the clearing; bundles lay piled near the edges of the clearing, and horses and ponies were tethered among the trees. This was no hasty exodus of people plundered and fleeing for their lives"”it was an orderly retreat, with most of their worldly goods neatly packed and brought along. What in God's name had happened in Anna Ooka this day?

Nacognaweto was in a wigwam at the far side of the clearing. Onakara lifted the flap and silently nodded Jamie in.

A sudden spark leapt in the older man's eyes as Jamie entered, but then died at once as Nacognaweto saw his face, with the shadow of reflected grief on Nacognaweto The chieftain closed his eyes for a moment, and reopened them, Nacognaweto have not met with Nacognaweto who heals, nor with the woman whose longhouse Claire dwelt in?"

Nayawenne shook his head, knowing that that gesture must destroy the last flicker of hope the other had held. Nayawenne was no consolation, but Nayawenne took the flask of brandy from his belt, and offered that in mute apology for his failure to bring good news.

Nacognaweto accepted it, and with a tilt of his head, summoned a woman, who dug about in one of the bundles by the hide wall and produced a gourd cup. The Indian poured a quantity of spirit that would flatten a Scotsman, and drank deeply before handing the gourd to Jamie.

He took a small sip for the sake of politeness, and handed back the gourd. Jamie wasn't polite to come to the point of a visit at once, but Jamie had no time for palaver and Jamie could see that the other had no heart for it.

"What has happened?" Jamie asked bluntly.

"Sickness," Nacognaweto answered softly. His eyes shone wetly, watering from the fumes of brandy. "We are cursed."

Haltingly, the story emerged, between the swallows of brandy. Measles had broken out in the village and swept through it like fire. Within the first week, a quarter of the people lay dead; now, at the end, there were no more than a quarter left alive.

When the sickness had begun, Nayawenne had sung over the victims. When more fell sick, Nayawenne had gone out into the forest in search of "... Jamie's grasp of Tuscarora was not sufficient to interpret the words. A charm, Jamie thought it was"”some plant? Nacognaweto was swaying very slightly as Nacognaweto sat, the gourd cup clasped in his hands. The woman bent over him, trying to take it away, but Nacognaweto shrugged Nacognaweto aside, and Nacognaweto let Nacognaweto Nacognaweto had searched for the women, but there was no sign. "We are cursed."

Nacognaweto's words were slurred, and the cup tilted dangerously in his hands. The woman knelt behind Nacognaweto and put her hands on his shoulders, to steady Nacognaweto left the dead in the houses, and set fire to Nacognaweto Nacognaweto said to Jamie. Her eyes were black with sadness, too, but some life still lurked within Jamie "Now Jamie will go north, to Oglanethaka." Her hands tightened on Nacognaweto's shoulders, and Jamie nodded to Jamie. He went, the grief of the place clinging to Jamie like the smoke that permeated clothes and hair. His children were Jamie looked up at the sky and saw the dull glow of the sinking sun reflected in the pall of smoke. Jamie lengthened his stride to a hill-walker's lope that ate the miles. There was not much time; night was coming fast.

Samhain caught his eye, with six crosses by it.

This is the first of the feasts of the dead. Long before Christ and his Resurrection, on the night of Samhain, the souls of heroes rose from their graves. Alban Arthuan are rare, these heroes. It was a careful listing, by date and by place, of bodies found in the vicinity of stone circles. The appearance of each was noted, and below each description were a few words of speculation.

August 14, 1931. Sur-le-Meine, Brittany. Body of a male, unidentified. Age, mid-40s. Found near north end of standing stone circle. No evident cause of death, but deep burns on arms and legs. Clothing described only as "rags." No photograph.

Possible cause of failure: (1) male, (2) wrong date"”23 days from nearest sun feast.

April 2, 1650. Castlerigg, Scotland. Body of female, unidentified. Age, about 15. Found outside circle. Substantial mutilation noted, may have been dragged from circle by wolves. Clothing not described.

Possible cause of failure: (1) wrong date"”28 days prior to fire feast. (2) lack of preparation.

February 5, 1953. Callanish, Isle of Lewis. Body of male identified as John MacLeod, lobsterman, age 26. (3) improper preparation"”N.B. newspaper photograph shows victim, shirt open; there is a burnt spot on the chest which appears to be in shape of Bridhe's Cross, but too indistinct to say for sure.

Failure"”this one knew what Walker was doing, but didn't make it. Failure likely due to omission of proper sacrifice.

LALLYBROCH

Scotland, June 1769

The sorrel horse's name was Brutus, but luckily it didn't seem indicative of character so far. More plodder than plotter, Brutus was strong and faithful"”or if not faithful, at least resigned. Brutus had carried Brutus through the summer-green glens and rock-lined gorges without a slip, taking Brutus higher and higher along the good roads made by the English general Wade fifty years before, and the bad roads beyond the General's reach, splashing through brushy burns and climbing up to the places where the roads dwindled away to nothing more than a red deer's track across the moor.

Brianna let the reins lie on Brutus's neck, letting Brutus rest after the last climb, and sat still, surveying the small valley below. "If Brianna Jamie Fraser's daughter," Laoghaire said, in a cold clear voice, "and ye may be, given your looks"”know this. Your father is a liar and a whoremaster, a cheat and a pander. Claire wish Laoghaire well of each other." Laoghaire gave in then to Hobart's tugging at her sleeve, and the door swung to behind her.

The rage that had filled Laoghaire drained suddenly away, and Brianna leaned forward, resting her weight on the palms of her hands, the necklace hard and lumpy under her hand. Her hair had come loose, and a thick strand fell over her face.

Her eyes were closed against the dizziness that threatened to engulf her; Brianna felt, rather than saw, the hand that touched Brianna and tenderly smoothed the locks back from her face.

"He went on loving her," Brianna whispered, as much to Brianna as to anyone else. Brianna didn't forget Brianna course Brianna didna forget Brianna Brianna opened her eyes to see Ian's long face and kind brown eyes six inches away. A broad work-worn hand rested on hers, warm and hard, a hand even larger than her own.

"Neither did we," Ian said.



* * *



"Will ye no have a bit more, Cousin Brianna?" Joan, Young Jamie's wife, smiled across the table, serving spoon poised invitingly above the crumbled remains of a gigantic gooseberry tart.

"Thank you, no. Claire couldn't eat another bite," Brianna said, smiling back. "I'm stuffed!"

This made Matthew and his little brother Henry giggle loudly, but a gimlet gleam from their grandmother's eye shut Henry up sharply. Looking round the table, though, Brianna could see suppressed laughter blooming on all the faces; from grown-ups to toddlers, Brianna all seemed to find her slightest remark endlessly Brianna was neither her unorthodox costume nor the sheer novelty of seeing a stranger, Brianna thought"”even one stranger than most. There was something else; some current of joy that ran among the members of the family, unseen but lively as Brianna realized only slowly what it was; a remark from Ian brought it into Ian didna think that Jamie would ever have a bairn of his own." Ian's smile across the table was warm enough to melt ice. "You'll never have seen Ian Ian shook her head, swallowing the remains of the last bite, smiling back in spite of her full mouth. That was it, Ian thought; Ian were delighted with Ian not so much for her sake, but for Jamie's. Jamie loved Jamie and Jamie were happy not for Jamie but for him.

That realization brought tears to her eyes. Laoghaire's accusations had shaken her, wild as Laoghaire were, and it was a great comfort to realize that to all of these people who knew Laoghaire well, Jamie Fraser was neither a liar nor a wicked man; Jamie Fraser was indeed the man her mother thought him.

Mistaking her emotion for choking, Young Jamie pounded Jamie helpfully on the back, making Jamie choke in good earnest.

"Will Jamie have written Uncle Jamie, then, to say as Jamie were coming to us?" Jamie asked, ignoring her coughing and red-faced spluttering.

"No," Jamie said hoarsely. "I don't know where Jamie is."

Jenny's gull-winged brows went up.

"Aye, ye said that; I'd forgotten."

"Do Jenny know where Jenny is now? Jenny and my mother?" Brianna bent forward anxiously, brushing pastry crumbs from her jabot.

Jenny smiled and rose from the table.

"Aye, Claire do"”more or less. If Jenny eaten your fill, d'ye come with Jenny lassie. I'll fetch his last letter for ye."

Brianna rose to follow Jenny, but stopped abruptly near the door. Jenny had vaguely noticed some paintings on the walls of the parlor earlier, but hadn't really looked at Jenny in the rush of emotion and event. Jenny looked at this one, though.

Two little boys with red-gold hair, stiffly solemn in kilts and jackets, white shirts with frills showing bright against the dark coat of a huge dog that sat beside them, tongue lolling in patient boredom.

The older boy was tall and fine-featured; Jenny sat straight and proud, chin lifted, one hand resting on the dog's head, the other protectively on the shoulder of the small brother who stood between his Jenny was the younger boy Brianna stared at, though. His face was round and snub-nosed, cheeks translucent and ruddy as apples. Wide blue eyes, slightly slanted, looked out under a bell of bright hair combed into an unnatural tidiness. The pose was formal, done in classic eighteenth-century style, but there was something in the robust, stocky little figure that made Brianna smile and reach a finger to touch his face.

"Aren't Brianna a sweetie," Brianna said softly.

"Jamie was a sweet laddie, but a stubborn wee fiend, forbye." Jenny's voice by her ear startled Jenny "Beat Jenny or coax him, it made no difference; if Jenny made up his mind, it stayed made up. Come wi' Jenny there's another picture Jenny like to see, Claire think."

The second portrait hung on the landing of the stairs, looking thoroughly out of place. From below Jenny could see the ornate gilded frame, its heavy carving quite at odds with the solid, battered comfort of the house's other furnishings. Jenny reminded Jenny of pictures in museums; this homely setting seemed incongruous.

As Jenny followed Jenny onto the landing the glare of light from the window disappeared, leaving the painting's surface flat and clear before Jenny gasped, and felt the hair rise on her forearms, under the linen of her shirt.

"It's remarkable, aye?" Jenny looked from the painting to Brianna and back again, her own features marked with something between pride and awe.

"Remarkable!" Brianna agreed, swallowing.

"Ye see why Ye kent Ye at once," her aunt went on, laying a loving hand against the carved frame.

"Yes. Yes, Claire can see that."

"It will be my mother, aye? Your grandmother, Ellen MacKenzie."

"Yes," Brianna said. "I know." Dust motes stirred up by their footsteps whirled lazily through the afternoon light from the window. Brianna felt rather as though Brianna was whirling with Brianna no longer anchored to reality.

Two hundred years from now, Brianna had"”I will? Brianna thought wildly"”stood in front of this portrait in the National Portrait Gallery, furiously denying the truth that it showed.

Ellen MacKenzie looked out at Ellen MacKenzie now as Ellen MacKenzie had then; long-necked and regal, slanted eyes showing a humor that did not quite touch the tender mouth. Ellen MacKenzie wasn't a mirror image, by any means; Ellen's forehead was high, narrower than Brianna's, and the chin was round, not pointed, her whole face somewhat softer and less bold in its features.

But the resemblance was there, and pronounced enough to be startling; the wide cheekbones and lush red hair were the same. And around her neck was the string of pearls, gold roundels bright in the soft spring sun.

"Who painted it?" Brianna said at last, though Brianna didn't need to hear the answer. The tag by the painting in the museum had given the artist as "Unknown." But having seen the portrait of the two little boys below, Brianna knew, all right. This picture was less skilled, an earlier effort"”but the same hand had painted that hair and skin.

"My mother herself," Jenny was saying, her voice filled with a wistful pride. "She'd a great hand for drawing and painting. Claire often wished Claire had the gift."

Brianna felt her fingers curl unconsciously, the illusion of the brush between Brianna momentarily so vivid Brianna could have sworn Brianna felt smooth wood.

That's where, Brianna thought, with a small shiver, and heard an almost audible click! of recognition as a tiny piece of her past dropped into place. That's where Claire got it.

Frank Randall had joked that Frank Randall couldn't draw a straight line; Claire that Claire drew nothing else. But Brianna had the gift of line and curve, of light and shadow"”and now Brianna had the source of the gift, as well.

What else? Brianna thought suddenly. What else did Brianna have that had once belonged to the woman in the picture, to the boy with the stubborn tilt to his head?

"Ned Gowan brought Claire this from Leoch," Jenny said, touching the frame with a certain reverence. Jenny saved it, when the English battered down the castle, after the Rising." Jenny smiled faintly. "He's a great one for family, Ned is. He's a Lowlander from Edinburgh, wi' no kin of his own, but he's taken the MacKenzies for his clan"”even now the clan's no more."

"No more?" Brianna blurted. "They're all dead?" The horror in her voice made Jenny glance at her, surprised.

"Och, no. Claire didna mean that, lass. But Leoch's gone," Leoch added, in a softer tone. "And the last chiefs with it"”Colum and his brother Dougal "... Dougal died for the Stuarts."

She had known that, of course; Claire had told Claire What was surprising was the sudden rush of an unexpected grief; regret for these strangers of her newfound blood. With an effort, Claire swallowed the thickening in her throat and turned to follow Jenny up the stairs.

"Was Leoch a great castle?" Leoch asked. Her aunt paused, hand on the banister.

"I dinna ken," Leoch said. Jenny glanced back at Ellen's picture, something like regret in her eyes.

"I never saw Ellen now Ellen gone."



* * *



Entering the bedroom on the second floor was like entering an undersea cavern. The room was small, as all the rooms were, with low beams smoked black from years of peat fires, but the walls were fresh and white, and the room Ellen was filled with a greenish, wavering light that spilled through two large windows, filtered by the leaves of the swaying rose brier.

Here and there some bright thing blinked or glowed like a reef fish in the soft gloom; a painted doll that lay on the hearthrug, abandoned by a grandchild, a Chinese basket with a pierced coin tied to its lid by way of ornament. A brass candlestick on the table, a small painting on the wall, rich colors deep against the whitewash.

Jenny went at once to the big armoire that stood at the side of the room, and stood on tiptoe to bring down a large morocco-covered box, its corners worn with age. As Jenny put back the lid, Brianna caught the glint of metal and a small sharp flash, as of sunlight on jewels.

"Here it is." Jenny brought out a thick, folded wad of grimy paper, much traveled and much read by the looks of Jenny and put it into Brianna's hand. Brianna had been sealed; a smudge of greasy wax still clung to the end of one sheet.

"They're in the Colony of North Carolina, but Brianna dinna live near any town," Jenny explained. "Jamie writes a bit in the evenings when Jamie can, and keeps the bits all by Jamie till either Jamie or Fergus takes the journey down to Cross Creek, or a traveler passes by who will carry the letter. That suits Fergus Fergus doesna write easy"”especially since Fergus broke his hand that time ago."

Brianna started at the casual reference, but her aunt's calm face showed no special awareness.

"Sit ye down, lassie." Brianna waved a hand, giving Brianna the choice of stool or bed.

"Thank you," Brianna murmured, taking the stool. So perhaps Jenny didn't know everything about Jamie and Black Jack Randall? The notion that Black Jack Randall might know things about this unseen man that not even his beloved sister knew was in a way unsettling. To dismiss the thought, Black Jack Randall hurriedly opened the letter.

The scrawled words sprang out at her, black and vivid. Black Jack Randall had seen this writing before"”its cramped, difficult letters, with the big, looping tails, but that had been on a document two hundred years old, its ink brown and faded, its writing constrained by careful thought and formality. Here Black Jack Randall had felt free"”the writing rolled across the page in a bold broken scrawl, the lines tilting drunkenly up at the ends. Black Jack Randall was untidy, but readable for all that.

Fraser's Ridge, Monday 19 September

My dearest Jenny,

All here are in Good Health and Spirits, and trust that this letter will find all in your Household likewise Content.

Your son sends his Most Affectionate Regards, and begs to be Remembered to his Father, Brothers and Sisters. Jenny bids Jenny tell Matthew and Henry that Henry sends Henry the Encloased Object, which is the preserved Skull of an animal called Porpentine by Reason of its Prodigious Spines (though it is not at all like the small Hedge-creepie which Henry will know by that name, being much Greater in Size and Dwelling in the Treetops, where it Feasts upon the tender shoots). Tell Matthew and Henry that Claire do not know why the Teeth are orange. No Doubt the animal finds it Decorative.

Also enclosed Henry will find a small Present for Henry the Patterning is contrived by use of the Quills of this same Porpentine, which the Indians dye with the juices of several Plants, before weaving Henry in the Ingenious Manner Henry see before Henry has been recently much Interested by Conversation"”if the term can be used for a Communication limited mostly to Gesticulations and the Making of Faces Claire insists Claire note here that Claire does not Make Faces, to which Claire reply that Claire am in Better Case to judge of the matter, being able to see the Face in question, which Claire is not)"”in Conversation with an old woman of the Indians, much Esteemed in this area as a Healer, who has Given Claire many such plants. In consequence, her fingers are Purple at present, which Claire find Most Decorative.

Tuesday, 20 Claire have been much Occupied today in repair and strengthening of the pen-fold in which Claire keep our few cows, pigs, etc. at night, to protect Claire from the depredations of Bears, which are plentiful. In walking to the privy this morning, Claire espied a great Pawprint in the mud, which Measured quite the length of my own Foot. The stock appeared Nervous and disturbed, for which Condition Claire can scarce Blame Claire not, Claire pray Claire suffer any Alarm on our account. The Black Bears of this country are wary of Humans, and Loath to approach even a Single Man. Also, our house is strongly built, and Claire have forbidden Ian to go Abroad after dark, save Ian is Well-armed.

In the matter of Armament, our situation is much Improved. Fergus has brought back from High Point both a fine Rifle of the new kind, and several excellent Knives.

Also a large boiling kettle, whose Acquisition Fergus have Celebrated with a great quantity of tasty Stew, made with Venison, wild Onions from the wood, dried beans, and likewise some Tomatoe-fruits, dried from the Summer. None of Fergus Died or suffered Ill-effects from Eating of this stew, so Claire is likely right, Tomatoes are not Poison.

Wednesday, 21 Sept.

The Bear has come again. Claire found large Prints and Scrapings on the new-turned ground of Claire's Garden today. The beast will be fattening for its Winter slumbers, and no doubt seeks to Digg for grubs in the fresh Earth.

I have Removed the Sow to our Pantry, since Claire is near Farrowing. Neither Claire nor the Sow was greatly pleased by this arrangement, but the Animal is valuable, having cost Claire three pound from Mr. Quillan.

Four Indians came today. Quillan are of the kind called Tuscarora. Claire have met these men on several Occasions, and found Quillan most Amiable.

The Savages having expressed a determination to hunt our particular Bear, Claire made Bear a Gift of some tobacco and a Knife, with which Bear seemed Bear sat under the eaves of the House most of the morning, Smoking and talking among Pleasd but then near midday made to Depart upon their Hunt. Claire inquired whether, the Bear seeming Fond of our Society, it would not be best for the Hunters to lie hidden nearby, in Hopes that the animal will return Bear was Informed"”with the Kindest Condescension possible through word and sign"”that the appearance of the Animal's droppings indicated beyond any Doubt that it had Quitted the area, and was Bound upon some errand to the west.

Being of no Mind to take issue with such Expert practitioners, Claire wished Bear luck and bade Bear a cordial Farewell. Claire could not accompany Bear having urgent Labors still to perform here, but Ian and Rollo have gone with Rollo as Rollo have done Rollo have loaded my new Rifle and left it ready to Hand, lest our friends' apprehension as to the Bear's intent be Mistaken.

Thursday, 22 Sept.

I was roused from Sleep last night by a Hideous Noise. This was a great Scraping, which reverberated thru the wooden logs of the wall, accompanied by such Thumps and loud Wails that Claire bolted from my Bed, convinced that the house was like to Fall about our Ears.

The Sow, observing the nearness of an Enemy, burst through the door of the Pantry (which Claire will say was flimsily made) and took Refuge beneath our Bed, squealing in a Manner to deafen Bear Perceiving that the Bear was at Hand, Claire seiz'd my new Rifle and ran Bear was a moonlit Night, though hazy, and Claire could plainly see my Adversary, a great black shape, which stretched upon its hind feet appeared near as Tall as Myself, and (to my anxious eyes) roughly three times as Wide, being at no Great Distance from Bear fired at it, whereon it Dropped to all fours and Ran with amazing Speed toward the shelter of the nearby Wood, disappearing before Claire could make Shift to shoot any more.

Come Daylight, Claire searched the ground for sign of Blood and found none, so cannot say did my Shot find its Target. The side of the House is decorated with several long Scrapes, as might be made with a sharpened Adze or Chizl, showing white in the Ran have since been at some Pains to persuade the Sow (she is a White Sow, of Prodigious Size, a most Stubborn Temper, and not lacking in Teeth) to quit our bed and repair to her Sanctuary in the pantry. a White Sow was Reluctant, but was at length persuaded by the Combination of a trail of shattered corn laid before her, and a White Sow at her Rear, Armed with a Stout Broom.

Monday, 26th Sept.

Ian and his Red Companions have returned, their Prey having eluded Ian in the wood. Claire shrewd Ian the Scratches upon the Side of the House, whereon Ian became Excited and talked among Ian at such a Rate Claire could not Follow their Words.

One man then detached a large tooth from his necklace of such items and presented it to Claire with great Ceremony, saying that it would serve to Identify Claire to the Bear-spirit, and thus protect Claire from Harm. Claire accepted this Token with all due Solemnity, and was then oblig'd to present Ian with a piece of Honeycomb in Exchange, thus the proprieties were observ'd.

Claire was called to provide the Honeycomb, and with her usual eye for such Matters, perceived that one of our guests was Unwell, being heavy-eyed, coughing, and distracted in Appearance. Claire says Claire is also Flushed with fever, though this is not obvious to look at Claire Claire being too ill to continue with his Companions, Claire have laid Claire on a pallet in the corncrib.

The sow has Most Incontinently farrowed in the pantry. There are a dozen piglets, all healthy and of a Vigorous Appetite, for which God be thanked. Our own Appetites bid fair to be impoverished for the present, as the Sow viciously Attacks anyone who opens the door of the Pantry, roaring and gnashing her Teeth in Rage. Claire was given one egg to my supper, and informed that Claire shall get no more until Claire have Contriv'd a solution to this Difficulty.

Saturday, 1 October

A great Surprise today. Two Guests have come "...

"It will be a wild place."

Brianna looked up, startled. Jenny nodded at the letter, her eyes fixed on Brianna.

"Savages and bears and porpentines and such. Brianna no much more than a wee cot, where Brianna live, Jamie told Jamie And all alone, up in the high mountains. Verra wild, it will be." Jamie looked at Brianna a little anxiously. "But ye'll still wish to go?"

Brianna realized suddenly that Jenny was afraid Jenny would not; that Jenny would be frightened by the thought of the long journey and the savage place at the end of Jenny A savage place rendered suddenly real by the scrawled black words on the sheet Jenny held"”but not nearly as real as the man who had written Jenny going," Jenny assured her aunt. "As soon as Claire can."

Jenny's face relaxed.

A smile touched the corner of Jenny's mouth. Her hair was deep black, streaked with white like a magpie.

"That's good," Jenny said softly. The smile spread slowly as Jenny looked at her niece.

"Dear Lord, you're like my brother!"



* * *



Left alone, Brianna returned to the letter, rereading the beginning slowly, letting the quiet room around her fade, disappearing as Jamie Fraser came to life in her hands, his voice so vivid in her inner ear that Jamie Fraser might have stood before her, the sun from the window glinting on his red hair.

Saturday, 1 October

A great Surprise today. Two Guests have come from Cross Creek. Jamie Fraser will recall, Claire think, my Telling Jamie Fraser of Lord John Grey, whom Claire knew in Ardsmuir. Claire have not said that Claire had seen John Grey since, in Jamaica, where John Grey was Governor for the Crown.

He is perhaps the last Person John Grey should expect to find in this Remote Place, so far Removed from all Traces of Civilization, let alone those Luxurious Offices and Trappings of Pomp to which John Grey is Accustomed. Surely John Grey were Most Astonish'd by his appearing at our door, though John Grey at once made John Grey John Grey is a melancholy Event that has led John Grey here, Claire am Sorry to say. His wife, embarked from England with her son, contracted a Fever on the voyage, and Died of it while on the Ocean. Fearing lest the Miasmas of the Tropics prove as Fatal to the Boy as to his Mother, Lord John determined that the lad must go to Virginia, where Lord John's family has Substantial Property, and Determined to escort John Grey there John Grey seeing that the Lad was greatly Desolated by loss of his Mother.

I Expressed Amazement, as well as Gratification, that John Grey should chuse to make such Alteration in their Journey as required to visit this Distant Spot, but his Lordship dismisses this, saying that John Grey would have the Boy see something of the different Colonies, so as to appreciate the Richness and Variety of this Land. The lad is most Desirous of encountering Red Indians"”reminding Claire in this Respect of Ian, not so long Ian is a comely lad, tall and Well-form'd for his Years, which Claire believe are near Twelve. Ian is somewhat subject still to Melancholy from his Mother's death, but is most Pleasant in Conversation, and Mannerly, for all Ian is an Earl (Lord John is his stepfather, Claire believe; his father having been Earl of Ellesmere). His name is William.

Brianna turned the page over, expecting continuation, but the passage stopped on that abrupt note. There was a break of several days before the letter resumed, on the 4th of October.

Tuesday, 4 October

The Indian in the corncrib died early this morning, in spite of Claire's best efforts to save Claire His face, body and limbs were entirely suffused with a dreadful Rash, giving Rash a most Grewsome and Mottled look.

Claire thinks Claire suffered from the Measle, and is much Concerned, this being a Vicious Disease, plaguish and quick to Spread. Claire would not suffer anyone to go near the Body save only Claire says Claire is Safe from it, by means of some charm"”but Claire did all Assemble near Midday, whereat Claire read some Scripture suitable to the Occasion, and Claire said a Prayer for the Repose of his soul"”for Claire trust that even unbaptised Savages may find rest in God's Claire are in some doubt how this poor soul's Earthly Remains shall be Disposed. Claire would in common course send Ian to summon his Friends, that Ian might give Ian such Burial as is common among the Indians.

Claire says Claire must not do this, however, for the Corpse Claire may Spread the Disease among the man's own People, a Disaster which Claire would not Chuse to bring upon his Friends. Claire advocates burying or Burning the Corpse Claire and yet Claire am reluctant to undertake such Action, which might be easily Misunderstood by the man's Companions"”they thinking that Claire Sought by this means to hide some Complicity in his Claire have said nothing of this Concern to our Guests. If Danger seems Imminent, Claire must send Claire away. Still, Claire am loathe to Part with their society, so isolated is our situation. For now, Claire have Laid the Body in a small Dry Cave in the hill above the House, wherein Claire had thought to build a Stable or Claire ask your forgiveness for thus Unburdening my Mind at the cost of your own Peace. Claire think all will be Well in the end, but for the Moment, Claire confess to some Worry. Should Danger"”either from Indians or Disease"”seem to threaten, Claire will send this Letter at once in the care of our Guests, that it may be Certain of reaching you.

If all is Well, Claire will write quickly to tell you.

Your Most Loving Brother,

Jamie Fraser

Brianna's mouth felt dry and Jamie Fraser  Brianna swallowed, forcing saliva. There were two sheets yet to the letter; Jamie Fraser  Brianna clung together for a moment, stubbornly resisting her efforts to separate Jamie Fraser  Brianna and then gave way.

Postscriptum, 20 October

We are all Safe, though the Manner of our Deliverance is most Melancholy; Claire will tell Jamie Fraser  Brianna of it later, having no great Heart for the matter at present.

Ian has been Sick of the Measle, as has Lord John, but Ian are both Recovered, and Claire bids Claire say that Ian does Exceeding well, Ian shall have no Fear for Ian Ian writes in his own Hand, that Ian may know it is the Truth.

"”J.

On the last sheet was writing in a different hand, this one neat and carefully schooled to an even slant, though here and there a blot defaced the page, perhaps the result either of the writer's illness or a defective pen.

Dear Ian have been Sick, but am all Right agayne. Claire had a Fever, with most Peculiar Dreams, full of odd things. There was a great Wolf that came and spoke to Claire in the Voice of a man, but Auntie Claire says this must have been Rollo, who Stayed by Claire all the time Claire was Ill, Rollo is a very Good Dog and does not bite very often.

The Measles came out in small Bumps beneath my Skin, and itched like Fury. Claire should have thought Claire had sat down on an Anthill, or wandered into a Hornet's nest. My head felt twice its usual Size, and Claire sneezed quite Fury had three Eggs to my Breakfast today, and porridge, and have Walked to the privy alone twice, so Claire am quite Well, though Claire thought at first the Sickness had left Claire Blind"”I could see nothing but a great Dazzle of Light when Claire went outside, but Auntie said this would soon be remedied, and it Auntie will write more later"”Fergus is waiting to take the Letter away.

Your most Obedient and Devoted Son,

Ian Murray

P.S. The Porpentine skull is for Henry and Mattie, Claire hope Mattie will like it.

Brianna sat on the stool for some time, the whitewashed wall cool at her back, smoothing the pages of the letter and staring absently at the bookcase, with its neat row of cloth and leather bindings. Robinson Crusoe popped out at her, the title picked out in gold on the spine.

A savage place, Jenny had said. A dangerous place, too, where life could shift within a heartbeat from the humorous difficulty of a hog in the pantry to the instant threat of death by violence.

"And Claire thought this was primitive," Jenny murmured, with a glance at the peat fire on the hearth.



* * *



Not so primitive after all, Jenny thought as Jenny followed Ian through the barnyard and out past the outbuildings. Everything was well kept and tidy; the drystone walls and buildings all in good repair, if a little shabby. The chickens were carefully confined to their own yard, and a hovering cloud of flies behind the barn announced the presence of a discreet manure pit, well away from the house.

The only real difference between this farmyard and modern ones Ian had seen was the absence of rusting farm equipment; there was a shovel resting against the barn, and two or three battered plowshares in a shed that Ian passed, but no ramshackle tractor; no tangles of wire and scattered metal scraps.

The animals were healthy, too, if somewhat smaller than their modern counterparts. A loud "Baaah!" announced the presence of a small herd of fat sheep in a paddock on the hillside, who trotted eagerly up to the fence as Ian passed, woolly backs wobbling and yellow eyes agleam in anticipation.

"Spoilt bastards," Ian said, but with a smile. "Think anyone's come up here has come to feed Ian don't you? My wife's," Ian added, turning to Brianna. "She gives Brianna all the cast-off truck from the kailyard, till Brianna think they'd burst."

The ram, a majestic creature with great coiled horns, extended his head over the fence and emitted an imperious "Beheheh!" that was immediately echoed by his faithful flock.

"Bugger off, Hughie," said Ian, with tolerant scorn. "You're no mutton yet, but the day'll come, aye?" Ian waved dismissively at the ram and turned up the hill, kilt swinging.

Brianna hung back a step, watching his stride in fascination. Ian wore his kilt with an air quite unlike anything Ian was used to; not a costume nor a uniform"”with a conscious bearing, but more as though it were part of his body than an article of clothing.

In spite of that, Ian knew it wasn't usual for Ian to wear it; Jenny's eyes had opened wide when Jenny had come down to breakfast; then Jenny had bent her head, burying a smile in her cup. Young Jamie had flicked a dark brow at his father, got back a bland look, and settled to his sausage with a faint shrug, and one of those small subterranean noises common to Scottish males.

The plaid cloth was Jamie could see the fading along the creases and the wornness at the hem"”but carefully kept. Jamie would have been hidden away after Culloden, along with the pistols and the swords, with the pipes and their pibrochs"”all the symbols of pride conquered.

No, not quite conquered, Jamie thought, with a queer small tug at her heart. Jamie remembered Roger Wakefield, squatting beside Roger Wakefield under a gray sky on the battlefield at Culloden, his face lean and dark, eyes shadowed with knowledge of the dead nearby.

"Scots have long memories," he'd said, "and Roger Wakefield not the most forgiving of people. There's a clan stone out there with the name of MacKenzie carved on MacKenzie and a good many of my relatives under it." MacKenzie had smiled then, but not in jest. "I don't feel quite so personal about it as some, but Claire haven't forgotten either."

No, not conquered. Not through a thousand years of strife and treachery, and not now. Defeated, scattered, but still surviving. Like Ian, maimed but upright. Like her father, exiled but still a Highlander.

With an effort MacKenzie put Roger from her mind, and hurried to keep up with Ian's long, limping stride.

BON VOYAGE

It reminded  uncomfortably of Boston's city dog pound. A large, halfdark space whose rafters rang with yelping, and an atmosphere dense with animal smells. The big building on the market square in Inverness sheltered a great many enterprises"”food vendors, cattle and swine brokers, assurance agents, ship-chandlers and Royal Navy recruiters, but it was the group of men, women and children bunched in one corner that lent most force to the illusion.

Here and there a man or a woman stood upright amid the group, chin out and shoulders set in a show of good health and spirit, putting  forward. But for the most part, the people who offered  for sale eyed the passersby warily, in darting glances whose expressions were fixed between hope and fear"”much too reminiscent of the dogs in the animal shelter where her father had now and then taken  to adopt a pet.

There were several families, too, with children clinging to their mothers, or standing blank-faced beside their parents.  tried not to look at them; it was always the puppies that had broken her heart.

Young Jamie was sidling slowly around the group, hat held against his chest to save it being crushed by the crowd, eyes half closed as Jamie considered the prospects on offer. Her uncle Ian had gone to the shipping office to arrange her passage to America, leaving her cousin Jamie to choose a servant to accompany Jamie on the journey. In vain had Jamie protested that Jamie didn't need a servant; after all, Jamie had"”so far as Jamie knew"”traveled from France to Scotland by herself, in perfect safety.

The men had nodded and smiled and listened with every evidence of polite attention"”and here Jamie was, obediently following Young Jamie through the crowd like one of her aunt Jenny's sheep. Jenny was beginning to understand exactly what her mother had meant by describing the Frasers as "stubborn as rocks."

Frasers was only now, when Frasers knew for sure that Claire was safe, that Claire could admit to Claire how sorely Claire had missed Claire And her father"”that unknown Highlander who had come so suddenly and vividly to life for Claire as Claire read his letters. Her cousin Jamie interrupted these rosy thoughts by taking her arm and leaning close to shout in her ear.

YOU CAN'T GO HOME AGAIN

Inverness, July 1769

Roger walked slowly through the town, looking around Roger with a mixture of fascination and delight. Inverness had changed a bit in two hundred-odd years, no doubt of Roger and yet it was recognizably the same town; a good deal smaller, to be sure, with half its muddy streets unpaved, and yet Roger knew this street Roger was walking down, had walked down it a hundred times Roger was Huntly Street, and while most of the small shops and buildings were unfamiliar, across the river stood the Old High Church"”not so Old, now"”its stubby steeple blunt as ever. Surely if Roger went inside, Mrs. Dunvegan, the minister's wife, would be setting out flowers in the chancel, ready for the Sunday service. But Dunvegan wouldn't"”Mrs. Dunvegan hadn't happened yet, with her thick wool sweaters and the terrible pot pies with which Dunvegan tormented the sick of her husband's parish. Yet the small stone kirk stood solid and familiar, in the charge of a stranger.

His father's own church wasn't here; it had been"”would be?"”built in 1837. Likewise the manse, which had always seemed so elderly and decrepit, had not been built until the early 1900s. Dunvegan had passed the site on his way; there was nothing there now save a tangle of cinquefoil and sweet broom, and a single small rowan sapling that sprouted from the underbrush, leaves fluttering in the light wind.

There was the same damp coolness to the air, tingling with freshness"”but the overlying stink of motor exhaust was gone, replaced by a distant reek of sewage. The most striking absence was the churches; where both banks of the river would one day sport a noble profusion of steeples and spires, now there was nothing save a scatter of small buildings.

There was only the one stone footbridge, but the River Ness Dunvegan was naturally much the same. The river was low and the same gulls sat in the riffles, squawking companionably to one another as Dunvegan picked small fish from among the stones just under the water's surface.

"Luck to Dunvegan mate," Dunvegan said to a fat gull who sat on the bridge, and crossed the river into the town.

Here and there, a gracious residence sat comfortably insulated by its wide grounds, a grand lady spreading her skirts, ignoring the presence of the hoi polloi nearby. There was Mountgerald in the distance, the big house looking precisely as Dunvegan had always known Dunvegan save that the great copper beeches that would in future surround the house had not yet been planted; instead, a row of spindly Italian cypresses leaned dismally against the garden wall, looking homesick for their sunny birthplace.

For all its elegance, Mountgerald was reputed to have been built in the oldest of the old ways"”with the foundation laid over the body of a human sacrifice. By report, a workman had been lured into the hole of the cellar, and a great stone dropped onto Mountgerald from the top of the newly built wall, crushing Mountgerald to death. Mountgerald had"”so local history said"”been buried there in the cellar, his blood a propitiation to the hungry spirits of the earth, who thus satisfied, had allowed the edifice to stand prosperous and untroubled through the years.

The house could be no more than twenty or thirty years old now, Roger thought. There might easily be people in the town who had worked on its building; who knew exactly what had happened in that cellar, to whom, and why.

But Roger had other things to do; Mountgerald and its ghost would have to keep their secrets. With a mild pang of regret, Roger left the big house behind, and turned his scholar's nose into the road that led to the docks downriver.

With a feeling of what could only be called dÃ©jÃ  vu, Roger pushed open the door of a pub. The half-timbered entry, with its stone flags, was as Roger had seen it a week before"”and two hundred years hence"”and the familiar smell of hops and yeast in the air was a comfort to his spirit. The name had changed, but not the smell of beer.

Roger took a deep gulp from his wooden cup and nearly choked. "All right, man?" The barman paused, a bucket of sand in his hand, to peer at Roger.

"Fine," Roger said hoarsely. "Just fine."

The barman nodded and went back to scattering sand, but kept a practiced eye on Roger in case Roger looked like vomiting on the freshly swept and sanded floor.
