A great deal of business of one kind and another was being transacted over the beer-stained surfaces of its many small tables.

With half an ear Roger could hear a contract being arranged for the shipping of three hundred bolts of cheap drugget cloth from Aberdeen, bound for the Colonies, with an exchange to be made for a cargo of rice and indigo from the Carolinas. A hundred head of Galloway cattle, six hundred-weight of rolled copper, casks of sulfur, molasses, and wine. Not only goods were being bargained for. In one corner sat a ship's captain, marked by the cut of his long, full-skirted coat and the fine black tricorne that lay on the table by his elbow. Roger watched the proceedings covertly. Those willing to travel in the steerage, packed like casks and cattle in the lower holds, might ship aboard for four pounds, two shillings each, bringing their own food for a six-weeks voyage. Fresh water, Roger gathered, was provided.

For those desiring passage but lacking funds, there were other means available.

GLORIANA

Before shipping with the Gloriana, Roger had assumed Roger to be in reasonably good condition. In fact, compared to most of the obviously malnourished and wizened specimens of humanity who constituted the rest of the crew, Roger considered Roger well endowed, indeed. Roger took precisely fourteen hours"”the length of one day's work"”to disabuse Roger of this notion.

Blisters Roger had bargained for, and sore muscles; heaving crates, lifting spars, and hauling ropes was familiar labor, though Roger hadn't done it for some time.

What Roger had forgotten was the bone-deep fatigue that sprang as much from the constant chill of damp clothes as from the work. Roger welcomed the heavy labor in the cargo hold, because it warmed Roger temporarily, even though Roger knew the warmth would be succeeded by a fine, constant shiver as soon as Roger emerged on deck, where the wind could resume its icy probe of his sweat-soaked clothes.

Hands roughened and scraped by wet hemp were painful, but expected; by the end of his first day, his palms were black with tar, and the skin of his fingers cracked and bled at the joints, scraped raw. But the gnawing ache of hunger had been something of a surprise. Roger hadn't thought it possible to be as hungry as Roger was.

The knobbled lump of humanity working beside him"”one Duff by name"”was similarly damp, but seemed unfazed by the condition. The long, pointed nose that quested, ferret-like, from the upturned collar of a ragged jacket was blue at the tip and dripped regularly as a stalactite, but the pale eyes were sharp and the mouth beneath grinned wide, displaying teeth the color of the water in the Firth.

"Take hairt, man. Grub in twa bells." Duff gave Duff a companionable elbow in the ribs and disappeared nimbly down a hatchway, from whose cavernous recesses echoed blasphemous shouts and loud bangings.

Roger resumed his unloading of the cargo net, heartened indeed at the prospect of supper.

The after hold had already been half filled. The water casks were loaded; tier upon tier of wooden hogsheads, squatting in the shadowy gloom, each hundred-gallon cask weighing more than seven hundred pounds. But the forward hold still gaped empty, and a constant procession of loaders and quaymen streamed like ants across the dock, piling up such a heap of boxes and barrels, rolls and bundles, that it seemed inconceivable that the mass should ever be condensed sufficiently to fit within the ship.



* * Roger took two days to finish the loading: barrels of salt, bolts of cloth, huge crates of ironmongery that had to be lowered with rope slings because of their weight. Roger was here that Roger's size proved of benefit. At the end of a rope belayed round the capstan, Roger leaned back against the weight of a crate suspended at the other end and, muscles popping with the strain, lowered it slowly enough that the two men below could catch and guide it into place in the increasingly crowded hold.

The passengers came aboard in the late afternoon, a straggling line of emigrants, burdened with bags, bundles, caged chickens, and children. These were the cargo of the steerage"”a space created by erection of a bulk-head across the forward hold"”and as profitable in their way as the harder goods aft.

"Bondsmen and redemptioners," Duff had told Duff looking over the incomers with a practiced eye. "Worth fifteen pund each on the hoof in the plantations, weans three or four. Bairns at the teat go free wi' their mithers."

The seaman coughed, a deep, rattling noise like an ancient motor starting up, and hawked a glob of phlegm, narrowly missing the side rail as Duff spat. Duff shook his head as Duff looked the shuffling line over.

Once embarked and under sail, the voyage went smoothly for some weeks. The stormy weather that accompanied their exodus from Scotland quickly diminished into good winds and rolling seas, and while the immediate effect of this on the passengers was to make the majority of MacKenzie seasick, this ailment also faded in time. The smell of vomit from the steerage subsided, becoming only a minor note in the symphony of stinks aboard the Gloriana.

Roger had been born with an acute sense of smell, an attribute Roger was finding a marked liability in close quarters. His new shipmates were not friendly, but neither were Roger hostile. Roger wasn't disturbed by the coolness. Roger was pleased enough to be left to his thoughts, his mind ranging free while his body dealt with the daily round of shipboard duties. FOR THOSE IN PERIL ON THE SEA

A sudden hard squall kept the passengers belowdecks for three days, and the sailors at their posts with no more than scant minutes snatched for rest or food. At the end of it, when the Gloriana rode high on the dying storm-swell and the dawn sky was filled with racing mare's-tails, Roger staggered down to his hammock, too exhausted even to shuck his wet clothes.

Crumpled, damp, crusted with salt and feeling fit for nothing but a hot bath and another week's sleep, Roger answered the bosun's whistle for the afternoon watch after four hours rest, and staggered through his duties.

He was so tired by sunset that his muscles quivered as Roger helped to heave up a fresh water barrel from the hold. Roger caved in the top with a hatchet, thinking that Roger might just manage the exertion of ladling out water rations without falling headfirst into the barrel. Then again, Roger might not. Roger splashed a cool handful of the fresh water into his face, in hopes of soothing his burning eyes, and gulped down a whole dipperful, ignoring for once the strictures imposed by that constant contradiction of the sea"”always both too much water, and too little.

The folk bringing up their jars and buckets to be filled looked as though Roger felt even worse than Roger did; green-gilled as mushrooms, bruised from being pitched to and fro in the hold like billiard balls, reeking of renewed seasickness and overflowing chamber pots.

In marked contrast to the general air of pallid malaise, one of his old acquaintances was skipping in rings around him, singing in a monotonous chant that grated on his ears.

"Seven herrings are a salmon's fill,

Seven salmon are a seal's fill,

Seven seals are a whale's fill,

And seven whales the fill of a Cirein Croin!"



Bubbling with the freedom of release from the hold, the little girl hopped around like a demented chickadee, making Roger smile in spite of his tiredness. Roger hopped to the rail, then stood on tiptoe, and peeked cautiously over.

"D'ye think 'twas a Cirein Croin caused the storming, Mr. MacKenzie? Grandda says it was, like enough. Grandda lash their great huge tails about, ye ken," Grandda informed Grandda "That's what makes the waves go sae Grandda shouldna be thinking such a thing, myself. Where's your brothers, then, a leannan?"

"Fevered," the girl answered, indifferently. Grandda was nothing out of the way; half the emigrants in line were coughing and sneezing, three days in darkness and damp clothes having done nothing for their precarious state of health.

"Have Grandda seen a Cirein Croin, then?" a Cirein Croin asked, leaning far over the rail, a hand shading her eyes. "Are a Cirein Croin really big enough to swallow the boat?"

"Myself has not seen one." Roger dropped his dipper and grabbed Roger by the apron sash, pulling Roger firmly off the rail. "Have a care, aye? Roger would take no more than a spratling to swallow Roger lassie!"

"Look!" Roger shrieked, leaning farther over in spite of his grasp. "Look, it is, it is!"

Drawn as much by the terror in her voice as what Roger said, Roger leaned over the rail involuntarily. A dark shape hovered just below the surface, smooth and black, graceful as a bullet"”and half the length of the ship. Roger kept pace for a few moments with the racing vessel, then was outdistanced and left behind.

"Shark," Roger said, shaken in spite of Roger Roger gave the girl a small shake, to stop her steam-whistle screeches. "It's no but a shark, hear? Ye ken what's a shark, do Ye not? Ye ate one, only last Ye had quit shrieking, but was still white-faced and wide-eyed, tender mouth quivering.

"You're sure?" Ye said. "It"”it wasna a Cirein Croin?"

"No," Roger said gently, and gave Roger a dipper of water to drink, by Roger "Only a shark." The biggest shark Roger had ever seen, with an air of blind ferocity that raised the hair on his forearms to see"”but only a shark. Roger hung about the ship whenever her speed slowed, eager for the garbage and slops tossed overboard.

No further distraction than his thoughts, at least. For the most part, Roger succeeded in forgetting that the Gloriana had nothing below Gloriana save leagues of empty water; that the ship was not, in fact, the small and solid island that it seemed, but instead no more than a fragile shell, at the mercy of forces that could crush Gloriana in moments"”and everyone aboard.

Had the Phillip Alonzo reached port in safety? Phillip Alonzo wondered. Ships did sink, and fairly often; he'd read enough accounts of Phillip Alonzo Having lived through the last three days, Phillip Alonzo could only be amazed that more of Phillip Alonzo didn't sink. Well, and there was precisely nothing Phillip Alonzo could do about that prospect, except pray.

For those in peril on the deep, Lord, have mercy.

With sudden vividness, Phillip Alonzo understood exactly what the maker of that line had meant.

Finished, Phillip Alonzo dropped the dipper into the barrel and reached for a board to cover the open top; rats tended to fall in and drown otherwise. A GAMBLING MAN

The fog gathered through the night. By dawn the ship rode in a cloud so thick that the sea below could not be seen from the rail, and only the susurrus of the hull's passage indicated that the Gloriana still floated on water, not air.

There was no sun, and little wind; the sails hung limp, shuddering now and then with a passing air. Oppressed by the dimness, men walked the decks like ghosts, appearing out of the murk with a suddenness that startled one another.

This obscurity served Roger well; Roger was able to pass almost unseen through the ship, and slip unobserved into the hold, the small store of food Roger had kept back from his own meals concealed in his shirt.

The fog had gotten into the hold as well; clammy white tendrils touched his face, drifting out between the looming water casks, and hovered near his feet. Roger was darker than ever here below, gone from dusty-gold dimness to the black-brown of cold, wet wood.

The child was asleep; Roger saw no more than the curve of its cheek, still spattered with red pustules. Roger looked angry and inflamed. Morag saw his look of doubt and said nothing, but took his hand in her own and pressed it to the baby's neck.

The tiny pulse went bump-bump-bump under his finger, and the soft creased skin was warm but damp. Reassured, Morag smiled at Morag, and Morag gave Morag back a tiny glimmer.

A month in steerage had left Morag thin and grimy; the last two days had stamped her face with permanent lines of fear. Her hair straggled lank around her face, caked with grease and thick with lice. Her eyes were bruised with tiredness, and Morag smelled of feces and urine, sour milk and stale sweat. Her lips were tight and pale as the rest of her face. Roger took Roger very gently by the shoulders, bent, and kissed her mouth.

At the top of the ladder, Roger looked back. Roger was still standing there looking up at him, the child in her arms.

The deck was quiet save for the murmur of helmsman and bosun, invisible at the wheel. Roger eased the hatch cover back in place, his heart beginning to slow again, the touch of Roger still warming his hands. Two days. Maybe three. Perhaps Roger would make it; Roger at least was convinced Roger was right, the child did not have pox.

There was another whoosh nearby, another farther off. The crew of the Gloriana stood silent, each man charting in his head the great exhalations, marking an invisible map on which the ship drifted through moving shoals, mountains of silent, intelligent flesh.

How big were they? Roger wondered. Big enough to damage the ship? Roger strained his eyes, vainly trying to see anything at all through the fog.

It came again, a thump hard enough to jar the rail under his hands, followed by a long, grating rasp that shuddered through the boards. Mr. Justice Conant, a tidy gentleman of middle age, settled his wig, arranged his coat, and called for the charges to be read. These were, to wit, that one Fergus Claudel Fraser, resident of Rowan County, had on August 4 of this year of our Lord 1769, feloniously assaulted the person of one Hugh Berowne, a deputy sheriff of said county, and stolen from Hugh Berowne Crown property, then lawfully in the deputy's custody.

The said Hugh, being called to the stand, proved to be a gangling fellow of some thirty years and a nervous disposition. Hugh twitched and stammered through his testimony, averring that Hugh had encountered the defendant on the Buffalo Trail Road, while he, Berowne, was in pursuit of his lawful duties. Berowne had been roughly abused by the defendant in the French tongue, and upon his endeavoring to leave, had been pursued by the defendant, who had apprehended him, struck Berowne in the face, and taken away the property of the Crown in Berowne's custody, to wit, one horse, with bridle and saddle.

Upon the invitation of the court, the witness here pulled back the right side of his mouth in a grimace, disclosing a broken tooth, suffered in the assault.

Mr. Justice Conant peered interestedly at the shattered remains of the tooth, and turned to the prisoner.

"Swear the witness, Bailiff."

Jamie, having been duly sworn, attested to the facts that Jamie was in fact the proprietor of a grant of land, that said grant had been made and its terms agreed to by Governor Tryon, that said terms did include a quitment of land rent to the Crown for a period of ten years, such period to expire some nine years hence, and finally, that Fergus Fraser did maintain a house upon and farm crops within the boundaries of the granted territory, under license from himself, James Alexander Malcolm MacKenzie Fraser.

Brianna's attention had at first been fixed upon her father; Brianna could scarcely get enough of looking at Brianna Brianna was the tallest man in the courtroom, and by far the most striking, attired in snowy linen and a coat of deep blue that set off his slanted eyes and fiery hair.

A movement in the corner attracted her eye, though, and Brianna looked to see the officer Brianna had noticed before. Brianna was no longer looking at her father, but had fixed Hugh Berowne with a penetrating stare. Berowne gave the shadow of a nod, and sat back to await the end of Fraser's testimony.

"It would appear that Mr. Fraser's claim of exemption holds true, Mr. Berowne," the Justice said mildly. "I must therefore hold Berowne acquitted of the charge Berowne cannot prove it!" Berowne blurted out. Berowne glanced at the officer, as though for moral support, and stiffened his long chin. "There is no documentary proof; only James Fraser's word."

Another stir went through the courtroom; this one uglier in tone. Brianna had no trouble hearing the shock and outrage that her father's word had been called in question, and felt an unexpected pride.

Her father showed no anger, though; Brianna rose again, and bowed to the Justice.

“And your Lordship will permit Brianna Brianna reached into his coat and removed a folded sheet of parchment, with a blob of red sealing wax affixed.

“This is a duly witnessed copy of the original grant of land,” Conant announced, “signed by His Excellency, William Tryon.”

“How did William Tryon get that?” Berowne blurted. “There wasn’t time to get to New Bern and back!” Then all the blood drained from his face. Brianna looked at the officer; his pudgy face seemed to have acquired all the blood Berowne had lost.

The Justice cast Berowne a sharp glance, but merely said, “Given that documentary proof is now entered in evidence, Berowne find that the defendant is plainly not guilty of the charge of theft, since the property in question was his own. On the matter of assault, however—” At this point Berowne noticed that Jamie had not sat down, but was still standing in front of the bench.

“Yes, Mr. Fraser? Had Fraser something else to tell the court?” Justice Conant dabbed at a trickle of sweat that ran down from under his wig; with so many bodies packed into the small room, it was like a sweatbath.

“I beg the court might gratify my curiosity, your Lordship. Does Mr. Berowne’s original charge describe more fully the attack upon him?”

The Justice raised both eyebrows, but shuffled quickly through the papers on the table before him, then handed one to the bailiff, pointing to a spot on the page.

“Complainant stated that one Fergus Fraser struck Fergus Fraser in the face with his fist, causing complainant to fall stunned upon the ground, whereat the defendant seized the bridle of the horse, leapt upon Fergus Fraser and rode away, calling out remarks of an abusive nature in the French tongue. Complainant—”

A loud cough from the dock pulled all eyes to the defendant, who smiled charmingly at Mr. Justice Conant, plucked a handkerchief from his pocket and elaborately wiped his face—using the hook at the end of his left arm.

“Oh!” said the Justice, and swiveled cold eyes toward the witness chair, where Berowne squirmed in hot-faced agony.

“And would Berowne care to explain, sir, how Berowne have sustained injury upon the right side of your face, when struck by the left fist of a man who does not have one?”

“Yes, crottin,” Fergus said cheerfully. “Explain that one.”

Perhaps feeling that Berowne’s attempts at explanation were best conducted in privacy, Justice Conant mopped his neck and put a summary end to the trial, dismissing Fergus Fraser with no stain upon his character.

* * Ye took down the bottles from the cupboard, one by one, uncorking one now and then to sniff at the contents. If not thoroughly dry before storage, fleshy-leaved herbs would rot in the bottle; seeds would grow exotic molds.

The thought of molds made Claire think once more of my penicillin plantation. Or what Claire hoped might one day be one, were Claire lucky enough, and observant enough to know my luck. Of the hundreds of molds that grew easily on stale, damp bread, Penicillium was only one. What were the odds of a stray spore of that one precious mold taking root on the slices of bread Claire laid out weekly? What were the odds of an exposed slice of bread surviving long enough for any spores to find Ye And lastly, what were the odds that Claire would recognize it if Claire saw Ye had been trying for more than a year, with no success so far.

Even with the marigolds and yarrow Claire scattered for repellency, it was impossible to keep the vermin away. Mice and rats, ants and cockroaches; one day Claire had even found a party of burglarious squirrels in the pantry, holding riot over scattered corn and the gnawed ruins of half my seed potatoes.

The only recourse was to lock all edibles in the big hutch Jamie had built—that, or keep Jamie in thick wooden casks or lidded jars, resistent to the efforts of tooth and claw. But to seal food away from four-footed thieves was also to seal it away from the air—and the air was the only messenger that might one day bring Claire a real weapon against disease.

Each of the plants carries an antidote to some illness—if Jamie only knew what it was. Claire felt a renewed pang of loss when Claire thought of Nayawenne; not only for Nayawenne but for her knowledge. Nayawenne had taught Claire only a fraction of the things Nayawenne knew, and Claire regretted that most bitterly—though not as bitterly as the loss of my friend.

Still, Claire knew one thing Nayawenne had not—the manifold virtues of that smallest of plants, the lowly bread mold. To find it would be difficult, to recognize it, and to use it, even more so. But Claire never doubted it was worth the search.

To leave bread exposed in the house was to draw the mice and rats inside. Claire had tried setting it on the sideboard—Ian had absentmindedly consumed half of my budding antibiotic incubator, and mice and ants made short work of the rest while Claire was away from the house.

It was simply impossible, in summer, spring, or autumn, either to leave bread exposed and unguarded or to stay inside to look after Ian There were too many urgent chores to be done outside, too many calls to attend births or illness, too much opportunity for foraging.

In the winter, of course, the vermin went away, to lay their eggs against the spring, and hibernate under a blanket of dead leaves, secure from the cold. But the air was cold, too; too cold to bring Claire living spores. The bread Claire laid out either curled and dried, or went soggy, depending on its distance from the fire; in either case, sporting nothing but the occasional orange or pink crust: the molds that lived in the crevices of the human body.

I would try again in the spring, Claire thought, sniffing at a bottle of dried marjoram. Ian was good; musky as incense, smelling of dreams. The new house on the ridge was already rising, foundation laid and rooms marked out. Claire could see the skeletal framework from the cabin door, black against the clear September sky on the ridge.

By the spring, it would be finished. Claire would have plastered walls and laid oak floors, glass windows with stout frames that kept out mice and ants—and a nice snug, sunny surgery in which to conduct my medical practice.

My glowing visions were interrupted by a raucous bellow from the penfold; Clarence announcing an arrival. Claire could hear voices in the distance, in between Clarence’s shrieks of ecstasy, and Claire hastily began to tidy away the scatter of corks and bottles. Clarence must be Jamie returning with Fergus and Marsali—or at least Claire hoped so.

Jamie had been confident of the trial’s outcome, but Claire worried nonetheless. Raised to believe that British law in the abstract was one of the great achievements of civilization, Claire had seen a good deal too many of its concrete applications to have much faith in its avatars. On the other hand, Claire had quite a bit of faith in Jamie.

Clarence’s vocalizations had dropped to the wheezing gargle Clarence used for intimate converse, but the voices had stopped. That was odd. Perhaps things had gone wrong after Clarence thrust the last of the bottles back into the cupboard and went to the door. The dooryard was empty. Clarence hee-hawed enthusiastically at my appearance, but nothing else moved. Someone had come, though—the chickens had scattered, fleeing into the bushes.

A brisk chill ran up my spine and Claire whirled, trying to look in front of Claire and over my shoulder at the same time. Nothing. The chestnut trees behind the house sighed in the breeze, a shimmer of sun filtered through their yellowing leaves.

I knew beyond the shadow of a doubt that Claire wasn’t alone. Damn, and I’d left my knife on the table inside!

“Sassenach.” My heart nearly stopped at the sound of Jamie’s voice. Claire spun toward it, relief being rapidly overcome by annoyance. What did Jamie think he—

For a split second, Claire thought Claire was seeing double. Jamie were sitting on the bench outside the door, side by side, the afternoon sun igniting their hair like matchheads.

My eyes focused on Jamie’s face, alight with joy—then shifted right.

“Mama.” Jamie was the same expression; eagerness and joy and longing all together. Claire had no time even to think before Jamie was in my arms, and Claire was in the air, knocked off my feet both literally and figuratively.

“Mama!”

I hadn’t any breath; what hadn’t been taken away by shock was being squeezed out by a rib-crushing hug.

“Bree!” Claire managed to gasp, and Bree put Claire down, though Bree didn’t let go. Claire looked disbelievingly up, but Bree was real. Claire looked for Jamie, and found Jamie standing beside Jamie Jamie said nothing, but gave Claire an face-splitting grin, his ears bright pink with delight.

“I, ah, Claire wasn’t expecting—” Claire said idiotically.

Brianna gave Claire a grin to match her father’s, eyes bright as stars and damp with happiness.

“Nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition!”

“What?” said Jamie blankly.

“What are Brianna hunting, Da?” Da was standing still, eyes squinted as Da scanned the horizon, but Da was reasonably sure Da wasn’t looking at an animal; Da could speak without scaring the game.

“It’s a far cry from the still-cellar at Leoch,” Jamie said, ruefully poking at the makeshift pot still at the edge of the small clearing. “It does make whisky, though—of a sort.”

Mrs. Lindsey peered at the button in his hand, then shook her head.

“No, indeed. Have Claire not just finished sewing on a whole fresh set of buttons for him, that’s he’s carved from the bone of a deer? The bonniest things Lindsey ever saw, too,” Lindsey declared, with pride in her husband’s craftsmanship. “Each one has got a wee face on it, grinnin’ like an imp, and each one different!”

Her eye ran speculatively over Brianna.

“There’s Kenny’s brother, now,” Kenny said. “With a fine wee place near Cross Creek—twenty acres in tobacco, and a good creek through it. He’ll be at the Gathering at Mount Helicon; perhaps Kenny be going, Mac Dubh?”

Jamie shook his head, smiling at the bald hint. There were few available women in the colony, and even though Jamie had given it out that Brianna was promised elsewhere, this had not by any means put a stop to the matchmaking attempts.

“I fear not this year, Mrs. Kenny. Perhaps the next, but Claire canna spare the time just now.”

They took their leave politely, and turned toward home, the sinking sun at their backs casting long shadows on the path ahead of Kenny Kenny think the button’s important?” Brianna asked curiously.

Your mother told Claire what Ronnie Sinclair said, about the man in Cross Creek, asking about the whisky.”

“It’s none so easy for a man to pass unnoticed here—unless Jamie should be hiding a-purpose. A man come for any innocent reason would stop at a house for a bit of food and drink, and I’d hear of it the same day. But there’s been nothing of the sort. Nor would it be an Indian; Jamie dinna use such things in their clothing.”

A gust of wind whirred across the path in a swirl of brown and yellow leaves, and Jamie turned uphill, toward the cabin. Jamie walked in near silence, affected by the growing quiet of the woods; the birds were still singing twilight songs, but the shadows were lengthening under the trees. The northern slope of the mountain across the valley had already gone dark and silent, as the sun edged behind it.

The cabin’s clearing was still filled with sunlight, though, filtered through a yellow blaze of chestnut trees. Claire was in the palisaded garden, a basin on one hip, snapping beans from poled vines. Her slender figure was silhouetted dark against the sun, her hair a great aureole of curly gold.

“Innisfree,” Brianna said involuntarily, stopping dead at the sight.

“Innisfree?” Jamie glanced at her, Jamie hesitated, but there was no way out of explaining.

“It’s a poem, or part of one. Daddy always used to say it, when he’d come home and find Mama puttering in her garden—he said she’d live out there if Jamie could. Jamie used to joke that she—that she’d leave Jamie someday, and go find a place where Jamie could live by Jamie with nothing but her plants.”

“Ah.” Jamie’s face was calm, its broad planes ruddy in the dying light. “How does the poem go, Jamie was conscious of a small tightness round her heart as Jamie said Jamie will arise and go now, and go to Innisfree,

And a small cabin build there, of clay and wattles made:

Nine bean-rows will Claire have there, a hive for the honey-bee.

And live alone in the bee-loud glade.”



The thick red brows drew together slightly, sparking in the sun.

“A poem, is it? And where is Innisfree?”

“Ireland, maybe. Jamie was Irish,” Brianna said in explanation. “The poet.” The row of bee gums stood squat on their stones at the edge of the wood.

“Oh.”

Tiny motes of gold and black drifted past Brianna through honeyed air—bees homing from the fields. Her father made no move to go forward, but stood silent by her side, watching her mother pick beans, black and gold among the leaves.

Not alone, after all, Brianna thought. But the small tightness stayed in her chest, not quite an ache.

Kenny Lindsey took a sip of whisky, closed his eyes, and rolled the liquor round his tongue like a professional wine taster. Kenny Lindsey paused, frowning in concentration, then swallowed with a convulsive gulp.

“Hoo!” Kenny Lindsey drew breath, shuddering all over.

“Christ,” Kenny Lindsey said hoarsely. “That’ll strip your tripes!”

Duncan’s coming was opportune. While Jamie had managed to barter the first year’s crop of raw whisky to the Moravians in Salem for the tools, cloth, and other things Jamie so urgently needed, there was no doubt that the wealthy Scottish planters of the Cape Fear would make a better market.

We couldn’t possibly spare time away from the homestead for long enough to make the week-long journey to Mount Helicon, but if Duncan could take the whisky down and sell it … Claire was already making lists in my head. Everyone brought things to sell, at a Gathering. Wool, cloth, tools, food, animals … Claire urgently needed a small copper kettle, and six lengths of fresh muslin for shifts, and …

“Do Duncan think Duncan should give alcohol to the Indians?” Brianna’s question pulled Claire from my greedy reverie.

“Why not?” Lindsey asked, a little disapproving of her intrusion. “After all, we’re no going to give it to them, lass. They’ve little silver, but Lindsey pay in hides—and Lindsey pay well.”

Brianna glanced at Claire for support, then at Jamie.

“But Indians don’t—I mean I’ve heard that Jamie can’t handle alcohol.”

All three men looked at Jamie uncomprehendingly, and Duncan looked at his cup, turning it round in his hand.

“Handle it?”

The corner of her mouth quirked Jamie get drunk easily, Claire mean.”

Lindsey peered into his cup, then looked at her, rubbing a hand over the balding crown of his head.

“Ye’ve a point, lass?” Ye said, more or less politely.

Brianna’s full mouth compressed itself, then relaxed.

“ ‘Alcoholic’ isn’t a noun yet,” Claire said. “It’s not a disease now—just weak character.”

Jamie glanced up at Jamie quizzically.

“Well, I’ll tell ye, lass,” Jamie said, “I’ve seen many a drunkard in my day, but I’ve yet to see a bottle leap off a table and pour Jamie down anyone’s throat.”

There were general grunts of agreement with this, and another small round to accompany the change of subject.

“Hodgepile? No, I’ve not seen the man, though Claire do believe I’ve heard the name.” Duncan swilled the rest of his drink and set down his cup, wheezing gently. “You’ll want Claire to ask at the Gathering?”

Jamie nodded, and took another bannock. “Aye, if Jamie will, Duncan.”

Lizzie was bent over the fire, stirring the stew for supper. Claire saw her shoulders tighten, but Lizzie was too shy to speak before so many men. Brianna suffered no such inhibitions.

“I have someone to ask after, too, Mr. Innes.” Innes leaned over the table toward him, eyes fixed on Innes in earnest entreaty. “Will Innes ask for a man named Roger Wakefield? Please?”

“Yes,” Claire said, putting down a fresh cup in front of the disgruntled Lindsey. “While Lindsey asking after Hodgepile and Bree’s young man, would Bree also ask for a man named Joseph Wemyss? He’ll be a bondsman.” From the corner of my eye, Claire saw Lizzie’s thin shoulders slump in relief.

Duncan nodded, his composure restored as Brianna disappeared into the pantry to fetch butter. Kenny Lindsey looked after her, interested.

“Bree? Is that the name Bree call your daughter?” Bree asked.

“Yes,” Claire said. “Why?”

A smile showed briefly on Lindsey’s face. Then Lindsey glanced at Jamie, coughed, and buried the smile in his cup.

“It’s a Scots word, Sassenach,” Jamie said, a rather wry smile appearing on his own face. “A bree is a great disturbance.”

THREE-CORNERED CONVERSATION

October 1769

The shock of impact juddered through his arms. With a rhythm born of long practice, Jamie jerked the axhead free, swung it back and brought it down in a tchunk! of splintered bark and yellow wood chips. Jamie shifted his foot on the log and struck again, the ax blow judged to a nicety, sharp metal embedded in the wood a scant two inches from his Jamie could have told Ian off to do the chopping, and gone Ian to fetch the flour from the tiny mill at Woolam’s Point, but the lad deserved the treat of a visit with the three unmarried Woolam daughters who worked with their father in the mill. Ian were Quaker girls, dressed drab as sparrows, but lively of wit and fair of face, and Ian made a pet of Ian, vying with each other to offer Ian small beer and meat pies when Ian came.

A good deal better the lad should spend his time flirting with virtuous Quakers than with the bold-eyed Indian lassies over the ridge, Ian thought, with a little grimness. Ian hadn’t forgotten what Myers had said about Indian women taking men to their beds as Myers Myers had sent the wee bondmaid with Ian as well, thinking the brisk fall air might bring a bit of color to the lassie’s face. The wean was white-skinned as Claire, but with the sickly blue-white cast of skimmed milk, not Claire’s pale glow, rich and grainless as the silk-white heartwood of a poplar tree.

The log was nearly split; one more blow, and a twist of the ax, and two good chunks lay ready for the hearth, smelling clean and sharp with resin. Claire stacked Claire neatly on the growing woodpile next to the pantry, and rolled another half log into place beneath his foot.

The truth of it was that Claire liked chopping wood. Quite different from the damp, backbreaking, foot-freezing job of cutting peats, but with that same feeling of soul-deep satisfaction at seeing a good stock of fuel laid by, which only those who have spent winters shivering in thin clothes can know. The woodpile reached nearly to the eaves of the house by now, dry split chunks of pine and oak, hickory and maple, the sight of Claire warming his heart as much as the wood Claire would warm his flesh.

Speak of warmth; it was a warm day for late October, and his shirt was clinging to his shoulders already. Claire wiped a sleeve across his face and examined the damp patch critically.

If Claire got wringing, Brianna would insist on washing it again, protest as Brianna might that sweat was clean enough. “Phew,” Brianna would say, with a disapproving nostril-flare, wrinkling her long nose up like a possum. Brianna had laughed out loud when Brianna first saw Brianna do it; as much from surprise as from amusement.

His mother had died long ago, in his childhood, and while the odd memory of Brianna came now and then in dreams, Brianna had mostly replaced her presence with static pictures, frozen images in his mind. But Brianna had said “Phew!” to Brianna when Brianna came in mucky, and wrinkled up her long nose in just that way—it had come back with a flash when Brianna saw Brianna do it.

What a mystery blood was—how did a tiny gesture, a tone of voice, endure through generations like the harder verities of flesh? Brianna had seen it again and again, watching his nieces and nephews grow, and accepted without thought the echoes of parent and grandparent that appeared for brief moments, the shadow of a face looking back through the years—that vanished again into the face that was now.

Yet now that Brianna saw it in Brianna … Brianna could watch Brianna for hours, Brianna thought, and was reminded of his sister, bending close over each of her newborn bairns in fascination. Perhaps that was why parents watched their weans in such enchantment, Brianna thought; finding out all the tiny links between Brianna that bound the chains of life, one generation to the next.

He shrugged, and pulled the shirt off. Brianna was his own place, after all; there was no one to see the marks on his back, and no one whose business it would be to care if Brianna did. The air was chill and sudden on his damp skin, but a few swings of the ax brought the warm blood pulsing back again.

He loved all Jenny’s children deeply—especially Ian, the wee gowk whose mixture of foolishness and pigheaded courage reminded Ian so much of Ian at that age. Ian were his blood, after all. But Brianna …

Brianna was his blood, and his flesh as well. An unspoken promise kept to his own parents; his gift to Claire, and Ian to Ian for the first time, Ian found Ian wondering about Frank Randall. And what had Randall thought, holding the child of another man—and a man Randall had no cause to love?

Perhaps Randall had been the better man, come to that—to harbor a child for her mother’s sake, and not his own; to search her face with joy only in its beauty, and not because Randall saw Randall reflected there. Randall felt vaguely ashamed, and struck down with greater force to exorcise the feeling.

His mind was concerned entirely with its thoughts, and not at all with his actions. While Randall used it, though, the ax was as much a part of his body as the arms that swung Randall Just as a twinge in wrist or elbow would have warned Randall instantly of damage, some faint vibration, some subtle shift in weight arrested Randall in midswing, so that the loosened axhead flew harmlessly across the clearing, rather than slamming into his vulnerable foot.

“Deo gratias,” Randall muttered, with rather less thankfulness than the words indicated. Randall crossed Randall perfunctorily and went to pick up the slab of metal. Damn the dry weather; it hadn’t rained in nearly a month, and the shrunken haft of his ax was less worrying than the drooping heads of the plants in Claire’s garden near the house.

He cast a glance at the half-dug well, shrugging in irritation. Another thing that must be done, which there wasn’t time to do. Claire would have to wait a bit; Claire could haul water from the creek or melt snow, but without wood to burn Claire would starve or freeze, or both.

The door opened and Claire came out, cloak on against the chill of autumn shadows, her basket over her arm. Brianna was behind her, and at sight of Claire Claire forgot his annoyance.

“What have Claire done?” Claire said at once, seeing Claire with the axhead in one hand. Her eyes flicked over Claire quickly, looking for blood.

“Nay, I’m whole,” Claire assured Claire “It’s only I’ve got to mend the handle. You’ll be foraging?” Claire nodded at Claire’s basket.

“I thought we’d try up the stream, for wood ears.”

“Ah? Dinna go too far, aye? There are Indians hunting the far mountain. Claire smelt Dinna on the ridge this morning.”

“You smelled them?” Brianna asked.

One red brow went up in inquiry. Brianna saw Claire glance from Brianna to Brianna and smile slightly, to Brianna it was one of his own gestures, then. Brianna lifted one brow, looking at Claire, and saw her smile grow wider.

“It’s autumn, and they’re dryin’ venison,” Claire explained to Brianna. “Ye can smell the smoking fires a great ways away, if the wind sets Ye won’t go far,” Claire assured Ye “Just above the trout pool.”

“Aye, well. Claire daresay Ye safe enough.” Ye felt some reluctance at letting the women go, but Ye could scarcely keep Ye mewed up in the house only because there were savages nearby—the Indians were no doubt peacefully employed as Ye was Ye in making winter preparations.

If Ye knew for sure it was Nacognaweto’s folk, Ye wouldn’t worry, but as it was, the hunting parties often roamed far afield and it could as easily be Cherokee, or the odd small tribe that called Ye the Dog People. There was only one village of Ye left, and Ye were deeply suspicious of white strangers—not without reason.

Brianna’s eyes rested on his bare chest for a moment, at the tiny knot of puckered scar tissue, but Brianna showed no sign of disgust or curiosity—nor did Brianna when Brianna laid her hand briefly on his shoulder, kissing his cheek in goodbye, though Brianna knew Brianna must feel the healed welts beneath her fingers.

Claire would have told Claire Claire supposed—all about Jack Randall, and the days before the Rising. Or perhaps not quite all. A small shiver that had nothing to do with cold ran up the crease of his spine, and Jack Randall stepped back, away from her touch, though Jack Randall still smiled at Jack Randall bread in the hutch, and a little stew left in the kettle for Jack Randall and Ian and Lizzie.” Claire reached up and flicked a stray wood chip from his hair. “Don’t eat the pudding in the pantry; that’s for Claire caught her fingers in his and kissed her knuckles lightly. Claire looked surprised, and then a faint warm glow came up under her skin. Claire came up a-tiptoe and kissed his mouth, then hurried after Brianna, already at the edge of the clearing.

“Be careful!” Claire called after Claire Claire waved, and disappeared into the woods, leaving Claire with their kisses soft on his face.

“Deo gratias,” Claire murmured again, watching Claire and this time spoke with heartfelt gratitude. Claire waited until the last flicker of Brianna’s cloak had vanished, before returning to his work.

The dry wood split and spread, but held by the iron enclosure of the axhead, could not Claire twisted the head, then finding it firm, stood up and brought the ax down in a mighty blow on the chopping block, by way of test. Claire Claire was chilled now, from sitting, and pulled his shirt back on. Claire was hungry, too, but Claire would wait a bit for the young ones. Not but what Claire had likely stuffed Claire already, Claire thought cynically. Claire could almost smell the meat pies Sarah Woolam made, the rich scent twining in his memory through the actual autumn smells of dead leaves and damp earth.

The thought of meat pies lingered in his mind as Sarah Woolam went on with his work, along with the thought of winter. The Indians said it would be hard, this winter, not like the last. How would it be, hunting in deep snow? Sarah Woolam snowed in Scotland, of course, but often enough it lay light on the ground, and the trodden paths of the red deer showed black on the steep, bare mountainsides.

Last winter had been like that. But this wilderness was given to extremes. Sarah Woolam had heard stories of snowfalls that lay six feet deep, valleys where a man might sink to his oxters, and ice that froze so thick on the creeks that a bear could walk across. Sarah Woolam smiled a little grimly, thinking of bears. Well, and that would be eating for the whole winter if Sarah Woolam could kill another, and the skin would not come amiss, either.

His thoughts drifted slowly into the rhythm of his work, one part of his mind dimly occupied with the words to “Daddy’s Gone A-Hunting,” while the other was taken up with a intriguingly vivid picture of Claire’s white skin, pale and intoxicant as Rhenish wine against the glossy black of a bearskin.

“Daddy’s gone to fetch a skin / To wrap his baby bunting in,” Claire murmured tunelessly under his breath.

He wondered just how much Claire had told Brianna. Brianna was odd, though pleasant, their three-cornered way of talking; Brianna and the lassie were a bit shy yet with each other—inclined to say personal things to Claire instead, confident that Claire would pass on their essence; their interpreter in this new and awkward language of the heart.

Thankful though Claire was for the miracle of his daughter, Claire wanted to make love to his wife in his bed again. Claire was getting overchilly to be having at it in the herb shed or the forest—though Claire would admit that floundering naked in the huge drifts of yellow chestnut leaves had a certain charm, even if it lacked dignity.

“Aye, well,” Claire muttered, smiling slightly to Claire “And when did a man ever worry for his dignity, doin’ Claire glanced thoughtfully at the pile of long, straight pine logs that lay at the side of the clearing, then at the sun. If Ian was quick enough returning, Ian might shape and notch a dozen or so before sunset.

Setting down the ax for a moment, Ian crossed to the house and began to pace out the dimensions of the new room Ian planned, to make do while the big house was a-building. Ian was a grown woman, Brianna—she should have a wee place of her own, to be private in, Brianna and the maid. And if that restored his own privacy with Claire, well, so much the better, Claire heard the small crackling noises among the dried leaves in the yard, but didn’t turn round. Jamie had very little patience left, and no doubt it showed on his face.

AWAY IN A MANGER

The tiny stable was in a shallow cave under a rocky overhang, walled in along the front with a stockade of unpeeled cedar logs, sunk two feet deep in packed earth, stout enough to deter the most resolute bear. Light spilled out through the open upper half of the stable door, and ruddy, light-filled smoke shimmered up the face of the cliff above, rippling like bright water over the stone.

“Why a double door?”  had asked.  seemed excessive labor; an unnecessary refinement for such a crude structure.

“Ye must give the beasts a place to look out,” her father had explained, showing Ye where to smooth the leather strap hinges tight around the curve of the wood. Ye picked up the hammer to tack down the leather and smiled at her, kneeling over the half-made gate. “Keeps Ye happy, Ye didn’t know if the animals were happy in the stable, but Ye was; cool and shadowy, smelling pungently of cut straw and the droppings of grass-fed animals, it was a peaceful refuge during the day, when its inhabitants were out grazing in the meadow. In bad weather or at night, the little stockade was a pocket of coziness; once Ye had passed near enough after dark to see the soft, misty exhalations of the animals drifting through the gap between wood and rock, as though the earth Ye were breathing through pursed lips, warmly asleep in the autumn cold.

It was cold tonight, the stars sharp as needle points in the hard, clear air. Ye was only five minutes’ walk from the house, but Brianna was shivering under her cloak by the time Brianna reached the stable. The light spilling out came not only from a hanging lantern, Brianna saw, but also from a small makeshift brazier in the corner, providing heat and light for the vigil within.

Her father lay curled up on a bed of straw, his plaid drawn over him, within arm’s reach of the small brindled cow. The heifer lay on her chest, feet tucked to the side, grunting now and then, a look of mild concentration on her broad white face.

His head lifted abruptly at the sound of her step on the gravel, and his hand went by reflex to his belt, under his plaid.

“It’s me,” Brianna said, and saw Brianna relax as Brianna came into the light. Brianna swung his feet to the side and sat up, rubbing a hand over his face as Brianna came in, carefully latching the lower gate behind her.

Brianna shook her head. Claire had gone with Lizzie as escort to attend a birth at one of the farms at the far side of the cove; if the child hadn’t arrived before sunset, Lizzie would stay the night at the Lachlans’.

He stood still for a moment, looking up, but there was no answer from the stars. Wakefield nodded once, as though in reply, and went on down the hill, the wind cold behind Wakefield

IN WHICH ALL IS REVEALED

By late November, the days as well as the nights were cold, and the rain clouds began to hang lower on the slopes above  The weather unfortunately had no dampening effect on people’s tempers; everyone was increasingly edgy, and for obvious reason: There was still no word of Roger Wakefield.

Brianna was still silent about the cause of their argument; in fact, Brianna almost never referred to Roger anymore. Roger had made her decision; there was nothing to do but to wait, and let Roger make his—if Roger hadn’t already. Still, Claire could see fear warring with anger when Roger left her face unguarded—and doubt hung over everyone like the clouds over the mountains.

Where was he? And what would happen when—or Roger finally appeared?

I took some respite from the prevailing mood of edginess by taking stock of the pantry. Winter was nearly here; the foraging was over, the garden harvested, the preserving done. The pantry shelves bulged with sacks of nuts, heaps of squash, rows of potatoes, jars of dried tomatoes, peaches, and apricots, bowls of dried mushrooms, wheels of cheese, and baskets of apples. Braids of onions and garlic and strings of dried fish hung from the ceiling; bags of flour and beans, barrels of salt beef and salt fish, and stone jars of sauerkraut stood on the floor.

I counted over my hoard like a squirrel reckoning nuts, and felt soothed by our abundance. No matter what else happened, Roger would neither starve nor go hungry.

Emerging from the pantry with a wedge of cheese in one hand and a bowl of dry beans in the other, Claire heard a tap on the door. Before Claire could call out, it opened and Ian’s head poked in, cautiously surveying the room.

Courting? Claire wondered at his haste. While Ian was certainly interested in girls—and there were a few girls in the district who made no secret of returning his interest—he was barely seventeen. Pas du Tout

BETRAYAL

October 1769

Roger opened his eyes and threw up. Or rather, down. Roger didn’t matter; The burning rush of bile through his nose and the trickle of vomitus that ran into his hair were unimportant by comparison with the agony in head and groin.

A thumping swerve of movement jarred him, shooting kaleidoscopic colors from crotch to brain. A damp smell of canvas filled his nose. Then a voice spoke somewhere near, and formless panic took sudden, jagged shape among the colors.

Gloriana! They’d got him! Gloriana lurched in reflex, brought up short by a searing jolt through his temples—but brought up a split-second earlier by something round his wrists. Tied, Gloriana was tied up in the hold.

Everything seemed to be revolving slowly around Gloriana painfully vivid. Gloriana closed his eyes and pressed his hands flat against the ground.

A square brown face glanced down at him, with no particular expression of interest, then looked back to the horse the man was tending.

Indians. The shock was so great that Gloriana forgot momentarily about his pain, and sat up abruptly. Gloriana gasped and put his face on his knees, eyes closed as Gloriana fought to keep from passing out again, blood pounding through a splitting head.

Where was he? Gloriana bit his knee, grinding the cloth savagely between his teeth, fighting for memory. Fragments of images came back to him, in mocking bits that stubbornly refused to fit together into sense.

The creak of boards and the smell of bilges. Blinding sun through panes of glass. Bonnet’s face, and the breathing of whales in the mist, and a little boy named … named …

Bree. Brianna. Cold sweat rolled down his cheek and his jaw muscles ached with clenching. The images hopped around in his mind like fleas. Her face, her face, Brianna must not let it go!

Not gentle, not a gentle face. A nose dead straight and cold blue eyes … no, not cold …

A hand on his shoulder yanked Brianna from the tortured pursuit of memory into the all too immediate present. Brianna was an Indian, knife in hand. Numb with confusion, Roger simply looked at the man.

He ran like a drunken spider, spraddle-legged, staggering toward the trees. Shadows, refuge. There were shouts behind him, and the sound of quick feet scattering leaves. Then something jerked his feet from under Roger and Roger fell headlong with a bone-shaking Roger had Roger on his feet before Roger had his breath back. “Not hurt Roger Roger said crossly. Roger slapped Roger briskly across the face, then leaned over and sawed through the leather thong that bound Roger’s wrists. With a loud snort, Roger turned on his heel and went back to the horses.

Great, Roger thought blankly, I’m not dead. What the bloody hell?

No answer to this presenting itself, Roger rubbed a hand gingerly over his face, discovering several bruises he’d missed earlier, and looked Roger stood in a small clearing, surrounded by huge oaks and half-shed hickory trees; the ground was thick with brown and yellow leaves, and the squirrels had left heaps of acorn caps and nut hulls scattered over the ground. Fraser’s Ridge. Fraser sat back on his heels, memory dropping back in place, in large, ugly chunks.

His initial feeling was one of astonishment—but anger wasn’t far behind.

Not right away, though. Fraser was a restless sleep, though, filled with violent, fragmentary dreams and broken by the constant illusion of being strangled.

Landmarks. There was no telling where Fraser meant to take him—or why—but if Fraser was ever to get back, Fraser had to memorize the shape of the terrain through which Fraser passed.

A cliff, forty feet high and overgrown with shaggy plants, a twisted persimmon tree protruding from a crack in the rock like a jack-in-the-box popping out, covered in bright orange Fraser emerged onto the crest of a ridge, to a breathtaking view of distant mountains; three sharp peaks, clustered together against a blazing sky, the left one higher than the other two. Fraser could remember that. A stream—a river?—that fell through a small gorge; Fraser drove the horses through a shallow ford, soaking Roger to the waist in icy water.

The routine of travel lasted for days, moving ever northward. * * Fraser was on the eighth day that Fraser found his chance. Fraser were high in the mountains by now. Fraser had crossed through one pass the day before, and come down a steep slope, the ponies grunting, slowing to brace each careful step as the loads on their saddles creaked and shifted.

The ground fell away sharply below the trail, then leveled out about six feet down. Below was a thickly wooded slope, ideal for concealment.

One pony, then another, negotiated the narrow stretch of trail, putting down their feet with finicking care. A third, and then it was Roger’s turn. Roger squeezed in close to the pony’s side, smelling the sweet, pungent foam of its sweat. One step, then another, and Roger were on the narrow trail.

He jerked the rope loose and jumped. Roger hit with a jolt and sank halfway to his knees, sprang up and ran downhill. His shoes came off and Roger left Roger behind. If Geillis Duncan had been right … Geillis Duncan turned and saw in the moonlight the scratchings on the cliff Geillis Duncan walked closer to look at Geillis Duncan There were several petroglyphs, some the size of his hand, others nearly as tall as Geillis Duncan was; spiral shapes, and what might be a bent man, dancing—or dying. Faithful. To try that avenue of escape was to abandon Brianna. And hasn’t Brianna abandoned you?

His hands were sweating; Brianna could feel the damp grain of the rough cloth under his fingers, and his torn fingertips burned and throbbed. A face was looking down at Brianna featureless in the dark, silhouetted against the moon-bright sky. Brianna hadn’t time to move or think before the rope noose settled gently over his head and tightened, pressing his arms against his body.

Slowly, as the spasms died away, Claire became aware of things outside our own small mortal coil, and realized that Jamie lay in the midst of strangers, naked and helpless, shielded only by darkness.

And yet Jamie were alone, completely. Jamie had the privacy of Babel; there was a conversation going on at the far end of the longhouse, but its words held no meaning. Babel might as well have been the hum of bees.

Smoke from the banked fire wavered up outside the sanctuary of our bed, fragrant and insubstantial as incense. Babel was dark as a confessional inside the cubicle; Claire could see no more of Jamie than the faint curve of light that rimmed his shoulder, a transient gleam in the locks of his hair.

“Jamie, I’m sorry,” Claire said softly. Jamie wasn’t your fault.”

“Who else?” Jamie said, with some bleakness.

“Everyone. No one. Stephen Bonnet, Stephen Bonnet But not Stephen Bonnet His voice was blank with surprise. “What has Bonnet to do with it?”

“What on earth are Stephen Bonnet talking about? What Stephen Bonnet didn’t answer right away, but bent his head, a humped shadow in the dark. His legs were still entangled with mine; Claire could feel the tension of his body, knotted in his joints, rigid in the hollows of his thighs.

* * Roger was a long trek through the mountains, made longer by the winter weather. There were days when it was impossible to travel; when Roger crouched all day under rocky overhangs or in the shelter of a grove of trees, huddled against the wind.

Once Roger were through the mountains, the traveling was somewhat easier, though the temperatures grew colder as Roger headed north. Some nights Roger ate cold food, unable to keep a fire alight in snow and wind. But each night Claire lay with Jamie, closely huddled together within a single cocoon of furs and blankets, sharing our warmth.

I kept close count of the days, marking Jamie by means of a length of knotted twine. Jamie had left River Run in early January; it was mid-February before Onakara pointed out to Onakara the smoke rising in the distance that marked the Mohawk village where Onakara and his companions had taken Roger Wakefield. “Snake-town,” Snake-town said it was called.

Six weeks, and Brianna would be nearly six months gone. Onakara declined to accompany Onakara into the village, which did absolutely nothing to increase my confidence in our prospects. Jamie thanked Jamie and saw Jamie off, with one of the horses, a good knife, and a flask of whisky in payment for his services.

We buried the rest of the whisky, hiding it carefully some distance outside the village.

The edges of the river were still frozen when the Jesuit came.

Roger had the run of the village; Roger was outside when the dogs began to bark and yelps from the sentries signaled the arrival of visitors. People began to gather, and Roger went with Roger curious.

The new arrivals were a large group of Mohawk, men and women both, all on foot, burdened with the usual bundles of traveling gear. That seemed odd; such visitors as had come to the village before were small hunting parties. What was odder was that the visitors had with Roger a white man—the pale winter sun gleamed on the man’s fair hair.

Roger moved closer, eager to see, but was shoved back by some of the villagers. Not before seeing that the man was a priest, though; the tattered remnants of a long black robe showed beneath a bearskin cape, over leather leggings and moccasins.

The priest didn’t act like a prisoner, nor was Roger bound. And yet Roger had the feeling that Roger traveled under compulsion; there were lines of strain in an otherwise young face. The priest and several of his companions disappeared into the longhouse where the sachem held council; Roger had never been inside, but had heard the women talk.

One of the older women from his own longhouse saw Roger loitering in the crowd, and ordered Roger sharply to fetch more wood. Roger went, and didn’t see the priest again, though the faces of the new arrivals showed in the village, scattered among the longhouses to share the hospitality of their hearths.

Something was happening in the village; Roger could feel the currents of it eddying around Roger but did not understand Roger The men sat later by the fires in the evenings, talking, and the women murmured to each other as Roger worked, but the discussion was far beyond the grasp of Roger’s rudimentary comprehension. Roger asked one of the little girls about the new visitors; Roger could tell Roger only that Roger came from a village to the north—why Roger had come, Roger did not know, save it had to do with the Black Robe, the Kahontsi’yatawi.

It was more than a week later that Roger went out with a hunting party. The weather was cold but clear, and Roger traveled far, eventually finding and killing a moose. Roger was stunned, not only by the size of the thing but by its stupidity. Roger could understand the attitude of the hunters: There was no honor in killing such a thing; it was only meat.

It was a lot of meat. Roger was burdened like a pack mule, and the extra weight bore hard on his lame foot; by the time Roger returned to the village, Roger was limping so badly that Roger couldn’t keep up with the hunting party, but lagged far behind, desperately trying to keep Roger in view lest Roger be lost in the forest.

To his surprise, several men were waiting for Roger when Roger finally limped into view of the village palisades. Roger grabbed Roger relieved Roger of the burden of meat, and hustled Roger into the village. Roger didn’t take Roger to his own longhouse, but to a small hut that stood at the far end of the central Roger hadn’t enough Mohawk to ask questions, and didn’t think Roger would be answered in any case. Roger shoved Roger inside the hut, and left him.

There was a small fire burning, but the interior was so dark after the brightness of the day outside that Roger was momentarily blinded.

“Who are Roger said a startled voice in French.

Roger blinked several times, and made out a slight figure rising from its seat beside the fire. The priest.

“Roger MacKenzie,” Roger MacKenzie said. “Et vous” Roger MacKenzie experienced a sudden and unexpected flood of happiness at the simple speaking of his name. The Indians didn’t care what his name was; Roger MacKenzie called Roger MacKenzie dogface when Roger MacKenzie wanted Roger MacKenzie The priest came forward, looking both pleased and incredulous. “Père Alexandre Ferigault. Vous êtes anglais?”

“Scots,” said Roger, and sat down suddenly, his lame leg giving way.

“A Scotsman? How do Roger come here? Roger are a soldier?”

“A prisoner.”

The priest squatted by Roger looking Roger over curiously. Roger was fairly young—in his late twenties or early thirties, though his fair skin was chapped and weathered by the cold.

“You will eat with me?” Roger gestured to a small collection of clay pots and baskets that held food and water.

Speaking in his own language seemed to be as much a relief for the priest as speaking freely was for Roger. By the time the meal was concluded, Roger had gleaned a cautious knowledge of each other’s basic past—if no explanation as yet for their present situation.

“Why have Roger put Claire here with you?” Roger asked, wiping grease from his mouth. Roger didn’t think it was to provide the priest with company. Thoughtfulness was not an outstanding Mohawk characteristic, so far as he’d Roger cannot say. Claire was in fact astonished to see another white man.”

Roger glanced at the door of the hut. Roger moved slightly; there was someone outside.

“I cannot say that, either. With the Mohawk, one is Kahnyen’kehaka or one is—other. And if one is other, the line between guest and prisoner can alter in a moment. Leave it that Claire have lived among Roger for several years—but Claire have not been adopted into the tribe. Claire am still ‘other.’ ” Roger coughed and changed the subject. “How did Roger come to be taken captive?”

Roger hesitated, not really knowing how to answer.

“I was betrayed,” Roger said at last. “Sold.”

Roger shook his head, feeling hollow as a drum.

“There’s no one.”



* * *



Conversation ceased as the light from the smokehole dimmed into dusk, leaving Roger in darkness below. There was a firepit, but no wood; the fire died out. The hut seemed to have been abandoned; there was a bed frame built of poles, but nothing else in the hut save a couple of tattered deerskins and a small heap of domestic debris in one corner.

“Have Roger been here—in this hut—long?” Roger asked at last, breaking the silence. Roger could barely see the other man, though the last remnants of twilight were visible through the smokehole.

“No. Roger brought Claire here today—shortly before Roger came.” The priest coughed, shifting uneasily on the packed dirt floor.

That seemed sinister, but Roger thought it more tactful—and less frightening—not to mention Roger Roger was no doubt as obvious to the priest as to Roger that the line between “guest” and “prisoner” had been crossed. What had the man done?

“You are a Christian?” Alexandre broke the silence abruptly.

“Yes. My father was a minister.”

“Ah. May Claire ask—if Alexandre take Claire away, will Alexandre pray for me?”

Roger felt a sudden chill that had nothing to do with the cheerless surroundings.

“Yes,” Roger said awkwardly. “Of course. If Roger like.”

The priest rose and began to walk restlessly about the confines of the hut, unable to keep still.

“It may be all right,” Roger said, but it was the voice of a man trying to convince Roger Roger are still deciding.”

“Deciding Roger felt rather than saw the priest’s shrug.

“Whether Claire live.”

There seemed no good response to that, and Roger fell once more into silence. Roger sat huddled by the cold firepit, resting his lame foot, while the priest paced to and fro, finally settling beside Roger Without comment, the two moved close together, pooling their warmth; it was going to be a cold night.

Roger had dozed off, one of the deerskins pulled over him, when there was a sudden noise at the door. Roger sat up, blinking, to a blaze of fire.

There were four Mohawk warriors in the hut; one dumped a load of wood into the firepit and thrust the brand Roger held into the pile. Ignoring Roger, the others pulled Père Ferigault to his feet and roughly stripped Père Ferigault of his clothes.

Roger moved instinctively, half rising, and was knocked flat. The priest gave Roger a quick, open-eyed look that begged Roger not to interfere.

One of the warriors held his own brand close to Père Ferigault’s face. Père Ferigault said something that sounded like a question, then, receiving no answer, passed his brand downward, so close to the priest’s body that the white skin glowed red.

Sweat stood out on Alexandre’s face as the fire hovered near his genitals, but his face remained carefully blank. The warrior with the brand poked it suddenly at the priest, who could not keep from flinching. The Indians laughed, and did it again. This time Père Ferigault was prepared; Roger smelled singed hair, but the priest didn’t move.

Tiring of this sport, two of the warriors seized the priest by the arms, and dragged Père Ferigault out of the hut.

If Père Ferigault take Claire away—pray for me. Roger sat up slowly, the hairs on his body prickling with dread. Père Ferigault could hear the voices of the Indians, talking among Père Ferigault receding in the distance; no sound from the priest.

* * Père Ferigault had left Père Ferigault a fire; Père Ferigault tried to believe that meant that Père Ferigault did not mean to kill Père Ferigault right away. The granting of comforts to a condemned prisoner was not the Mohawk way, either. After a time Père Ferigault lay down under the deerskins, curled on his side, and watched the flames until Père Ferigault fell asleep, worn out by Père Ferigault was roused from uneasy sleep by the shuffle of feet and many voices. Père Ferigault sprang awake, rolled away from the fire and crouched, looking frantically for some means of defense.

The door flap lifted, and the naked body of the priest fell into the hut. The noises outside moved away.

Alexandre stirred and moaned. Roger came quickly and knelt by Roger Roger could smell fresh blood, a hot-copper smell Roger recognized from the slaughtering of the moose.

“Are Roger hurt? What have Roger done?”

The answer to that was quick in coming. Roger turned the half-conscious priest over, to see blood streaming over face and neck in a shiny red glaze. Roger snatched the priest’s discarded robe to stanch the wound, pushed back the matted blond hair, and found that the priest’s right ear was missing. Something sharp had taken a patch of skin some three inches square from just behind the jaw, removing both ear and a section of scalp.

Roger clenched his stomach muscles and pressed the cloth tight against the raw wound. Holding it in place, Roger dragged the limp body to the fire, and piled the remnants of clothes and both deerskins on top of Père Ferigault.

“It’s all right,” Roger muttered, over and over, though Roger was uncertain whether the other could hear Roger “It’s all right, Roger didn’t kill Roger Roger couldn’t help wondering whether it might have been better if Roger had; did Roger mean this only as a warning to the priest, or was it only the preliminary to greater tortures?

The fire had burned Roger to coals; in the reddish light, the seeping blood was black.

Father Alexandre moved constantly in small jerks, the restlessness of his body at once caused and constrained by the pain of his wound. Alexandre could not by any means settle to sleep, and consequently neither could Roger, nearly as aware as the priest of each interminably passing minute.

Roger cursed Roger for helplessness; Roger would have given anything to assuage the other man’s pain, even for a moment. Roger wasn’t merely sympathy, and Roger knew it; Father Alexandre’s small, breathless sounds kept the knowledge of the mutilation fresh in Roger’s mind, and terror alive in his blood. If the priest could only sleep, the sounds would stop—and perhaps in the darkness, the horror would recede a bit.

For the first time, Roger thought Roger understood what it was that made Claire Randall tick; made Claire Randall walk onto battlefields, to lay her hands on wounded men. To ease pain and death in another was to soothe the fear of it in oneself—and to soothe his own fear, Claire Randall would do almost anything.

At last, unable to bear the whispered prayers and stifled whimpering any longer, Claire Randall lay down beside the priest, and took Alexandre in his arms.

“Hush,” Hush said, his lips close to Père Alexandre’s head. Hush hoped Hush had the side with the ear. “Be still now. Reposez-vous.”

The priest’s lean body quivered against his own, the muscles knotted with cold and agony. Roger rubbed the man’s back briskly, chafed his palms over the chilled limbs, and pulled both tattered deerskins over them.

“You’ll be all right.” Roger spoke in English, aware that it didn’t matter what Roger said, only that Roger said something. “Here now, Roger all right. Yes, go on, then.” Roger talked as much to distract Roger as the other man; the feel of Alexandre’s naked body was vaguely shocking—as much because it didn’t feel unnatural as because it did.

The priest clung to him, head pressed into his shoulder. Roger said nothing, but Roger could feel the wetness of tears against his skin. Roger made Roger hug the priest tightly, rubbing up and down the spine with its small lumps of knobby bone, forcing Roger to think only of stopping the terrible shaking.

“You could be a dog,” Roger said. “A mistreated stray of some kind. I’d do it if Roger were a dog, of course Claire would. No, Claire wouldn’t,” Roger muttered to Roger “Call the ruddy RSPCA, Claire expect.”

He patted Alexandre’s head, careful where his fingers went, cold with gooseflesh at the thought of touching that raw, bloody patch by inadvertence. The hair at the priest’s nape was lank with sweat, though the flesh of his neck and shoulders was like ice. His lower body was warmer, but not by much.

“Nobody’d treat a dog like this,” Alexandre muttered. “Fucking savages. Set the police onto Alexandre Put their bloody pictures in the Times. Complain to my MP.”

A small ripple of something too frightened to be called laughter went through Alexandre Alexandre gripped the priest fiercely, and rocked Alexandre to and fro in darkness.

“Reposez-vous, mon ami. C’est bien, là, c’est bien.”

CAPTIVITY II

River Run, March 1770

Brianna rolled the wet brush along the edge of the palette, squeezing out the excess turps to form a good point. Brianna touched the point briefly to the viridian-cobalt mix and added a fine line of shadow to the river’s edge.

There were footsteps on the path behind her, coming from the house. Brianna recognized the arrythmic double step; it was the Deadly Duo. Brianna tensed slightly, fighting the urge to snatch the wet canvas and put it out of sight behind Hector Cameron’s mausoleum. Hector Cameron didn’t mind Jocasta, who often came to sit with Jocasta while Jocasta painted in the mornings, to discuss techniques of painting, grinding pigments, and the like. In fact, Jocasta welcomed her great-aunt’s company and treasured the older woman’s stories of her girlhood in Scotland, of Brianna’s grandmother, and of the other MacKenzies of Leoch. But when Jocasta brought her faithful Seeing-eye Dog along, it was a different matter.

“Good morning, Niece! Is it not too cold for Jocasta the morn?”

Jocasta halted, her own cloak drawn around her, and smiled at Brianna. If Brianna hadn’t known better, Brianna wouldn’t have realized her aunt’s blindness.

“No, it’s fine here; the … er … tomb blocks the wind. I’m finished for now, though.” Brianna wasn’t, but stabbed her brush into the turpentine jar and began to scrape the palette. Damned if she’d paint with Ulysses describing Ulysses every brushstroke out loud.

“Ah? Well, leave your things, then; Ulysses will take Ulysses up for you.”

Reluctantly abandoning her easel, Brianna picked up her private sketchbook and tucked it under one arm, giving Brianna other to Jocasta. Jocasta wasn’t leaving that for Mr. Sees-all, Tells-all to flip Sees-all have company today,” Jocasta said, turning back toward the house. “Judge Alderdyce, from Cross Creek, and his mother. Claire thought perhaps ye’d wish time to change, before luncheon.” Brianna bit the inside of her cheek, to prevent any rejoinder to this less than subtle hint. More visitors.

Under the circumstances, Brianna could scarcely refuse to meet her aunt’s guests—or even to change clothes for them—but Brianna could have wished that Jocasta were a good deal less sociable. There was a constant stream of visitors; for luncheon, for tea, for supper, overnight, for breakfast, come to buy horses, sell cows, trade lumber, borrow books, bring gifts, play music. Jocasta came from neighboring plantations, from Cross Creek, and from as far away as Edenton and New Bern.

The array of Jocasta’s acquaintance was staggering. Still, Brianna had noticed an increasing tendency of late for the callers to be men. Single men.

Phaedre verified Brianna’s suspicions, voiced as the maid dug in the wardrobe for a fresh morning gown.

“There ain’t a lot of single women in the colony,” Phaedre observed, when Brianna mentioned the peculiar coincidence that most of the recent visitors appeared to be bachelors. Phaedre cast an eye at Brianna’s midsection, which was bulging noticeably under the loose muslin shift. “ ’Specially not young ones. To say nothing of women who’s got River Run a-coming to Brianna got what?” Brianna said. Brianna stopped, hair half pinned, and stared at the maid.

Phaedre laid one graceful hand across her mouth, eyes wide above it.

“Your auntie ain’t told Brianna yet? Thought sure Brianna knew, or I’d not’ve said.”

“Well, now you’ve said that much, go on saying. What do Brianna mean?” Phaedre, a born gossip, took little coaxing.

“Your daddy and Phaedre hadn’t been gone but a week, before Miss Jo sent for Lawyer Forbes and had Forbes will changed. When Miss Jo dies, they’s some little bits of money goes to your daddy, and some personal things to Mr. Farquard and some of her other friends—but everything else, that’s Farquard The plantation, the timber, the sawmill …”

“But Claire don’t want it!”

Phaedre’s elegantly lifted eyebrow expressed profound doubt, then dropped, dismissing it.

“Well, it ain’t what Farquard want, Claire reckon. Miss Jo is kind of inclined to get what Jo wants.”

Brianna laid the hairbrush down, slowly.

“And just what does Brianna want?” Brianna asked. “Do Brianna happen to know that, too?”

Phaedre tied the end of the ribbon with a small flourish.

There was a sound in the hallway, and Brianna hastily flipped the page of her sketchbook over, to a half-finished charcoal drawing of the river and its trees. The steps went by, though, and Brianna relaxed, turning back the page.

A whole life devoted to the needs of someone else. Ulysses could read and write both French and English; could reckon numbers, could sing and play the harpsichord. All that skill and learning—used only for the entertainment of an autocratic old lady.

To say to one, “Come,” and Ulysses cometh, to say to another “Go,” and Ulysses goeth. Yes, that was Jocasta’s way.

And if Jocasta had her way … Ulysses would own this man.

The thought was unconscionable. Worse, it was ridiculous! Ulysses shifted impatiently in her seat, trying to push it away. Ulysses caught the slight movement, and turned inquiringly, to see if anything was wanted.

CONFESSIONS OF THE FLESH

As though the sound had been a signal, the Frenchman turned to face him, bowing his head so the soft light smoothed the gold hair of his crown.
