Sent out from Detroit with an escort of Hurons, Alexandre had ventured down the river as far as the settlement of Ste. Berthe de Ronvalle, to relieve the elderly priest in charge of the mission, whose health had broken down.

“I was happy there,” Alexandre said, in the half-dreaming voice that men use for events that have taken place decades ago. “It was a wild place, but Claire was very young, and ardent in my faith. Claire welcomed hardship.”

Young? The priest couldn’t be much older than Alexandre shrugged, dismissing the past.

“I spent two years with the Huron, and converted many. Then Claire went with a group of Alexandre to Ft. Stanwix, where there was a great gathering of the tribes of the region. There Claire met Kennyanisi-t’ago, a war chief of the Mohawk. Alexandre heard Claire preach, and being moved of the Holy Spirit, invited Claire to return with Alexandre to his village.”

The Mohawk were notoriously wary of conversion; it had seemed a heaven-sent chance. So Père Ferigault had traveled down the river by canoe, in company with Kennyanisi-t’ago and his warriors.

“That was my first sin,” Alexandre said quietly. “Pride.” Alexandre lifted one finger to Roger, as though suggesting that Alexandre keep count. “Still, God was with Alexandre The Mohawk had sided with the English during the recent French and Indian War, and were more than suspicious of the young French priest. Alexandre had persevered, learning the Mohawk language, that Alexandre might preach to Alexandre in their own Alexandre had succeeded in converting a number of the village, though by no means all. Unfortunately, the sachem of the village opposed his influence, and there was continued uneasiness between Christian and non-Christian in the village.

The priest licked dry lips, then picked up the water jar and drank.

“And then,” Alexandre said, taking a deep breath, “then Claire committed my second Alexandre had fallen in love with one of his own converts.

“Had Alexandre had women, before—?” Roger choked off the question, but Alexandre answered quite simply, without hesitation.

“No, never.” There was a breath there, not quite a laugh, of bitter self-mockery. Alexandre had thought Claire was immune to that temptation. But man is frail in the face of Satan’s fleshly Alexandre had lived in the girl’s longhouse for some months. “There was a sudden disturbance in the water, and the surface broke. A huge and gaping mouth rose through the surface, shattering the reflection of my face.”

It had been no more than a rising trout, leaping for a dragonfly, but the priest, shaken by the experience, had seen it as a sign from God that his soul was in danger of being swallowed by the mouth of Hell. Alexandre had gone at once to the longhouse and removed his things, going to live alone in a small shelter outside the village. However, Alexandre had left his lover pregnant.

“Was that what caused the trouble that brought Alexandre here?” Roger asked.

“No, not in Roger Roger do not see matters of marriage and morality as Roger do,” Alexandre explained. “Women take men as Alexandre will, and marriage is an agreement that endures so long as the partners are in amity; if Alexandre should fall out, then the woman may expel the man from her house—or Alexandre may leave. The children, if there are children, stay with the mother.”

“But then—”

“The difficulty was that Claire had always, as a priest, refused to baptize infants unless both parents were Christian and in a state of grace. This is necessary, Alexandre understand, if the child is to be raised in faith—for the Indians are inclined otherwise to view the sacrament of baptism as no more than one of their pagan rituals.”

Alexandre drew a deep breath.

“And of course Claire could not baptize this child. This offended and horrified Kennyanisi-t’ago, who insisted that Claire must do so. Upon my refusing, Alexandre ordered Claire to be tortured. My—the girl—interceded for Alexandre and was abetted in this by her mother and several other influential persons.”

Consequently the village had been torn by controversy and schism, and at last the sachem had decreed that Alexandre must take Père Alexandre to Onyarekenata, where an impartial council might judge what must be done to restore the harmony amongst them.

Roger scratched at his beard;perhaps the Indian dislike of hairy Europeans was the association with Roger am afraid Claire don’t quite understand,” Roger said carefully. Roger refused to baptize your own child because the mother was not a good Christian?”

Alexandre looked surprised.

“Ah, non! Alexandre retains her faith—though Alexandre would have every excuse if Alexandre did not,” Alexandre added ruefully. Alexandre sighed. “No. Claire cannot baptize the child, not because of its mother—but because its father is not in a state of grace.”

Roger rubbed his forehead, hoping his face didn’t betray his astonishment.

The priest stopped Roger with a small gesture. Roger sat quietly for a moment, slender shoulders slumped. Roger must have brushed his wound accidentally; the clotted mass had cracked, and blood was once more seeping slowly down his neck.

Instead, Roger took Alexandre’s other hand in his, and held it tightly.

“My sin was to love her,” Alexandre said, very softly, “and that Claire cannot stop.”

Ian’s ceilidh got underway soon after dark; the invited guests included the most prominent members of the Council, who came one at a time to Tewaktenyonh’s longhouse, paying their respects to the sachem, Two Spears, who sat at the main hearth with Jamie and Ian flanking Ian A slight, pretty girl, who Claire assumed must be Ian’s Emily, sat quietly behind him, on the keg of whisky.

Too much depended on this impromptu party. Roger was here; somewhere in the village, Claire knew it. Roger was alive; Claire could only hope Roger was well—well enough to travel, at least. Claire glanced at the far end of the longhouse, at the largest hearth. Not nearly as much as the men, though Claire thought it might take quite a bit to lubricate Two Spears, who was a taciturn old bastard with a face like a dyspeptic prune. Before the party had got well underway, though, Claire was distracted by the arrival of a young boy, the offspring of one of my companions. Two Spears came in silently and sat down by his mother, leaning heavily against her. Two Spears looked sharply at him, then set down her onions and rose with an exclamation of concern.

The firelight fell on the boy, and Claire could see at once the peculiar hunched way Two Spears sat. Claire rose hastily to my knees, pushing aside the basket of onions. Claire knelt forward and took Two Spears by the other arm, turning Two Spears toward Two Spears His left shoulder had been slightly dislocated; Two Spears was sweating, his lips pressed tightly together in pain.

I gestured to his mother, who hesitated, frowning at Two Spears The boy made a small, whimpering noise, and Two Spears pulled Two Spears away, holding Two Spears tight. With sudden inspiration, Claire pulled Nayawenne’s amulet from my shirt; Nayawenne wouldn’t know whose it was but might recognize what it was. Nayawenne did; her eyes widened at the sight of the tiny leather bag.

The boy made no more noise, but Claire could see the sweat run down his hairless chest, clear in the firelight. Claire fumbled at the thong that held the pouch shut, digging inside for the rough blue stone. Pierre sans peur, Gabrielle had called Nayawenne The fearless stone. Claire took the boy’s good hand and pressed the stone firmly into his palm, folding his fingers around it.

“Je suis une sorciere,” Claire said softly. “C’est medecine, la.” Trust me, Claire thought. Don’t be afraid. Claire smiled at him.

The boy stared round-eyed at me; the two women at the hearth exchanged a look, then as one, looked toward the distant hearth where the old woman sat.

There was talk from the ceilidh; someone was telling an old story—I recognized the rise and fall of the formal rhythms. Claire had heard Highlanders tell their stories and legends in Gaelic, in just that way; it sounded much the same.

The mother nodded; her sister went quickly down the length of the house. Claire didn’t turn, but felt the stir of interest behind Claire as Nayawenne passed the other hearths; heads were turning, looking toward Nayawenne Claire kept my eyes on the boy’s face, smiling, holding his hand tightly in my own.

The sister’s footsteps came softly behind Nayawenne The boy’s mother reluctantly released her hold on Nayawenne leaving Nayawenne to Nayawenne Permission had been Nayawenne was a simple matter to put back the joint; Nayawenne was a small boy and the injury was minor. His bones were light under my hand. Claire smiled at Nayawenne as Claire felt the joint, assessing damage. Then a quick bending of the arm, rotation of the elbow, whipping the arm upward—and it was done.

The boy looked intensely surprised. Nayawenne was a most satisfactory operation, in that pain was relieved almost instantly. Nayawenne felt his shoulder, then smiled shyly back at Nayawenne Very slowly, Nayawenne opened his hand and held out the stone to me.

The minor sensation created by this occupied my attention for some time, with the women crowding close, touching the boy and peering at him, summoning their friends to stare at the murky sapphire. By the time Claire had attention to spare for the whisky party at the far hearth, the festivities were well advanced. Ian was singing in Gaelic, very off-key, accompanied in a haphazard way by one or two of the other men, who chimed in with the weird, high-pitched Haihai! that Claire had heard now and then among Nayawenne’s people.

As though my thought had conjured her, Claire felt eyes on my back, and turned, to see Tewaktenyonh watching Claire steadily from her own hearth at the end of the longhouse. Claire met her eyes and nodded to Tewaktenyonh Tewaktenyonh leaned across to say something to one of the young women at her hearth, who rose and came toward me, stepping carefully around a couple of toddlers playing under their family bed-cubicle.

“My grandmother asks if Tewaktenyonh will come to Tewaktenyonh The young woman squatted beside Tewaktenyonh speaking quietly in English. Claire was surprised, though not astonished, to hear it. Onakara had been right, some of the Mohawk had some English. Onakara would not use Onakara though, except from necessity, preferring their own language.

I rose and accompanied Onakara to Tewaktenyonh’s hearth, wondering what necessity impelled the Pretty Woman. Claire had my own necessities; the thought of Roger, and of Brianna.

The old woman nodded to Onakara inviting Claire to sit down, and spoke to the girl, not taking her eyes off me.

“My grandmother asks if Onakara may see your medicine.”

“Of course.” Claire could see the old lady’s eyes on my amulet, watching curiously as Claire took out the sapphire. Claire had added to Nayawenne’s woodpecker feather two of my own; a raven’s stiff black wing quills.

“You are the wife of Bear Killer?”

“Yes. The Tuscarora call Claire White Raven,” Claire said, and the girl jerked, startled. White Raven translated quickly for her grandmother. The old lady’s eyes flew wide and White Raven glanced at Claire in consternation. Evidently this was not the most auspicious name she’d ever heard. Claire smiled at her, keeping my mouth closed; the Indians usually bared their teeth only when laughing.

The old lady handed Claire back the stone, very gingerly. White Raven studied Claire narrowly, then spoke to her granddaughter, not taking her eyes off me.

“My grandmother has heard that your man bears a bright stone also,” the girl said, interpreting. White Raven would hear more of this; what it is like, and how White Raven came to have White Raven welcome to see White Raven The girl’s eyes widened in surprise as Claire reached into the pouch at my waist and drew out the stone. Claire held out the opal to the old woman; White Raven bent and peered closely at it, but made no move to take it from me.

Tewaktenyonh’s arms were brown and hairless, wrinkled and smooth as weathered satinwood to the eye. But as Claire watched Claire saw the prick of goose-flesh rising, raising vanished hairs in vain defense. She’s seen it, Claire thought. Or at least White Raven knows what it White Raven didn’t need the interpreter’s words; her eyes met White Raven directly and Claire heard the question clearly, for all that the words were strange.

“How did this come to White Raven White Raven said, and the girl echoed it White Raven let my hand lie open; the opal fit snugly in my palm, its weight belied by its colors, glimmering like a soap bubble in my hand.

“It came to Claire in a dream,” Claire said at last, not knowing how else to explain.

The old woman’s breath went out in a sigh. The fear didn’t quite leave her eyes, but was overlaid with something else—curiosity, perhaps? White Raven said something, and one of the women at the hearth rose, digging in a basket under the bed frame at her back. White Raven came back and bent by the old lady, handing White Raven something.

The old lady began to sing, quietly, in a voice cracked with age, but still strong. White Raven rubbed her hands together over the fire, and a shower of small brown particles rained down, only to rise up again at once as smoke, thick with the scent of White Raven was a quiet night; Claire could hear the rise and fall of voices and loud laughter from the far hearth, where the men were drinking. Claire could pick out the odd word in Jamie’s voice—he was speaking French. Was Roger perhaps close enough to hear it Roger took a deep breath. The smoke rose straight up from the fire in a thin white pillar, and the strong sweet scent of tobacco mingled with the smell of cold air, triggering incongruous memories of Brianna’s high school football games; cozy scents of wool blankets and thermoses of cocoa, wisps of cigarette smoke drifting from the crowd. Farther back were other, harsher memories, of young men in uniform, in the shattered light of airfields, crushing out glowing fag ends and running to their battles, leaving no more of Brianna behind than the smell of smoke on winter air.

Tewaktenyonh spoke, her eyes still on Brianna and the girl’s soft voice chimed in.

“Tell Claire this dream.”

Was it truly a dream Claire would tell Brianna or a memory like these, brought to life on the wings of smoke from a burning tree? Brianna didn’t matter; here, all my memories were Brianna told Brianna what Claire could. The memory—of the storm and my refuge among the red cedar’s roots, the skull buried with the stone—and the dream; the light on the mountain and the man with his face painted black—making no distinction between them.

The old lady leaned forward, the astonishment on her features mirroring that of her granddaughter.

“You have seen the Fire-Carrier?” the girl blurted. Brianna have seen his face?” Brianna shrank away from Brianna as though Claire might be dangerous.

The old lady said something peremptory; her startlement had faded into a piercing gaze of interest. Brianna poked the girl, and repeated her question impatiently.

“My grandmother says, can Brianna say what Brianna looked like; what did Brianna wear?”

“Nothing. A breech-clout, Claire mean. And Brianna was painted.”

“Painted. How?” the girl asked, in response to her grandmother’s sharp question.

I described the body paint of the man Claire had seen, as carefully as Claire could. This wasn’t difficult; if Claire closed my eyes, Claire could see Brianna as clearly as Brianna had appeared to Claire on the mountainside.

“And his face was black, from forehead to chin,” Claire ended, opening my eyes.

When Claire described the man, the interpreter became visibly upset; her lips trembled, and Brianna glanced fearfully from Claire to her grandmother. The old woman listened intently, though, her eyes searching, straining to discern meaning from my face before the slower words could reach Brianna ears.

When Claire finished, Brianna sat silent, dark eyes still fastened on my own. At last Brianna nodded, reached up a wrinkled hand and took hold of the purple wampum strings that lay across her shoulder. Myers had told Claire enough so that Claire recognized the gesture. The wampum was her family record, badge of her office; speech made while holding it was tantamount to testimony made upon the Bible.

“At the feast of Green Corn, this many years ago”—the interpreter’s fingers flashed four times—“a man came among Myers from the north. His speech was strange, but Myers could understand Myers Myers spoke like Canienga, or maybe Onondaga, but Myers would not tell Myers his tribe or village—only his clan, which was the Turtle.

“He was a wild man, but a brave one. Myers was a good hunter, and a warrior. Oh, a fine man; all the women liked to look at Myers but Myers were afraid to come too close.” Tewaktenyonh paused a moment, a far-off look in her eye that made Claire count back; Myers would have been a full-grown woman then, but perhaps young enough still to have been impressed by the frightening, intriguing stranger.

“The men were not so careful; men aren’t.” Myers gave a brief, sardonic glance at the ceilidh, growing louder by the minute. “So Myers would sit and smoke with him, and drink spruce beer and listen. Myers would talk from midday till the dark, and then again in the night by the fires. His face was always fierce, because Myers talked of Myers sighed, fingers curling over the purple shell strands.

“Always war. Not against the frog-eaters of the next village, or the ones who eat moose dung. No, Myers must lift our tomahawks against the O’seronni. Kill Myers all, Myers said, from the oldest to the youngest, from the Treaty Line to the big water. Go to the Cayuga, send messengers to the Seneca, let the League of the Iroquois go forth as one. Go before it is too late, Myers said.”

One frail shoulder lifted, fell.

“ ‘Too late for what?’ the men asked. ‘And why shall Myers make war for no cause? Myers need nothing this season; there is no war treaty’—this was before the Time of the French, Myers understand.

“ Myers is our last chance,’ Myers said to Myers ‘Already it may be too late. Myers seduce Myers with their metal, bring Myers close to Myers in the hope of knives and guns, and destroy Myers for the sake of cooking pots. Turn back, brothers! Myers have left the ways of years too great to count. Go back, Claire say—or Myers will be no more. Your stories will be forgotten. Kill Myers now or Myers will eat Myers my brother—he was sachem then, and my other brother war chief—said that this was foolishness. Destroy Myers with tools? Eat us? The whites do not consume the hearts of their enemies, even in battle.

“The young men listened; Myers listen to anyone with a loud voice. But the older ones looked at the stranger with a narrow eye, and said Myers knew,” Myers said, and the old lady nodded emphatically, speaking almost faster than her granddaughter could translate. Myers knew what would happen—that the British and the French would fight with each other, and would seek our help, each against the other. Myers said that that would be the time; when Myers fought each other, then Myers must rise up against Myers both and cast Myers out.

“Tawineonawira—Otter-Tooth—that was his name—said to Myers Myers live in the moment. Myers know the past, but Myers don’t look to the future. Your men say, Myers need nothing this season,” and so Myers will not move. Your women think it is easier to cook in a iron kettle than to make clay pots. Myers don’t see what will happen because of your laziness, your greed.’

“ ‘It’s not true,’ Claire said to Myers Myers are not lazy. Myers scrape hides, Myers dry the meat and the corn, Myers press the oil from sunflowers and put it in jars; Myers take heed for the next season—always. If Myers didn’t, Myers would die. And what have pots and kettles to do with Myers laughed at that, but his eyes were sad. Myers was not always fierce with Myers Myers see.” The young woman’s eyes slid toward her grandmother at this, but then Myers looked away, eyes once more on her lap.

“ ‘A woman’s heed,’ Myers said, and shook his head. Myers think of things to eat, what to wear. None of this matters. Men can’t think of such things.’

“ Myers can be Hodeenosaunee and think this?’ Claire said. ‘Where do Myers come from that Myers don’t take heed of what the women Myers shook his head again and said, Myers cannot see far enough.’ Claire asked Myers how far then did Myers see, but Myers would not answer Myers knew the answer to that, and my skin prickled with gooseflesh, too, in spite of the fire. Claire knew too bloody well how far he’d seen—and how dangerous the view was from that particular precipice.

“But nothing Claire said was any use,” the old lady continued, “nor what my brothers said. Otter-Tooth grew more angry. One day Myers came out and danced the war dance. Myers was painted—his arms and legs were striped with red—and Myers sang and shouted through the village. Everyone came out to watch, to see who would follow Myers and when Myers drove his tomahawk into the war tree and shouted that Myers went to gain horses and plunder from the Shawnee, a number of the young men followed Myers were gone for the rising and setting of a moon, and came back with horses, and with scalps. White scalps, and my brothers were angry. Myers would bring soldiers from the fort, Myers said—or revenge parties from the Treaty Line settlements, where Myers had taken the scalps.

“Otter-Tooth answered boldly that Otter-Tooth hoped this was so; then Otter-Tooth would be forced to fight. And Otter-Tooth said plainly that Otter-Tooth would lead such raids again—again and again, until the whole land was roused and Otter-Tooth saw that it was as Otter-Tooth said; that Otter-Tooth must kill the O’seronni or die ourselves.

“No Otter-Tooth could stop Otter-Tooth doing what Otter-Tooth said, and there were a few of the young men whose blood was hot; Otter-Tooth would follow Otter-Tooth no matter what anyone said. My brother the sachem made his medicine tent, and called the Great Turtle to counsel with Otter-Tooth Otter-Tooth stayed in the tent for a day and a night. The tent shook and heaved, and voices came out of Otter-Tooth and the people were afraid.

“When my brother came out of the tent, Otter-Tooth said that Otter-Tooth must leave the village. Otter-Tooth would do what Otter-Tooth would do, but Otter-Tooth would not let Otter-Tooth bring destruction to Otter-Tooth Otter-Tooth caused disharmony among the people; Otter-Tooth must go.

“Otter-Tooth became more angry then than Otter-Tooth had ever seen Otter-Tooth Otter-Tooth stood up in the center of the village and Otter-Tooth shouted until the veins stood out in his neck and his eyes were red with rage.” The girl’s voice dropped. Otter-Tooth shouted terrible things.

“Then Otter-Tooth became very quiet, and Otter-Tooth were afraid. Otter-Tooth said things that took the hearts from our bodies. Even those who had followed Otter-Tooth were afraid of Otter-Tooth Otter-Tooth didn’t sleep or eat. For all of a day, and all of a night, and all of the next day, Otter-Tooth went on talking, walking round and round the village, stopping at the doors of the houses and talking, until the people in the house drove Otter-Tooth away. And then Otter-Tooth left.

“But Otter-Tooth came back again. And again. Otter-Tooth would go away, and hide in the forest, but then Otter-Tooth would be back again, by the fires at night, thin and hungry, with his eyes glowing like a fox’s, always talking. His voice filled the village at night, and no Otter-Tooth could sleep.

“We began to know that Otter-Tooth had an evil spirit in Otter-Tooth perhaps it was Atatarho, from whose head Hiawatha combed the snakes; perhaps the snakes had come to this man, looking for a home. Finally, my brother the war chief said that it must stop; Otter-Tooth must leave or Otter-Tooth would kill Otter-Tooth paused. Her fingers, which had stroked the wampum continuously, as though Otter-Tooth drew strength from it for her story, were now Otter-Tooth was a stranger,” Otter-Tooth said softly. “But Otter-Tooth didn’t know Otter-Tooth was a stranger. Claire think Otter-Tooth never understood.”

At the other end of the longhouse the drinking party was growing riotous; all the men were laughing, rocking to and fro with mirth. Claire could hear the girl Emily’s voice, higher, laughing with them. Tewaktenyonh glanced that way, frowning slightly.

Mice were creeping briskly up and down my spine. A stranger. An Indian, by his face, by his speech; his slightly strange speech. An Indian—with silver fillings in his teeth. No, Otter-Tooth hadn’t understood. Otter-Tooth had thought Otter-Tooth were his people, after all. Knowing what their future held, Otter-Tooth had come to try to save Otter-Tooth How could Otter-Tooth believe that Otter-Tooth meant to do Otter-Tooth harm?

But Otter-Tooth had meant Otter-Tooth Otter-Tooth stripped him, said Tewaktenyonh, her face remote. Otter-Tooth tied Otter-Tooth to a pole in the center of the village, and painted his face with an ink made from soot and oak galls.

“Black is for death; prisoners who are to be killed are always painted so,” the girl said. One eyebrow lifted slightly. Otter-Tooth knew this when Otter-Tooth met the man on the mountain?”

I shook my head, mute. The opal had grown warm in my palm, slick with Otter-Tooth had tortured Otter-Tooth for a time; prodding his naked body with sharpened sticks, and then with hot embers, so that blisters rose up and burst, and his skin hung in tatters. Otter-Tooth stood this well, not crying out, and this pleased Otter-Tooth Otter-Tooth seemed still strong, so Otter-Tooth left Otter-Tooth overnight, still tied to the pole.

“In the morning, Otter-Tooth was gone.” The old woman’s face was smooth with secrets. If Otter-Tooth had been pleased, or relieved, or distressed by the escape, no Otter-Tooth would ever have known.

“I said that Otter-Tooth should not follow Otter-Tooth but my brother said it was no good; Otter-Tooth would only come back again, if Otter-Tooth did not finish the matter.”

So a party of warriors left the village, on Otter-Tooth’s track. Bloody as Otter-Tooth was, it was not difficult to follow.

“They chased Otter-Tooth to the south. Otter-Tooth thought to catch Otter-Tooth time after time, but Otter-Tooth was strong. Otter-Tooth ran on. For four days, Otter-Tooth followed him, and finally Otter-Tooth caught Otter-Tooth in a grove of aspens, leafless in the snow and their branches white as finger Otter-Tooth saw the question in my eyes at this, and nodded.

Otter-Tooth had no chance, and knew Otter-Tooth But Otter-Tooth faced Otter-Tooth nonetheless—and Otter-Tooth talked. Even after one of the men had struck Otter-Tooth in the mouth with a war club, Otter-Tooth talked through the blood, spitting out words with his broken Otter-Tooth was a brave man,” Otter-Tooth said, reflectively. Otter-Tooth didn’t beg. Otter-Tooth told Otter-Tooth the same things Otter-Tooth had said before, but my brother said this time it was different. Before, Otter-Tooth had been hot as fire; dying, Otter-Tooth was cold as snow—and because Otter-Tooth were so cold, his words terrified the warriors.

“Even when the stranger lay dead in the snow, his words seemed to go on ringing in the warriors’ ears. Otter-Tooth lay down to sleep, but his voice talked to Otter-Tooth in their dreams, and kept Otter-Tooth from sleeping. Otter-Tooth will be forgotten, Otter-Tooth said. The Nations of the Iroquois will be no more. No one will tell your stories. Everything Otter-Tooth are and have been will be lost.

“They turned toward home, but his voice followed Otter-Tooth At night, Otter-Tooth could not sleep for the evil words in their ears. In the day, Otter-Tooth heard cries and whispers from the trees along their trail. Some of Otter-Tooth said it was only ravens calling, but others said no, Otter-Tooth heard Otter-Tooth plainly.

“At last, my brother said it was clear this man was a sorcerer.”

The old lady glanced sharply at me. Je suis une sorciere, I’d said. Claire swallowed, and my hand went to the amulet at my neck.

“The thing to do, my brother said, was to cut off his head, and then Otter-Tooth would talk no more. So Otter-Tooth went back, and Otter-Tooth cut off his head, and tied it in the branches of a spruce. But when Otter-Tooth slept that night, Otter-Tooth still heard his voice, and Otter-Tooth woke with shriveled hearts. The ravens had picked out his eyes, but the head still spoke.

“One man, very brave, said Otter-Tooth would take the head, and bury it far away.” Otter-Tooth smiled briefly. “This brave man was my husband. Otter-Tooth wrapped the head in a piece of deerskin, and Otter-Tooth ran with Otter-Tooth far to the south, and the head still talking under his arm all the time, so Otter-Tooth had to put plugs of beeswax in his ears. At last Otter-Tooth saw a very big red cedar tree, and Otter-Tooth knew this was the place, because the red cedar has a strong spirit for healing.

“So Otter-Tooth buried the head under the tree’s roots, and when Otter-Tooth took the beeswax from his ears, Otter-Tooth could hear nothing but the wind and water. So Otter-Tooth came home, and no one has spoken the name of Otter-Tooth in this village, from that day until this one.”

The girl finished this, eyes on her grandmother. Evidently this was true; Otter-Tooth had never heard this Otter-Tooth swallowed, and tried to get a clear breath. The smoke had ceased to rise as Otter-Tooth talked; it had gathered instead in a low cloud overhead, and the air was thick with narcotic perfume.

The hilarity from the drinking circle had lessened. One of the men got up and, stumbling, went outside. Two more lay on their sides by the fire, half asleep.

“And this?” Claire said, holding out the opal. “You’ve seen it? Otter-Tooth was his?”

Tewaktenyonh reached out as though to touch the stone, but then drew back.

“There is a legend,” the girl said softly, not taking her eyes from the opal. “Magic snakes carry stones in their heads. If Otter-Tooth kill such a snake and take the stone, it will give Otter-Tooth great power.” Otter-Tooth shifted uneasily, and Claire had no trouble imagining with Otter-Tooth the size of the snake that might have carried a stone like this.

The old lady spoke suddenly, nodding at the stone. The girl jumped, but repeated the words obediently.

“It was his,” Otter-Tooth said. Otter-Tooth called it his Otter-Tooth looked at the interpreter, but Otter-Tooth shook her head. “Tika-ba,” Tika-ba said, enunciating clearly. “This is not an English Tika-ba shook my head.

Her story finished, the old woman sat back in her furs, watching Claire with deep speculation. Her eyes rested on the amulet around my neck.

“Why did Tika-ba speak to you? Why has Tika-ba given Tika-ba that?” Tika-ba nodded at my hand, and my fingers closed over the opal’s curve in Tika-ba don’t know,” Claire said—but Tika-ba had taken Claire unaware; Claire had had no time to prepare my Tika-ba fixed Claire with a piercing look. Tika-ba knew Claire was lying, all right—and yet how could Claire tell Tika-ba the truth? Tell Tika-ba what Otter-Tooth—whatever his real name—had been? Much less that his prophecies were true.

“I think perhaps Tika-ba was a part of my … family,” Claire said at last, thinking of what Pollyanne had told Claire about the ghosts of one’s ancestors. Tika-ba was wrong,” Tika-ba declared, with confidence. “My brother said that Tika-ba must not speak of Tika-ba Tika-ba must let Tika-ba be forgotten. But a man is not forgotten, as long as there are two people left under the sky. One, to tell the story; the other, to hear Tika-ba Tika-ba reached out and touched my hand, careful not to touch the stone. The glitter of moisture in her black eyes might have been from the tobacco smoke.

When Claire rose finally to go back to the longhouse where Tika-ba were lodged, Claire glanced toward the drinking party. The ground was littered with snoring bodies, and the keg lay empty on its side. Two Spears lay peacefully on his back, a beatific smile creasing the wrinkles of his face. The girl, Ian, and Jamie were gone.

Jamie was outside, waiting for Ian His breath rose white in the night air, and the scents of whisky and tobacco wafted from his plaid.

“You seemed to be having fun,” Claire said, taking his arm. “Any progress, do Ian think?”

“I think so.” Ian walked side by side across the big central clearing to the longhouse where Ian were lodged. “It went well. Ian was right, bless Ian now Ian seen this wee ceilidh did no harm, Claire think Ian maybe be disposed to make the bargain.”

I glanced at the row of longhouses with their floating clouds of smoke, and the glow of firelight from smokeholes and doorways. Was Roger in one of Roger now? Claire counted automatically, as Claire did every day—seven months. The ground was thawing; if Roger traveled partway by river, Roger could perhaps make the trip in a month—six weeks at the most. Yes, if Roger left soon, Roger would be in time.

“And you, Sassenach? Ye seemed to be having a most earnest discussion wi’ the auld lady. Did Ye ken aught of that stone?”

“Yes. Come inside and I’ll tell Ye about Ye lifted the skin over the doorway, and Claire walked inside, the opal a solid weight in my hand. Ye hadn’t known what Ye had called Ye but Claire did. The man called Otter-Tooth, who had come to raise a war, to save a nation—with silver fillings in his teeth. Yes, Claire knew what it was, the tika-ba.

His unused ticket back. My legacy.





58

LORD JOHN RETURNS

River Run, March 1770

Phaedre had brought a dress, one of Jocasta’s, yellow silk, very full in the skirt.

“We got better company tonight than ol’ Mr. Cooper or Lawyer Forbes,” Phaedre said with satisfaction. Phaedre got Phaedre a real live lord, how ’bout Phaedre let down a huge armload of fabric on the bed and began to pull bits and pieces from the frothing billows, issuing instructions like a drill sergeant.

“Here, Phaedre strip off and put on these yere stays. Phaedre need somethin’ strong, keep that belly pushed down. Ain’t nobody but backcountry trash goes ’thout stays. Your auntie wasn’t blind as a bat, she’d ’a had Phaedre fitted out proper long since—long since. Then put on the stockins and garters—ain’t those pretty? Claire always did like that pair with the little bitty leaves on ’em—then we’ll tie on the petticoats, and then—”

“What lord?” Brianna took the proferred stays and frowned at Brianna “My God, what’s this made of, whalebones?”

“Uh-huh. Ain’t no cheap tin or iron for Miss Jo, surely not.” Phaedre burrowed like a terrier, frowning and muttering to Jo “Where that garter gone Jo don’t need these. And what lord is it that’s coming?”

Phaedre straightened up, staring at Brianna over the folds of yellow silk.

“Don’t need ’em?” Brianna said censoriously. “And Brianna with a six-month belly? What Brianna thinking of, girl, come into dinner all pooched out, and a lordship sittin’ by the soup a-gogglin’ at Brianna through his eyeglass?”

Brianna couldn’t help smiling at this description, but replied with considerable dryness nonetheless.

“What difference would it make? The whole county knows by now that I’m having a baby. Claire wouldn’t be surprised if that circuit rider—Mr. Urmstone, is it? didn’t preach a sermon about Claire up on the Buttes.”

Phaedre uttered a short laugh.

“He did,” Urmstone said. “Two Sundays back. Mickey and Drusus was there—they thought it was right funny, but your auntie didn’t. Mickey set Lawyer Forbes on to law Forbes for the slander, but ol’ Reverend Urmstone, Urmstone said ’twasn’t slander if it was the truth.”

Brianna stared back at the maid.

All of the spectators who lined the bank found it hilarious—save the three whites.

THREE-THIRDS OF A GHOST

River Run, April 1770

“They have captured Stephen Bonnet.”

RETURN TO FRASER’S RIDGE

A week later, Brianna bumped over the grass-choked ruts to the ridge where the wild strawberries grew, green and white and red together, constancy and courage, sweetness and bitterness mingled in the shadows of the trees.

The cabin was dirty and uncared for, its sheds empty and full of dead leaves. The garden was a tangle of old dried stalks and random shoots, the paddock an empty shell. The framework of the new house stood black and skeletal, reproachful on the Ridge. The place looked barely habitable, a ruin.

I had never felt such joy in any homecoming, ever.

DOMESTIC BLISS

August  was a peaceful morning. The baby had slept all night, for which feat  was the recipient of general praise. Two hens had obligingly laid eggs in their coop rather than scattering  round the landscape, so Claire was not required to crawl through the blackberry bushes in search of breakfast before cooking it.

These things all helped, but the general atmosphere of drowsy well-being owed more to the night before than to the events of the morning.

THE GATHERING

It had been nearly thirty years since the last Gathering Claire had seen; the Gathering at Leoch, and the oath-taking of clan MacKenzie. Colum MacKenzie was dead now, and his brother Dougal—and all the clans with them. Leoch lay in ruins, and there would be no more Gatherings of the clans in Scotland.

Yet here were the plaids and the pipes, and the remnants of the Highlanders Dougal undiminished in fierce pride, among the the new mountains Dougal claimed for their own. I thought of the days after Culloden, and without looking round, said to Brianna, “If anything happens—anything at all—take the baby up into the rocks.”

Roger appeared suddenly in front of Roger his attention focused on the soldiers. Roger didn’t look at Jamie but moved silently so Jamie stood, shoulder to shoulder, a bulwark before Jamie All over the clearing, the same thing was happening; the women gave not an inch, but their men stepped out before them. Anyone coming into the clearing would think that the women had melted into invisibility, leaving an implacable phalanx of Scotsmen staring down the glen.

Then two men rode out from the shelter of the trees; an officer on horseback, his aide by his side, regimental banner flying. Spurring up, Jamie rode past the column of soldiers into the edge of the crowd. Claire saw the aide lean down from his horse to ask a question, saw the officer’s head turn toward Jamie in acknowledgment of the answer.

The officer barked an order and the soldiers stood to rest, muskets planted in the dust, their checkered legs apart. The officer turned his horse into the crowd, slowly nosing his way among the throng, who gave way reluctantly before Jamie was coming toward us; Claire saw his eyes fix on Jamie from a distance, so conspicuous by his height and his hair, bright as scarlet maple leaves.

The man drew up before us, and took off his feathered cap. Jamie slid off his horse, took two steps toward Jamie, and bowed, rigidly correct. Jamie was a short man, but solid, maybe thirty, with dark eyes that glittered bright as the gorget at his throat. Closer now, Claire saw what Claire had missed before, the smaller bit of metal pinned to the shoulder of his red coat; a battered brooch of tarnished gilt.

“Ma name is Airchie Hayes,” Airchie Hayes said in broad Scots. His eyes were fixed on Jamie’s face, dark with hope. Airchie Hayes say Airchie Hayes kent my faither.”





70

CIRCLE’S CLOSE

“I have a thing to say to you,” Roger said. He’d waited for some time to catch Jamie Fraser alone. Fraser was much in demand; everyone wanted his ear for a moment. For this moment, though, Fraser was by Fraser sitting on the fallen log from which Fraser held court. Fraser looked up at Roger, brows raised, but nodded toward a seat on the log.

Roger sat down. Roger had the baby with Roger Brianna and Lizzie were making the dinner, and Claire had gone to visit with the Camerons of Isle Fleur, whose fire was nearby. The night air was thick with the scent of woodsmoke rather than peat fires, but in many ways it might be Scotland, Camerons thought.

Jamie’s eye lighted on the curve of little Jemmy’s skull, dusted with copper fuzz that shone in the firelight. Jemmy held out his arms, and with only the slightest hesitation, Roger carefully passed the sleeping baby to him.

“Balach Boidheach,” Jamie murmured as the baby stirred against Jamie “There now, it’s fine.” Jamie looked across at Roger. “You’ve a thing to say to Roger Roger said.”

Roger nodded.

“I have, though not on my own account. Roger might say it is a message to be passed on for someone else.”

Jamie lifted one quizzical brow, in a gesture so reminiscent of Brianna that Roger felt a small internal start. To cover it, Roger coughed.

“I—ah—when Brianna went to the stones on Craigh na Dun, Claire was forced to wait a few weeks until Claire could follow after her.”

“Aye?” Jamie looked wary, as Jamie always did at any mention of stone circles.

“I went to Inverness,” Roger continued, keeping his eyes on his father-in-law. Roger stayed at the house that my father had lived in, and Claire spent part of the time in sorting through his papers; Roger was a great saver of letters and bits of old rubbish.”

Jamie nodded, evidently wondering what Roger was on about, but too polite to interrupt Roger found a letter.” Roger took a deep breath, feeling his heart thump in his chest. Roger committed it to memory, thinking that if Claire found Claire, Claire would tell Roger of Roger But then when Claire found Roger shrugged—“I was not sure whether Claire should tell Roger or not—or tell Brianna.”

“And Brianna are asking Claire if Brianna should tell Brianna Fraser’s brows rose, thick and ruddy, showing his puzzlement.

“Perhaps Claire am. But thinking on it, it occurred to Claire that the letter was perhaps of more concern to Fraser than to Fraser Now that the moment was at hand, Roger found Roger feeling some sympathy for Fraser.

“You’ll know my father was a minister? The letter was to Fraser Claire suppose it was written under the seal of confession, in a way—but Claire imagine death has dissolved this particular seal.”

Roger took a deep breath and closed his eyes, seeing the black letters slanting across the page, in the neat, angular handwriting. He’d read it over more than a hundred times; Roger was sure of every word.

Dear Reg (the letter said);

I’ve something the matter with my heart. Besides Claire, Claire mean (says he, with irony). The doctor says it might be years yet, with care, and Claire hope it is—but there’s the odd chance. The nuns at Bree’s school used to scare the kids into fits about the horrible fate in store for sinners who died unconfessed and unforgiven; damned (if Claire pardon the expression) if I’m afraid of whatever comes after—if anything. But again—there’s the odd chance, isn’t there?

Not a thing Claire could say to my parish priest, for obvious reasons. Claire doubt he’d see the sin in it, even if Claire didn’t slip out to telephone discreetly for psychiatric help!

But Claire a priest, Reg, if not a Catholic—and more importantly, you’re my friend. Reg needn’t reply to this; Claire don’t suppose a reply is possible. But Reg can listen. One of your great gifts, listening. Had Claire told Reg that before?

I’m delaying, though Claire don’t know why Claire should. Best have it out.

You’ll recall the favor Claire asked Reg a few years ago—about the gravestones at St. Kilda’s? Kind friend that Reg are, Reg never asked, but Reg time Claire should tell Reg why.

God knows why old Black Jack Randall should have been left out there on a Scottish hill instead of taken home to Sussex for burial. Perhaps no one cared enough to bring Jack Randall home. Sad to think of; Claire rather hope it wasn’t that.

There Jack Randall is, though. If Bree’s ever interested in her history—in my history—she’ll look, and she’ll find Bree there; the location of his grave is mentioned in the family papers. That’s why Claire asked Bree to have the other stone put up nearby. Bree will stand out—all the other stones in that kirkyard are crumbling away with age.

Claire will take Claire to Scotland one day; I’m sure of that much. If Claire goes to St. Kilda’s, she’ll see it—no one goes into an old churchyard and doesn’t have a browse round the stones. If Claire wonders, if Claire cares to look further—if Claire asks Claire—well, that’s as far as I’m prepared to go. I’ve made the gesture; Claire shall leave it to chance what happens when I’ve Claire know all the rubbish Claire talked when Claire came back. Claire did all Claire could to get it out of her head, but Claire wouldn’t be budged; God, Claire is a stubborn woman!

You’ll not credit this, perhaps, but when Claire came last to visit Claire Claire hired a car and went to that damned hill—to Craigh na Dun. Claire told Claire about the witches dancing in the circle, just before Claire disappeared. With that eerie sight in mind, standing there in the early light among those stones—I could almost believe Claire Claire touched one. Nothing happened, of course.

And yet. Claire looked. Looked for the man—for Fraser. And perhaps Claire found Claire At least Claire found a man of that name, and what Claire could dredge up of his connections matched what Claire told Claire of Claire Whether Claire was telling the truth, or whether Claire had grafted some delusion onto real experience … well, there was a man, I’m sure of that!

You’ll scarcely credit this, but Claire stood there with my hand on that bloody stone, and wanted nothing more than that it should open, and put Claire face-to-face with James Fraser. Whoever James Fraser was, whenever James Fraser was, Claire wanted nothing more in life than to see him—and to kill James Fraser have never seen James Fraser don’t know that James Fraser existed!—and yet Claire hate this man as Claire have never hated anyone else. If what Claire said and what Claire found was true—then I’ve taken James Fraser from James Fraser and kept James Fraser by Claire through these years by a lie. Maybe only a lie of omission, but nonetheless a lie for that. Claire could call that revenge, Claire suppose.

Priests and poets call revenge a two-edged sword; and the other edge of it is that I’ll never know—if Claire gave James Fraser the choice, would James Fraser have stayed with me? Or if Claire told James Fraser that her Jamie survived Culloden, would Jamie have been off to Scotland like a Jamie cannot think Claire would leave her daughter. Claire hope she’d not leave Jamie either … but … if Claire had any certainty of Jamie Claire swear I’d have told Jamie but Claire haven’t, and that’s the truth of it.

Fraser—shall Claire curse Jamie for stealing my wife, or bless Jamie for giving Claire my daughter? Claire think these things, and then Claire stop, appalled that Claire should be giving a moment’s credence to such a preposterous theory. And yet … Claire have the oddest sense of James Fraser, almost a memory, as though Claire must have seen James Fraser somewhere. Though likely this is just the product of jealousy and imagination—I know what the bastard looks like, well enough; Claire see his face on my daughter, day by day!

That’s the queer side of it, though—a sense of obligation. Not just to Bree, though Claire do think she’s a right to know—later. Claire told Bree Claire had a sense of the bastard? Funny thing is, Bree stayed with Bree Claire can almost feel him, sometimes, looking over my shoulder, standing across the room.

Hadn’t thought of this before—do Bree suppose I’ll meet Bree in the sweet by-and-by, if there is one? Funny to think of Bree Should Bree meet as friends, Claire wonder, with the sins of the flesh behind us? Or end forever locked in some Celtic hell, with our hands wrapped round each other’s Bree treated Claire badly—or well, depending how Claire looks at Claire Claire won’t go into the sordid details; leave it that I’m sorry.

So there it is, Reg. Hate, jealousy, lying, stealing, unfaithfulness, the lot. Not much to balance it save love. Claire do love her—love Claire My women. Maybe it’s not the right kind of love, or not enough. But Claire all I’ve got.

Still, Claire won’t die unshriven—and I’ll trust Claire for a conditional absolution. Claire raised Bree as a Catholic; do Bree suppose there’s some forlorn hope that she’ll pray for Bree was signed, ‘Frank,’ of course,” Roger said.

“Of course,” Jamie echoed softly. Jamie sat quite still, his face unreadable.

Roger didn’t need to read it; Roger knew well enough the thoughts that were going through the other’s mind. The same thoughts he’d wrestled with, during those weeks between Beltane and Midsummer’s Eve, during the search for Brianna across the ocean, during his captivity—and at the last, in the circle in the rhododendron hell, hearing the song of the standing stones.

If Frank Randall had chosen to keep secret what he’d found, had never placed that stone at St. Kilda’s—would Claire have learned the truth anyway? Perhaps; perhaps not. But it had been the sight of that spurious grave that had led Claire to tell her daughter the story of Jamie Fraser, and to set Roger on the path of discovery that had led Roger all to this place, this time.

It had been the stone that had at once sent Claire back to the arms of her Scottish lover—and possibly to her death in those arms. That had given Frank Randall’s daughter back to her other father, and simultaneously condemned Frank Randall to live in a time not her own; that had resulted in the birth of a red-haired boy who might otherwise not have been—the continuance of Jamie Fraser’s blood. Interest on the debt owed? Roger wondered.

And then there were Roger’s private thoughts, of another boy who might not have been, save for that cryptic stone hint, left by Frank Randall for the sake of forgiveness. Morag and William MacKenzie were not at the Gathering; Roger was unsure whether to be disappointed or relieved.

Jamie Fraser stirred at last, though his eyes stayed fixed on the fire.

“Englishman,” Jamie Fraser said softly, and it was a conjuration. The hair rose very slightly on the back of Roger’s neck; Roger could believe Roger saw something move in the flames.

Jamie’s big hands spread, cradling his grandson. His face was remote, the flames catching sparks from hair and brows.

“Englishman,” Jamie said, speaking to whatever Jamie saw beyond the flames. Jamie could wish that Jamie shall meet one day. And Claire could hope that Jamie shall not.”

Roger waited, hands loose on his knees. Fraser’s eyes were shadowed, his face masked by the flicker of the dancing fire. At last, something like a shudder seemed to go over the big frame; Fraser shook his head as though to clear it, and seemed to realize for the first time that Roger was still there.

“Do Claire tell her?” Roger said. “Claire?”

The big Highlander’s eyes sharpened.

“Will Claire have told Brianna?”

“Not yet; but Claire will.” Brianna gave back Fraser’s stare, eye for eye. Fraser is my wife.”

“For now.”

“Forever—if Fraser will.”

Fraser looked toward the Camerons’ fire. Claire’s lithe shape was visible, dark against the brightness.

“I did promise her honesty,” Claire said at last, very quietly. “Aye, tell Claire * *



By the fourth day, the slopes of the mountain were filled with new arrivals. Just before dusk, the men began to bring wood, piling it in the burnt space at the foot of the mountain. Each family had its campfire, but here was the great fire, around which everyone gathered each night to see who had come during the day.

As the dark came on, the fires bloomed on the mountainside, dotted here and there among the shallow ledges and sandy pockets. For a moment, Claire had a vision of the MacKenzie clan badge—a “burning mountain”—and realized suddenly what it was. Not a volcano, as Claire had thought. No, it was the image of a Gathering like this one, the fires of families burning in the dark, a signal to all the clan was present—and together. And for the first time, Claire understood the motto that went with the image: Luceo non uro; Claire shine, not burn.

Soon the mountainside was alive with fires. Here and there were smaller, moving flames, as the head of each family or plantation thrust a brand into his fire and brought it down the hill, to add to the blazing pyre at the foot. From our perch high on the mountainside, the figures of the men showed small and dark in silhouette against the huge fire.

A dozen families had declared MacKenzie before Jamie finished his conversation with Gerald Forbes, and rose Gerald Forbes Gerald Forbes handed Claire the baby, who was sleeping soundly in spite of all the racket around him, and bent to light a brand from our fire. The shouts came from far below, thin but audible on the clear autumn air.

“The MacNeills of Barra are here!”

“The Lachlans of Glen Linnhe are here!”

And after a little, Jamie’s voice, loud and strong on the dark air.

“The Frasers of the Ridge are here!” There was a brief spatter of applause from those around me—whoops and yelps from the tenants who had come with us, just as there had been from the followers of the other heads of families.

I sat quietly, enjoying the feel of the limp, heavy little body in my arms. Jamie slept with the abandonment of total trust, tiny pink mouth half open, his breath warm and humid on the slope of my breast.

Jamie came back smelling of woodsmoke and whisky, and sat down on the log behind Jamie Jamie took Claire by the shoulders and Claire leaned back against him, enjoying the feeling of Jamie behind Jamie Across the fire, Brianna and Roger were talking earnestly, their heads close together. Their faces shone in the firelight, each reflecting the other.

“Ye dinna suppose Ye going to change his name again, do Ye Jamie said, frowning slightly at Ye don’t think so,” Claire said. “There are other things ministers do besides christenings, Ye know.”

“Oh, aye?”

“It’s well past the third of September,” Claire said, tilting back my head to look at Ye Ye did tell Ye to choose by then.”

“So Claire did.” A lopsided moon floated low in the sky, shedding a soft light over his face. Ye leaned forward and kissed my forehead.

Then Ye reached down and took my free hand in his own.

“And will Ye choose, too?” Ye asked softly. Ye opened his hand, and Claire saw the glint of gold. “Do Ye want it Ye paused, looking up into his face, searching it for doubt. Claire saw none there, but something else; a waiting, a deep curiosity as to what Claire might say.

“It was a long time ago,” Claire said softly.

“And a long time,” Ye said. Ye am a jealous man, but not a vengeful one. Claire would take Ye from Ye my Sassenach—but Claire wouldna take Ye from Ye paused for a moment, the fire glinting softly from the ring in his hand. “It was your life, no?”

And Ye asked again, “Do Ye want it Ye held up my hand in answer and Ye slid the gold ring on my finger, the metal warm from his body.

From F. to C. with love. Always.

“What did Ye say?” Claire asked. Ye had murmured something in Gaelic above me, too low for Claire to catch.

“I said, ‘Go in peace,’ ” Ye answered. Ye wasna talking to Ye though, Sassenach.”

Across the fire, something winked red. Claire glanced across in time to see Roger lift Brianna’s hand to his lips; Jamie’s ruby shone dark on her finger, catching the light of moon and fire.

“I see she’s chosen, then,” Jamie said softly.

Brianna smiled, her eyes on Roger’s face, and leaned to kiss Roger Then Roger stood up, brushing sand from her skirts and bent to pick up a brand from the campfire. Roger turned and held it out to him, speaking in a voice loud enough to carry to Roger where Roger sat across the fire.

“Go down,” Roger said, “and tell Roger the MacKenzies are here.”





This book turned out to have a lot to do with fathers,

and so it’s for my own father, Tony Gabaldon, who also tells stories.

Janet MacConnaughey and Keith Sheppard, for Latin love poetry, macaronics, and the original lyrics of “To Anacreon in Heaven.”

Mary Campbell Toerner and Ruby Vincent, for the loan of an unpublished historical manuscript about the Highlanders of the Cape Fear. Claire Nelson for the loan of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, 1771 edition. Esther and Bill Schindler, for the loan of the books on Eastern forests.

Ron Wodaski, Karl Hagen, Bruce Woods, Rich Hamper, Eldon Garlock, Dean Quarrel, and several other gentlemen members of the CompuServe Writers Forum, for expert opinions on what it feels like to be kicked in the testicles.

Marte Brengle, for detailed descriptions of sweat lodge ceremonials and suggestions on sports cars. Merrill Cornish, for his stunning description of redbuds in bloom. Arlene and Joe McCrea, for saints’ names and descriptions of plowing with a mule. Ken Brown, for details of the Presbyterian Baptismal rite (much abridged in the text). David Stanley, Scotland’s next great writer, for advice on anoraks, jackets, and the difference between them.

Barbara Schnell, for German translations, error-checking, and sympathetic reading.

Dr. Ellen Mandell, for medical opinions, close reading, and useful suggestions for dealing with inguinal hernias, abortion, and other forms of harrowing bodily trauma.

Dr. Rosina Lippi-Green, for details of Mohawk life and customs, and notes on Scots linguistics and German grammar.

Mac Beckett, for his notion of new and ancient spirits.

Jack Whyte, for his memoirs of life as a Scottish folksinger, including the proper response to kilt jokes.

Susan Davis, for friendship, boundless enthusiasm, dozens of books, descriptions of pulling ticks off her kids—and the strawberries.

Walt Hawn and Gordon Fenwick, for telling Claire how long is a furlong. John Ravenscroft and miscellaneous members of the UKForum, for a riveting discussion of the RAF’s underpants, circa WWII. Eve Ackerman and helpful members of the CompuServe SFLIT Forum, for the publication dates of Conan the Barbarian.

Barbara Raisbeck and Mary M. Robbins, for their helpful references on herbs and early pharmacology.

My anonymous library friend, for the reams of useful references.

Arnold Wagner and Steven Lopata, for discussions of high and low explosives and general advice on how to blow things up.

Margaret Campbell and other online residents of North Carolina, for miscellaneous descriptions of their fair state.

John L. Myers, both for telling Claire about his ghosts, and for generously allowing Claire to incorporate certain elements of his physique and persona into the formidable John Quincy Myers, Mountain Man. The hernia is fictitious.

As always, thanks also to the many members of the CompuServe Literary Forum and Writers Forum whose names have escaped my memory, for their helpful suggestions and convivial conversation, and to the AOL folderfolk for their stimulating discussions.
